Title: Iina Paarma I Chief, Talent Development, UNDP Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Welcome to the United Nations Career Journey Podcast, where we interview colleagues working for the United Nations all around the world. Our conversations explore their fascinating career paths, what career satisfaction means to them, and how they keep learning and developing on the job. My name is Petra, and today, our conversation is with Iina Paarma who works as a Chief of the Talent Development Unit at the UNDP’s Office of Human Resources based in Copenhagen, Denmark. Welcome to the Career Journey Podcast Iina, it’s good to see you. And thank you very much for joining us. It’s a pleasure to have you as our guest speaker on the podcast.
Hi, Petra. Thank you. It’s my pleasure to be here with you today.
Thank you again. And could you introduce yourself to our listeners?
Absolutely. So, my name is Iina Paarma. And as Petra said, I’m the Chief of the Talent Development Unit at UNDP. I’m also a proud mother of two children. And I grew up in Finland and sometime in my early teenage years, I started dreaming of an international career in international development.
Lovely, thank you very much. My first question that I want to ask about your career is how did you begin your career? It can be internships, or maybe first job, so what was the start of your career?
Well, during my studies, I did have a chance to do an internship in my home country’s representation office in Vienna, in Austria. And I also studied one term in Geneva, as an exchange student during my master’s studies. And another one actually in Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia. But after completing my master’s degrees, I actually landed a job in the private sector, and then actually another job in the private sector. But somewhere during those years, I did realize that the sort of the dream to be part of the UN, or the international community, had actually never really disappeared. And so, I started applying for jobs in different international organizations. This was already around the time when I was approaching 30. It took it took almost three years, but then late 2012, I got my first assignment with UNOPS, actually here in Copenhagen, and I spent a number of years in that agency. And then, in 2017, I joined UNDP, in New York City after having applied for a position that I found on UNDP Jobs site.
Thank you for this introduction, Iina. And how was the transition into getting into UNDP, after spending time in the private sector and also in another UN organization? And also, which specific tools have been useful for you for this transition, and during this transition?
Yeah, I mean, when I joined the UN, then in 2012, early 2013, that’s when I was coming from the private sector, and I joined UNOPS in Copenhagen. So that transition wasn’t actually that, you know, that big one. It was really a dream to come true. But in terms of specific tools that have been useful, I think, first of all, I’ve tried to do my job as well as I only can. And secondly, you know, I have hopped on every opportunity that was given to me. And early on in the UN, in UNOPS, I also had fantastic bosses who believed in me and took me to meetings, and, you know, let me job shadow them. And that has been incredibly powerful, and I am really, forever grateful for this. And it was a pivotal steppingstone for me to be able to be sort of, on-the-job mentored by my people manager early on in my UN days. Then in terms of tools in general, I mean, I learned incredibly much from interactions with others. So, in that sense, the transition to the UN wasn’t a difficult one, it was a fascinating one.
That’s very good to hear. And I think these points are can be very useful for someone who is trying to look for maybe inspiration or ways to do that step to get into the UN system, but also just career tips in general. So, thank you so much for, for sharing those. So, your role as the Chief of the Talent Development Unit, could you explain a little bit to our listeners what is it about, what are some of the tasks that are a part of your daily job?
Yeah. So, you know, UNDP, we’re a big organization, we are close to 20,000 people in 170 countries. So, this role is really to lead the Talent Development Unit that focuses on leadership development, people manager development, career experiences, capability development. So, we have the three sort of main components in the unit. And overall, we are catering for the talent needs of the whole organization. We are really looking at talent development and learning as something that happens in the flow of work. It’s, it’s not a one-off sort of exercise, it’s sort of part of our DNA as an organization. We believe that creating a learning organization is something that is embedded in every aspect of the organization. And UNDP puts a lot of effort in talent development, we see that as a catalyst for organizational performance, for sure. But also, people’s careers, their career development, and their professional development.
This is great, and working with learning and talents, that must be something very rewarding for you as well, to help the people to develop themselves. But I would like to ask you my next question, and that is, what do you like the most about your role? What aspects of your job of your current job bring you career satisfaction?
I think for me, I am a people person. So definitely teamwork and learning from others. And the fact that I do feel very privileged to have the opportunity to work with people from all over the world, it is extremely rewarding to constantly, you know, develop oneself as one hears about other people’s perspectives based on their backgrounds, you know, be it educational, or cultural, or other backgrounds. The UN is also a big part of my identity. So, so serving this greater purpose of the UN is something that brings me enormous satisfaction. So then when I think about the current role, our team is not in the frontlines of international development. But what brings us satisfaction is the fact that we can develop the ones who are closer to our beneficiaries. And we can see that directly translated into better results on the ground.
That sounds great. And I think this is something that is a big motivating factor for many people working at the UN. And you also mentioned that it was your dream, when you were younger, that, you know, you really wanted to work for the UN. So, it’s actually great that it’s now a part of your daily motivation and career satisfaction. On the other hand, what are some of the more challenging, perhaps, aspects of your job? Or something that you need to continuously work with? Could you just share some of those with our listeners?
Yeah, you know, I think in terms of challenges, this is a global organization that’s present in 170 countries like I mentioned, and this means that someone is always awake, and the work never stops. So, I would say, you know, UN colleagues in general are very committed, you know, hardworking people. So, it’s very easy to sort of get into that sort of ‘someone is always awake’ mode. So, I would say that what I’m trying to learn is to manage myself in such a way that I allow enough time to rest and recharge, so as to be the best version of myself in the workplace.
That’s very good to highlight because I think this topic is very important. And to highlight the need for, you know, strengthening your resilience and well-being is something very important. So, thank you for bringing that to the discussion. And that actually kind of leads to my next question. Sometimes our mental health can be challenged by big changes, challenging moments, and it can take a toll on how we feel about our careers. So my next question is, could you share a time in your career where you had some big changes in responsibilities of your role, and how did you approach it and what did you learn from it?
Yeah, I think, I think maybe the sort of critical juncture for me was when I joined UNDP, in 2017, and moved to New York, the new role was quite different from my previous role and UNDP, as an organization also worked in a very different way than my previous organization. So I think I learned to appreciate that it takes some time to grasp the new context and asking the right questions and understanding that, you know, one should not assume that what worked well in your previous role and organization is, is sort of directly applicable in the in the new content, or in the new context. I think the learnings maybe happened, sort of, in some kind of internal after-action review and reflection, also now in hindsight, realizing that UN, especially when it comes to relocations, those are not only your decisions, if you have family members who are joining you, and so, so certainly reflecting afterwards, the appreciation of the willingness of my family to join me and also looking back at not only those years, but also throughout my career in the UN, as someone who was raising children as well, I am having such gratitude and sort of humility. And understanding that those people around me, you know, grandparents and relatives and their immediate family members have certainly been enablers for me, and for that I am, I am very grateful.
That’s lovely, thank you so much for sharing that. And, yeah, I can totally imagine that these changes of relocating to a different country, different continent, changing your are a big milestone in everyone’s lifetime. And so sharing those learning outcomes might be very useful and good to hear, and I’m sure a lot of our listeners can relate to it as well. Talking about living abroad and having different international experiences, experiences from different career paths and career experiences, what are some of the best tips you have gathered throughout your career so far, when it comes to either creating a career that you like, creating a satisfying career, or just navigating a career in general?
Well, I think it’s important to follow your heart and your passion, when you enjoy what you do, it makes, it makes it all so much easier. And it shows also in the results you deliver, you know, when I grew up, the mentality was a little bit like, you know, job is a job, and then life happens outside of the job, and you should sort of play the same card, you know, study hard and get a job that you can have until you retire. And, you know, we all know, especially the young generations, that those days are over. So, I think maybe, you know, understanding that these type of career moves and career aspirations, they always come with a certain risk. You can’t have it all, you know, you should always in mind, you follow your passion, and understand that that’s not necessarily always the most sort of stable path. But if that’s what you truly want, you should go for it. And then I think in general, I mean, when it comes to sort of career tips, I’m not sure if I’m the best one to share any of those. Once someone much wiser than me told me that, you know, essentially, there are two ways to plan your career, either you go with the flow, or you have clear goals of the type of roles and profiles you’re aspiring for, and then, you know, you make a roadmap and follow that path. Honestly, I have personally been one of the sorts of go with the flow type of profiles. And, you know, that has worked for me. I have jumped on the opportunities that had been in front of me, and sometimes it’s been daunting, but I would say, you know, go for it. All jobs are extremely valuable. You learn things in whatever role you have, for however short time you would have that, you know, it teaches you about the role itself, but it also allows you to meet different people who might have different tips.
These are really great tips and advice and I’m sure the listeners will find it very helpful because I think it’s always good to be reminded of, you know, following the passion and having that as the guiding… guiding light of when you’re trying to navigate through the career so, so thank you very much for that. I’d like to ask you, where would you like to be career-wise in the next coming years? Or do you have any maybe aspirations as well? I know you just shared with us that you prefer to, you know, maybe go with the flow. But is there anything you’d like to achieve in the next coming years in terms of your career?
Oh, thanks for the question. You know, I love my current role. I‘ve been in this role for some 18 months. And I feel that I still have quite a lot to give in this current position. And then future will show what’s the what’s next in in store for me.
Well thank you very much, and I wish you all the best! I really enjoyed our conversation. And I found it very interesting and insightful. And yeah, I hope you had a good time as well.
Absolutely. My pleasure Petra, and keep up with the great job, great work that you’re doing here with the podcast.
Thank you very much! And thank you to all our listeners. We hope you enjoyed this episode and that our conversations will inspire you to keep learning and advancing in your careers. If you liked the episode, please share it with your friends and colleagues, and make sure to tune in for the next one.
--
--

Title: A small towner Indian in Denmark
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
4
Listen
Share
Just about a year ago I moved into this incredibly small and beautiful country called Denmark all the way from India to pursue my PhD. I had dreamt about it for a long time and it was so surreal when I actually landed in Copenhagen. Noone back home understood why I chose this strange far away cold land when I could have been applying to top universities in the US; hustling away in pursuit of an empire I had no desire to build in the first place. To me, a safe, happy and a peaceful place would make moving my entire life to another country absolutely worth it. Copenhagen consistently ranked among the top three livable cities in the world while Denmark is popularly known for being one of the happiest countries across the entire world. I knew that as an expat the rules would be different; I wouldn’t share the same benefits that the Danes enjoy and perhaps, my opinions about the happiness index would be different from how the Danes perceive it. That is not say that the index is wrong because it is indeed the opinions of the Danish citizens that actually matter.
My priorities in life were always different. I didn’t care about owning a car and a house to display how successful I was in my social circle. To me, peace of mind, having just enough of what you need and want, and respect were above materialistic desires. That is not to say that money didn’t matter to me. I want to be wealthy in terms of experiences, good health, healthy relationships and money is just a part of wealth. As an overly anxious, introverted and sensitive person, I learnt from a very young age what my triggers were and how to cope with them and so I knew that working in an annoyingly bureaucratic corporate structure and culture was not for me. While I have financially successful friends I really respect and admire, I have no desire to talk the same language as them. I started working young and ensured that I would never have to borrow money from my parents anymore whether it was for my education or materialistic pursuits. If I couldn’t afford it, I wouldn’t buy it. I chose academia simply because at the time it gave me the freedom to think, read, and write the way I wanted and I was given due credit for it. I wanted to move away right after my Masters but my father was clear that unless I had a scholarship, it wouldn’t be worth it. And, that’s when it all began! A six year long journey post my Masters making peanuts but doing what I loved, saving just enough to finally take the leap. I had my eyes on Denmark for many reasons, the most important being safety and gender equality.
One year down and I wouldn’t call it perfect but I know it in my gut that I made the right choice. They ask, what was the biggest culture shock for you when you moved here? I laugh! Because India has given me far more cultural shocks than I expect to experience anywhere else. I have lived in different parts of India and navigated life across language and cultural barriers. We were united by the delicious food and our diversity itself! I am grateful for my journey from a tiny Indian town noone knows of to this beautiful city where I am living the life I always dreamt of. Life in India prepared me for life in a strange country I had absolutely no connection to. The struggles are not unfamiliar— a different language, the lack of a social circle, having to find an affordable living arrangement, getting familiar with the rules and regulations. Things that took me a while getting adjusted to was the right-hand traffic and the fact that there was barely any traffic :D Sure, the weather is rough and the winters are dark and the Danes are reserved (you know the stereotype), but every single day I am in awe of how this tiny little dot on the world map evolved into an architectural beauty, home to some of the largest MNCs and holding an impressive reputation of being politically progressive.
Danmark er virkelig et dejligt land! There was not a single day when a Dane refused to help a “confused” me trying to get used to the city. Often they would greet with a pleasant smile and would appreciate you trying to speak a little bit of broken Danish while making small talk. I deliberately chose to work with a Danish supervisor for two reasons — first I wanted to push myself to work with unfamiliar people (since Indians tend to flock to each other everywhere in the world; I am guilty of this too) and second, I had some serious toxic boss baggage from India that I knew would ease off in the flat heirarchical structure Scandanivian countries are famous for. Wait, I could call my seniors by their first names and they wouldn’t mind? And did you say they don’t call you after work hours (they never call you at all if you are lucky)? Also, you are not obligated to respond to their emails after 5 pm? Wait, did they ask for my opinion? Oh wait, the professors consider their PhD students “colleagues” and not slaves? And…whaaattt!! I am paid a living wage as a PhD student? To me, this was a dream! This is where I felt I could become a well-rounded person whose opinions were equally important and my gender didn’t decide how much I was paid.
I won’t lie I did have my own insecurities (thanks to our colonial past and the ensuing inferiority complex). I was in this land full of white people with beautiful blue/green eyes and blond hair, ones I had only seen on Television up until I moved to Denmark. Soon enough I realised we are bonded by similar desires and experiences that is only natural to the humankind and it is not the color of our skin but our openness to embracing the unknown that really mattered. Sure, I felt unseen many times in a conversation across a table that only white people could connect to (endless discussions over the origins of wine and cheese like we talk about chai and samosas) but this would be followed by a few empathetic people (or those afraid to be perceived as politically incorrect…kidding!) displaying a little bit of curiosity into my culture. I was suddenly representing India in these conversations; not my tiny hometown, not the cities that I lived in but the rich and diverse country that India is. I was educating people who had these preconceived biases against the Indians, some of which were quite ridiculous and rude to be frank (if you don’t eat red meat, you are religious; most of India is polluted, poor and filthy). Some of them had ill-informed opinions about Hinduism and the political situation in the country! On the other hand I was surprised by how India was perceived by Europeans in general. Many considered it to be the land of CEOs, shooting for the galaxies, full of lucrative investment opportunities, ofcourse Bollywood and interestingly home to the good “green stuff” (if you know what I mean ;)). Some applauded me for the bold choice to move to a cold country all the way from India while some struggled to grasp why any South Asian would want to move to this part of the world. I just enjoyed the ride! I am not one to get offended easily. It is only natural to have your prejudices but come to me with an open mind and I will answer all your questions. How you frame your words and the way you speak them tells me a bit about your upbringing and the conscious efforts you put into educating yourself to get rid of your biases often shaped by problematic western constructs. So hey! It has nothing to do with the color of your skin. You can be brown, white, black, straight, gay, queer and whatever you identify as and still be a vile person. In Denmark though, I have mostly met the nicest and most open minded people. They are not intrusive (which unfortunately we Indians could be most of the time), they are polite and respectful of other’s time and space, they call a spade a spade and they really do have a wonderful life outside of work (hygge anyone???). This is the place where I feel my own person, where nobody cares about my age, gender, marital status and whether or not I have kids. I am a far more evolved person than I was when I first moved here and I am doing things I never believed I would be able to do.
So that’s my first Medium post here, a short story of an Indian smalltowner in Denmark. Not sure if I would still call this the happiest place in the world but this sure is the happiest I have ever been :)
--
--
4
Introverted, politically incorrect, tad bit socially awkward. A desi navigating life in Denmark!

Title: Copenhagen. One year after.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I remember well the last days before I left my Vilnius. Days, where I have been walking in the city, going to the places that I have always wanted to, but did not have time for it, spending time with my family and meeting with good old friends. Those days were great. However, the time flies fast. And even though I was quite excited to start a new life in a foreign country, I was also a bit worried. Who will be my new friends? When will Ifind a job? Will I like the studies? How will Copenhagen greet me? After a year of living here, I have found some answers.
Copenhagen greeted me with big white clouds and the hustle in the airport. The hustle of the people greeting their fellow travelers and the hustle of the people running for their planes. An airport is a place where people come and go. And I was one of the many arrived to Copenhagen. I remember that I was not at all impressed by Copenhagen in the first days. So many buildings so similar to each other, so few green spaces compressed between them and cyclists with their angry faces.
It is now, a year after living in Copenhagen, I understand that Copenhagen has so much to offer. Small details matter in this city and it feels like the community is trying to make it with a personal touch. Buildings in different neighborhoods do not look alike and there are very nice green spaces within the city. Only my perception of cyclists did not change.
Nevertheless, I came here to study Organizational Innovations and Entrepreneurship (OIE) — a masters program organized by Copenhagen Business School (CBS). The program offered quite an interesting path of studying, combining theoretical knowledge and practical classes with the most diverse class that I’ve been a part of in my life.
The beginning of the studies was quite interesting. We’ve had an introduction week, organized by previous OIE students, where we had a chance to visit some of the most prominent startup hubs and companies in Copenhagen, mingle together and get to know what awaits us in the future.
And the future was…
Studies at OIE program comprise of two different sets of subjects divided into 4 quarters throughout the first year. One subject will be practical (lectures which are happening in Studio) and the other one — theoretical. On the second year of education students are allowed to choose between exchange, electives, summer university or internship. Or it can be a mix of everything (up to 30 ECTS credits). After that — only master thesis and graduation, where everybody is happy :)
But let’s get back to the first year with compulsory subjects. As it was mentioned before there were 4 quarters with different focuses:
Furthermore, we have also had an elective course — study trip to Silicon Valley, where we have met 28 different companies throughout 2 weeks. You can read more about it in my previous stories on Medium (beginning, part 1, part 2).
As the courses implied, we have been working hard on different business ideas every quarter. I remember it like yesterday:
Q1. Developing an app for finding people/friends with similar interests
Q2. Developing a lip balm for winter sports enthuziasts
Q3. Developing a YouTube channel about local undiscovered places
Q4. Researching the “precariat” & changing spaces (in our case — CPH Village and containers made livable).
Plus we’ve had some of the theoretical classes related to the classical understanding of entrepreneurship, strategic management of innovations, the art of innovation (like design-driven innovation) and some other interesting activities combined together.
Last, but not least, CBS really tries hard to develop in us the entrepreneurial spirit, creating opportunities for the students to go further and make the ideas real. As part of our program, we have been also introduced to Copenhagen School of Entrepreneurship, whereas we, if there is any business idea, could try to get in and use the co-working spaces, advisors and other useful programs for free throughout the different stages of development.
Overall, the OIE program allows to develop the skills and abilities, necessary for becoming an entrepreneur or working with innovations within different fields. Plus, if you have a business idea — you can go for it. Nevertheless, the living costs in Copenhagen are not cheap and a big part of a Danish student life will be described in the next chapter.
Most of the students in Denmark are combining studies with student jobs. That’s a fact. Even though they are generously paid by the government scheme called SU, they are still working as part-time employees in different companies, starting from cafes and bars and ending with study-related jobs.
As my finances did not allow me to live here for two years without having an actual job, I started to look for the new opportunities in Copenhagen. Even though it took me some time (including exams and other activities) to find an actual first job (to be precise — 4 months), I had a great experience learning how the Danish job market operates.
Throughout the 4-month period I had 6 job interviews with different companies, where I had a chance to present myself and also get to know the other side of the table. In the end, I have landed a job at a local food chain, where I have been working as Operations Assistant, learning to deal with numbers, revenues, Excel and developing programs. Nevertheless, during the summer situation has changed and I have to find a new job, which I would like to learn from most, combining my previous experience with my skills and knowledge.
One lesson that I have learned throughout the year — try to be more unique in every aspect that goes throughout the job search adventure. And, the most important, show the companies what you can bring to the advertised position and show that you are a valuable person worth the salary that you will get while working there.
Pro tip: students from EU — if you have a part-time job, working min. 10–12 hours/week — apply for a student scholarship (SU) to be equal with Danish students. More info: www.su.dk
What is a student life without fun? The answer is easy — it is not a student life. People, with whom you are studying, can bring a lot of joy, happiness and adventures throughout the years that you will be studying together and, most probably, they will become the friends for life.
I had the honor to meet with people from different countries and cultures, with whom I had a lot of fun and great things done together. Copenhagen is a great city, where if you want to do something — you will find it. It offers a wide variety of events, places, bars, cafes, parks where you can hang out with your friends, meet even more people and learn about Danish traditions. And, the most important thing, not to be lonely, because sometimes that feeling of being such can come.
Last year I have visited many different places and hometowns of my friends — Bornholm, Aalborg, San Francisco, Asturias. I have also participated in many local traditional events and learned more about Danish culture and who are Danes. Funny enough, but while being in Denmark, I have learned a lot about Mexican culture :) I had a lovely Christmas-New Year’s Eve period, seeing the local traditions and participating in them, seeing how Danes can be welcoming and how cozy are their homes.
Pro tip: check out the Survival Guide in Denmark, it is a great guide to find almost everything you need before your arrival or during your stay.
The first year in Denmark was an amazing experience. The weather was great (4 months of sun in a row), the people are awesome, the studies and the job gave me lots of new skills and knowledge.
I believe that the next year will be even better, with more interesting discoveries, experiences and amazing people. Especially now, when everybody will be back in Copenhagen and will be ready to rock’n’roll.
24–08–2018, Copenhagen, Denmark
--
--
An Entrepreneurship graduate trying to find his own place in the world by reading, listening, writing and talking with awesome people.

Title: Sustainable cities: Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Copenhagen, Denmark (population of 799,033 as of 2020)
Copenhagen aims to be the world’s first carbon-neutral capital city by 2025 (The CPH 2025 Climate Plan, Copenhagen — Urban Development). Politically, the city also intends to demonstrate how it is possible for big cities to combine growth, development, and an enhanced quality of life while reducing carbon emissions at the same time. This goal sets Copenhagen as a frontrunner in the international arena.
Copenhagen designed its Climate Plan Roadmap in three phases and set on the first phase of the net-zero journey in 2013 with the ultimate goal to become carbon neutral by 2025. The plan was developed in line with the emergence of new knowledge and technology, as continued innovation allowed to make carbon reduction strategies possible and at scale. At the same time, the CPH 2025 Climate Plan seeks to enhance the quality of life for Copenhageners using carbon neutrality goals to change behavior and stimulate innovation, job creation and investments.
By 2018, Copenhagen has successfully achieved a reduction of carbon emissions per capita by 57% while the city’s population grew by 22%. This reduction was mostly due to the green conversion of power-generation and district heating systems from coal to biomass and the erection of wind turbines.
Figures 5, 6: Copenhagen carbon emissions actual and projected, 2005–2025
According to Figure 6, while the 2018 progress has been remarkable, it will require significant additional efforts to reach the 2025 targets. This aggressive goal is based on the city’s climate plan’s four pillars: (1) Energy consumption, (2) Energy production, (3) Mobility with reduced emissions, and (4) City Administration initiatives.
Energy consumption. This pillar primarily focuses on achieving energy efficiency for district heating and transitioning from oil to renewable energy systems. City of Copenhagen collaborates with large building owners on efficient management of their properties by monitoring their energy consumption and optimizing building operations.
Energy production. Copenhagen is powered mostly by renewable energy with more than 50% of electricity supplied by wind and solar, and approximately 80% of all electricity coming from renewable energy sources including bioenergy and geothermal energy (“A record year: Wind and solar supplied more than half of Denmark’s electricity in 2020.” State of Green). The city has ambitious efforts to add at least 460MW from wind turbines by 2025.
Mobility covers two groups of transportation: road and maritime. The city plans to convert all its public busses, road and harbor busses, to renewable energy sources and run on electricity, biodiesel, bioethanol, biogas, natural gas-electric hybrids or hydrogen fuel cell busses. The city is looking to expand public transportation and promote the use of bicycles to travel around the city. In addition to achieving a reduction of CO2 emissions, this initiative will have the benefit of significantly less street noise and reduced local air pollution (“Copenhagen aims to become a carbon neutral capital/Sustainable Transit.” Green City Times).
City Administration. This category sets an example for the Administration to lead the way to reduce the city’s energy consumption, green procurement and transition of the city’s vehicles and infrastructure to operate on alternative fuels. This is important in stimulating public-private partnerships, cooperation with other municipalities and other organizations, and engaging the citizens in the green transformation.
Copenhagen is showing an impressive reduction in carbon emissions. Two specific projects the city is proud of are EnergyLab Nordhavn and seawater use for cooling (“This is how Copenhagen plans to go carbon neutral by 2025.” World Economic Forum). EnergyLab Nordhavn is located in Copenhagen’s waterfront city district North Harbor. The EnergyLab was launched in 2015 in close partnership between academia, industry, utilities, and local government to design a full-scale smart city energy lab with innovative solutions in the areas such as intelligent waste handling, low-temperature district heating, clean public transportation, and super cycle highways. This project is looking at the whole energy system as one, integrating heat, electricity, and transport and testing new solutions such as large batteries and EVs to reduce peak load on the grid, intelligent heating of buildings, and a heat pump and storage system to improve flexibility and optimize local district heating network (“Cities 100: Copenhagen’s new Nordhavn neighborhood is a center of innovation for small energy systems.” C40 Knowledge).
Copenhagen also uses seawater from the harbor for its cooling system with the potential to cut emissions by 70% and keep about 80,000 tons of carbon out of the city’s direct atmosphere. In addition to the climate and environmental benefits, it costs less, takes up less space and it makes no noise. It works by pumping seawater of about 6C, using this water for the district water supply and returning water at about 16C back to the harbor (“Seawater keeps Copenhagen buildings cool.” Climate Change Adaptation).
This is a case study for the main article, Urban Path to Net-Zero: Leading Strategies of the Most Energy-Efficient Cities.
[1] World Economic Forum: This is how Copenhagen plans to go carbon-neutral by 2025. weforum.org/agenda/2019/05/the-copenhagen-effect-how-europe-can-become-heat-efficient
[2] Danfoss Engineering Tomorrow: Seawater cools Copenhagen, cutting 70% emissions. www.danfoss.com/en/service-and-support/case-stories/dds/seawater-cools-copenhagen-city-cutting-emissions-by-70
--
--
Executive, climate strategist, impact investor, and champion for a sustainable future.

Title: My experience at GOTO Copenhagen 2019
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are the Swiss leader in online banking. Discover technology and techniques used by our software engineers.

--
Listen
Share
This is a short summary of what I saw in the conference, what I liked and didn't like and what I think was most interesting or worth notice considering my personal preferences and needs.
It was my first international conference and also the biggest conference I've attended so far, so please take that into account when reading this.
The conference had a good amount of different topics, I was satisfied with the balance between topics related with soft and hard skills, although, some of the mandatory talks could be frustrating to some people due to the lack of technical points or a practical guides.
Talks presented by partners (sponsors) weren’t simply trying to sell their solution, but were tackling problems or showing general solutions that can benefit you or your company even if you don’t use the partner specific solution. It was great to see the power of Kafka, GraphQL and Erlang/Elixir.
I was happy to be able to catch up on some topics like AI and quantum computing, the talks in general were well presented, not too long or too short and relevant. I felt that some topics should have had less talks considering that talks on similar subject were already present as part of the mandatory talks (AI and machine learning for example). I believed that the topics could had been better distributed (maximum number of talks per topic). On another side I understand that some redundancy is built-in for the different days and for people that might not be able to attend certain talks due do conflicts with parallel sessions. I understand that it’s not an easy to solve problem, and even with these remarks the overall experience was incredibly positive.
On a personal note I really liked the talk from Saša Jurić about Erlang and Elixir, seeing what Erlang and Elixir can do really gave me the extra push needed to dive into it. The talk from Adam Tornhill "Prioritizing Technical Debt as if Time and Money Matters" gave me a new perspective and even actionable points (although not easy) to deal with the trade-off between improving existing code and adding new features. Finally I was surprised with the extreme digitization in China presented by Christina Boutrup, it gave great insights which I believe are not on the radar of standard western people.
I currently live in Switzerland and I have to say that the Danes seemed to me to be even more punctual and organized! No real issues with talks being late or running over time, the duration and number of breaks helping to keep your attention on each talk you attend. Registration and overall logistical organization was very good ( quality of the food and amount of options was great).
The area for partners was cool and well structured, good amount of swag and most partners were easy to interact and have a good conversation during the quick breaks between talks.
One point that I really didn’t like was the amount of talks that were not being recorded, I don’t have enough conference experience to know how much this is common practice but feeling forced to attend to certain talks that might, or not, be of interest just for fear of missing out isn’t a great feeling in my opinion.
I didn't know most of the speakers, but was satisfied with the quality of the talks. As celebrities go, it was cool to see Steve Wozniak in person!
Most of the talks contributed more or less in the same way and a lot of them helped me into catching up with the current state of the industry (at least in a high-level view).
I'm less scared about AI and I think the field still has to evolve a lot before an AI tries to destroy humanity, still I would bet that many people will have their jobs taken by AI based solutions, but it's difficult to say how fast this will happen even for specialists in the field.
China is really a place to pay attention to, we can learn from them, as they seem to be able to foster innovation despite being very restrictive on their market and ideas.
Machine learning is finding more efficient and precise methods to do things in ways that humans can't understand, so it’s something I think everyone should pay more attention to as the results so far are already impressive (and seem to be less dangerous than what we normally associate with AI apocalypse, although strongly related).
Elixir is really awesome and I need to start experimenting and learning asap.
There are different ways to handle the trade-off between adding new functionality and improving existing code, I have much to learn!
The new perspective from Adam Tornhill is something that I believe will have an immediate positive impact on my daily work as in any fast paced and competitive business it’s part of the day to day job to weight the benefits of improving existing code versus the many new features that business requires in the short and long term. This talk gave me a different perspective on how to look at the problem and directions on what needs to be considered on a more technical and practical stand for me to be able to keep the best balance between business value added and the long term evolution of our platforms, while also keeping our 24/5 high frequency trading system competitive.
As a possible mid/long term contribution I think I would like to partner with our big data and BI teams and see what I can do using machine learning to improve the overall business. I now, more than before, believe that machine learning can really help businesses to take big leaps forward in ways that we humans simply can’t predict.
I wish I have the time and opportunity to put some Elixir in action at Swissquote as I believe that the very nature of the business can benefit immensely from the platform features (Erlang/Elixir) that support high availability, fast recovery and the benefits of the actor based model (processes in Elixir). Perfect for my needs in the Forex business line!
Thank you for you attention.
Did you like what you read? Join me at Swissquote:https://careers.smartrecruiters.com/Swissquote/tech-jobs
--
--

Title: Can a Copenhagen based startup scale to global success?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
GUEST ENTRY: Pleo’s Jeppe Rindom gives his opinion on Copenhagen’s current ability to attract the best of the best.
Hi! My name is Jeppe Rindom and I am CEO and co-founder of Pleo, a fintech startup that automates expense reporting.
In 2015, my former colleague from Tradeshift, Niccolo, and I founded Pleo in Copenhagen. We had and still have big and global ambitions but with the limited access to digital talent in Denmark, we wondered, right from the beginning, if we would ever be able to scale a global company without moving our base.
It is evident that digital graduates are produced at a much slower pace than what our fellow startups (and desperate ‘we-fear-disruption’ corporates) are screaming for. But hey, our country has pretty architecture, bikes, great food, and the happiest people in the world. So, as bold entrepreneurs we figured; ‘let’s not bring Pleo to the talent — Let’s bring the talent to Pleo!’
Fast forward 30 months, our organisation now counts +40 employees and more than half are non-Danes. What a great success one might conclude, but actually I would argue the opposite, because only in one single case did we, as a company, succeed in convincing an international candidate to relocate to Denmark. And in this specific case, the relocation was caused by a strong friendship to an existing employee.
We consider Pleo a fairly attractive workplace. We’ve been recognized with international prizes and have attracted substantial investments from venture capital firms. I believed so much in our ability to attract international talent that I naively wrote a blog post with the title ‘Let’s conquer the World, not each other!’, which was a shout to the Danish digital ecosystem to hire internationally instead of stealing talent locally. Yet, we’ve never been able do so. But Why?
The Danish ‘package’ is not competitive
As much as I am proud of the Danish welfare system as well as the Capital of Copenhagen, I have come to the conclusion that the Danish ‘package’ sounds much more compelling than it is.
A classic Danish startup package looks somewhat like this:
1) a non-competitive salary, which is really no news if you want to work in startups.
2) high taxation due to our welfare system. Here you might say ‘you get what you pay for’, but that’s actually not true. Most candidates we’ve tried to relocate have a 3 to 7 year perspective for staying in Denmark. They are at a stage in their lives, where access to free education, free healthcare etc. is of very little value.
3) a high cost of living. Being a foreigner without a place to stay in Copenhagen is really tough. Even if you’re willing to settle for just a room in a shared apartment, you will likely end up paying +€1K a month.
On point 1 and 3, Copenhagen is not much different from cities like London, Paris and Stockholm but on taxation, our offering is much worse. And that’s not only a shame, it’s a deal breaker.
So, how have we made it to first base?
I’ve always had mixed feelings when it comes to our ‘open’ (read: free for EU citizens) education system. Today, I praise myself lucky. It saved my a.. Big Time. When we were 1.5 year into the journey, we, as everybody else, couldn’t recruit Danish digital talent, and when our team turned 15 employees, I was still the only Dane. Looking around me, I realised that everyone else were here because of our good and open education system. Luckily for us, many had decided to stay after graduation and in hindsight, I should have done more to build relationships to schools and universities and would encourage any startup to do so.
Second, we right from the beginning had an international company culture. My co-founder is Italian so the Danish way was really never an option. It was of course an obvious thing for us, as our ambitions goes far beyond Danish borders, but our strong international company culture has also become a strong selling point when we hire. Today, Pleo has 14 different nationalities and we still have strong focus on maintaining a welcoming, family-like company culture.
Third, we have had a lot of media attention both inside and outside of Denmark. Today, it mostly relates to our business traction, but in the beginning we did serious efforts to create some buzz, both in terms of being present at conferences, startup events and constantly trying to get media coverage. That helped us tremendously — also in our recruiting.
Fourth, our foreign employees have been great at enabling their networks. Because of that, we today have a handful of engineers working remotely. And it has worked surprisingly well, not something I expected initially and that I believe is strong correlated to the fact that all remote workers were familiar with other Pleo folks (and vice versa) right from the beginning. So get your employees to enable their networks! Chances are that they already know a handful of relevant candidates.
We praise ourselves lucky to have made it to first base. But I fear that more challenges will come when targeting second base and growing our product organisation from 15 to 50 in the foreseeable future.
The bigger picture
We have to join forces on promoting Copenhagen as a European techhub. Organisations like CPHFTW and Copenhagen Capacity are doing a great job building, empowering, and promoting our tech community. But there’s a need for more ambassadors spreading great stories of the Danish tech ecosystem. We just hired a candidate who chose to move to Denmark before having a job. She decided to seek opportunities in Copenhagen (and relocate from Madrid) due to her positive perception of the Copenhagen startup scene. What a win!
We also need shared living at a reasonable price for foreign workers, who relocate to Denmark. Shared living initiatives such as LifeX have also proved to be social catalysts in the tech community. A place to meet like minded people outside of work. Being a foreigner and having social success in Denmark can be hard. Let’s admit it, Danes are pretty reserved when it comes to being inclusive of foreigners. Foreigners with a social headstart are more likely to stick around.
Lastly, I want to come back to our taxation. Our tax society has previously been creative, when facing the lack of talent. In the 90’s, we invented ‘expert taxation’ (in Danish: Forskerordningen), a favourable tax system for researchers and well paid employees recruited abroad. At that point in time, most of the Danish growth arrived from research-heavy organisations.
Today, our world is upside down. Big corporates face challenges maintaining growth and leadership positions and younger growth companies are contributing increasingly to the economic growth.
I strongly encourage Denmark to expand the ‘expert taxation’ agreement, so that tax incentives are created for medium-income but much-needed digital talent moving to Denmark.
Because there is no way we can scale our businesses without help from abroad. So let’s spread those great stories, let’s do our utmost to welcome foreign talent and let’s continue to push our politicians for more attractive framework conditions.
Jeppe
The opinions expressed in this article are those of the author.
___________________________________________________________________
Should #CPHFTW keep you updated on the Danish startup community? Sign up for our newsletter here!

Title: Getting married in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
"Why Copenhagen?" has been the common question when we told people we got married there. I am a Cambodian; my husband is English; and we live in Berlin. Wouldn't it make more sense to get married in Berlin, England, or Cambodia?
Yes, we did have a big fat wedding celebration in Cambodia. But more to that later. What I'm talking about is the legal/civil wedding where you sign a paper that legally binds you as husband and wife.
So… Yes, we live in Berlin. No, we don't speak very good German. This makes it hard because (1) we will then need an official translator at the wedding, (2) it would be tough throughout the whole application because of the limited German, (3) the paperwork is just too much. This article here could tell you more about everything you need to do to get married in Germany. One of the most ridiculous document you need to provide — in my opinion — is the Ehefähigkeitszeugnis aka Certificate of no impediment to marriage from your country of origin (and if I'm not mistaken, from all the countries you have lived at prior to Germany). Did I also mention certified copy of birth certificate? It's not easy business to get that for some countries.
And "why not the UK then"? Which is actually a good question. UK is a bit simpler (probably because it's all in English so we could understand stuffs), but then we found out there is this requirement that "In order to actually start the marriage process, you and your partner have to have been living in the UK for at least 7 days prior to notifying a designated registrar office of your plans to marry". Read more from this article.
So yeah. Getting married in Germany seems hard. Getting married in the UK was also tricky. Thanks to the sponsored Google ads, we found out that a lot of expats in Europe goes to Denmark to get married. It looked like Copenhagen was the Vegas of Europe! No joke! Looking deeper, it was not like Vegas. There's no drive-through or laundry weddings. I know, disappointing right? But still, everyone claimed it was the best decision one could do if one of us are not German and not willing to go through the bureaucracy. So yeah, we decided to do Copenhagen.
There is literally this website that we found: https://gettingmarriedindenmark.com/ that provided a very clear step by step explanation of what to do. (FYI this is not a sponsored post or anything, I'm simply sharing information) They also provide the consultation service that helps you through with a fee. Honestly, the process is simple enough that you probably would not need the service, but we got it just for the peace of mind (and admit it — less stress for the bride).
So here is what we did.
Voila! Now you just need to turn up for the wedding!
We got married at Copenhagen city hall. Everything was straightforward and relaxing, and the whole ceremony was done in less than 10 minutes. We did not even have to bring any witnesses — they have those if we need. The people who performed the ceremony was nice and friendly, and we felt really comfortable. You can do vows too if you like. We didn't though. None of us really like to say emotional stuffs, so we skipped it. We simply said "I do"and exchanged rings, and kissed. And oh, we signed the papers too.
It was just the two of us. So simple. So easy. Not a care in the world about guests, how we looked, or anything going wrong. We focused on getting married and did exactly JUST that.
As you could see, we dressed up a little though and had a photographer to capture the moment. You can skip all these and just rock up. I told the consultant agency what I was looking for, and they gave me some recommendations. However, there's plenty of photography, makeup, and flower services at different price points that you could go for if you google or check on instagram. They are pretty nice and friendly too, so just send them a text with your needs. Some people also opted for the fancier packages where you get married it at your own venue or a little off the bustling city center area.
None at all. We spent a bit of money but it was smooth and I recommend any expats living in Germany or Europe that struggles with the bureaucracy where they live to consider Copenhagen as their wedding destination. You can make it a little holiday and even invite people you care about to attend the ceremony.
Lots of love, from the newly Mrs ❤ Let me know if you have any questions or would like to know which photography and makeup service we used.
--
--
A Cambodian living in Portugal; Works in Tech; Lover of nice things

Title: Alex Martin’s Tour of the Danish Food Scene
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Alex Martin shares his love of history with people in Copenhagen, Denmark, through his job as a tour guide. This last Tuesday, April 5th, Martin led a food focused tour with a group of students from Semester at Sea.
Semester at Sea is a floating university where students from all over the world spend the semester taking classes on a ship, the MV World Odyssey. During the semester students get to travel to 10–13 different countries. While in country, they can travel independently or with field programs organized by Semester at Sea and tour companies from each country. Martin’s tour was with a group of journalism students.
Martin has been living in Copenhagen for 20 years. He started working as a tour guide because of his love for the city and his love for history. Because of his wide range of knowledge, he is able to lead tours related to a variety of topics. This tour focused on the food scene in Copenhagen, but just the day before Martin led another tour with Semester at Sea that focused on social movements with a group of political science students. Martin introduced the group of journalism students to the rich history of food in Denmark by telling them the story of rye bread, and its importance in the country. According to him, rye bread is a staple in most Nordic cultures because of its rich nutrients. The bread uses flour made from rye grain instead of wheat grain and includes a variety of seeds. Historically, people used to even put wood shavings in it to bulk up its nutritious value. Danish farmers used to use this bread as an edible plate and bring their leftovers to the fields for lunch, creating an open-faced sandwich called the smorgasbord. This practical and inexpensive dish was later adopted by bars who would serve it to clients in effort to get them to buy more drinks. The public really enjoyed these sandwiches and began to request specific flavors. The bars responded to this interest by making the smorgasbord a permanent item on the menu, and restaurants soon followed. Smorgasbord is now considered the national dish of Denmark and, although it has practical roots, it is presented as a delicate, elegant dish at many dining establishments.
After teaching the students about the history of rye bread and smorgasbord, Martin brought them to CPH Cooking Class to try and make the dish themselves. The group prepared three different variations of the dish. The first variation was vegetarian and consisted of buttered rye, boiled potatoes, mustard mayo, fried onions, and dill. The second was rye topped with chicken salad made of shredded chicken, mayo, green apple, green onion, and herbs. The last variation was fried fish and vegetables served on top of rye with lemon. Martin said the fish was a red spotted fish popular in Denmark because of its supply in the North Atlantic. The group was able to eat their creations with popular fruit juices while having time to ask Martin and the CPH Cooking Class staff questions before heading off to their next activity.
A short bus ride took Martin and his students to Reffen, a famous Copenhagen food market where the stands are made of recycled shipping containers. Martin explained that Denmark is one of the most sustainability focused countries in the world with a huge emphasis on recycling. Making food stands out of old shipping containers near the capitol’s shipping port is just one of the innovative Danish techniques that Martin taught about. He also pointed out a complex of student housing made from the recycled containers, a garbage incinerator that creates power for the city and has an artificial ski hill on top of it, a group of windmills near the coast, the importance of bikes in the city, and the use of recycled materials in Copenhagen’s hippie commune, Christiania. He gave the students free time to explore the food market, interview business owners, and taste more unique dishes. According to Martin, Reffen is a great place for aspiring chefs and business owners to enter Copenhagen’s already dense food industry.
For their last stop, Martin took the students to one of his personal favorite spots, Halls on the Plaza in the city center. This food market offers many take home options and is conveniently located downtown, making it a popular spot for Copenhagen residents on their way home from work. The plaza consists of two buildings constructed on top of an underground recycling complex. While it is expensive to rent a space at, the heavily trafficked area generates steady business making it another great place for people trying to enter the city’s food industry. Martin’s personal favorite things to buy at the plaza are fish cakes and chocolates.
Bellies full of Danish food and heads full of information, Martin took the group of students back to their ship. When asked if he likes his job he replied, “I get to learn new things every day, what’s not to like?”
Thank you to Kris Kodrich and Semester at Sea for facilitating this field class.
Written April 2022
--
--
Graduate student at Harvard Extension School with a passion for writing, storytelling, and media production.

Title: My flight Copenhagen — Vagar with Atlantic Airways
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I would like to share my overall impressions about the flight to the Faroe Islands and why I chose this airline.
The company made its first flight on March 1988. Since then, much has changed, and the company has become larger. Now Atlantic Airways has 184 employees. The fleet consists of 3 planes and 2 helicopters, the aircrafts are relatively new, including the brand new Airbus A320NEO and Leonardo AW139 helicopters. The airplanes and helicopters are named after the outstanding artists of the Faroe Islands.
The decision to fly to the Faroe Islands came very spontaneously, and there was little to no time for deliberation and plans. However, at the same time, I was pleasantly surprised by the cost of tickets, even when buying a mere 10 days before the departure.
As an experienced tourist, I decided to register on the site and get a frequent flyer card, but something went wrong, and I was confronted with an error on the website. Looking ahead, I would say that this is the only minus that I can note. In any case, I was not upset, as the primary goal was to buy flight tickets, and this can be done without any registration.
Go to the airline’s website, and right on the main page, you can immediately see all direct destinations:
North
South
There is also an option — to see the calendar of low prices.
The process of buying tickets is quite simple, all prices on the website are in Danish kroner. Choosing a date, you can see prices for a few days back and forth, which will allow you to find the best option.
You can also buy tickets using mobile apps on iOS and Android devices.
You can use the app or web to Check-in online, and you don’t need to print out boarding passes, you can use them directly from the mobile app.
Before buying tickets, I recommend checking the information if you need a visa since the Faroe Islands have their own permission.
Information on countries whose residents need a visa can be found here.
If you still need a visa, the list of embassies can be found here.
The Faroe Islands are not part of the Schengen Area, and therefore you can’t get here using a Danish visa. You must apply directly for an Island visa.
After all the preparations had been completed, finally the long-awaited day of the departure had arrived. The route consisted of a stop off in Copenhagen then onto Vagar.
Check-in and baggage drop-off at the airport closes half an hour before a flight. If you have luggage, you can choose 2 options:
In the first case, the airport staff will help you arrange everything. Although if you decide to use the second option, you need to scan the boarding pass and select passengers with luggage, after which the machine prints a sticker that must be attached to the suitcase. After that, just a few meters away is the baggage drop-off point. If your baggage weighs more than 20 kg, it’s classified as heavy so you will need to attach a special tag to it, which you will find right next to the scanner.
Wave goodbye to your luggage and head to the gate for boarding. If you are departing from Copenhagen Airport, I would highly recommend you to arrive early, as there are a lot of shops and various cafes inside.
The gate was in a small remote wing of the terminal. Most of all, I was worried about company loyalty to hand luggage. The hand luggage restrictions are 55x40x25 cm and 8kg weight plus a laptop bag.
As I noticed, there were no questions from the airport staff regarding the size and quantity of hand luggage and boarding was speedy.
I flew on the brand new AIRBUS A320NEO, and my impressions were only the most positive, not only from the plane but also from what was happening inside.
I was almost the last person to board the plane, and this did not hinder me from putting my suitcase on the luggage rack. The shelves were not full, even despite the fact I was flying to a cold country, and people would need a lot of outerwear.
I think it’s not worth saying however that the seats were in excellent condition as the plane is still new. You are able to change the position of the chair and headrest.
I was surprised by the mobile device holder, as well as USB charging for each seat.
Atlantic Airways provides an app for passengers. The main functionality is
How to get the app? Connect to WIFI AtlanticAirFi and open airfi.aero in a browser.
Atlantic Review Magazine is published 4 times a year and has been available to airline users since 1990. On the airline’s website, you can find all the old publications since 2010. The journal tells about the sights, entertainment, and events on the islands, as well as historical information.
Oh, what a delicious sandwich, you can create songs about it ;)
A selection of free drinks provided on board: sweet soda, juices, and coffee or tea.
I especially recommend you to try tomato juice. I would even say that it is not juice, but a ready-made cocktail with spices, incredibly tasty for spicy lovers.
Food can be ordered in several ways:
You can order sandwiches or rolls as well as desserts and drinks, but if you travel in the morning, breakfast may be your choice too.
A feature of the menu was the opportunity to try craft beer, specially brewed in collaboration with the brewery and the airline.
Föroya Bjór fly WIT me
Atlantic Airways asked Föroya Bjór to brew beer specifically for passengers, and as a result, we got a fly WIT me. This is Belgian Witbier (Bière Blanche), and experts say that the best place to drink beer you can have at an altitude of 10,000 meters. Föroya Bjór is the oldest brewery in the Faroe Islands and was founded in 1888.
Okkara Hop in the Air
Another beer is Indian Pale Ale brewed together with Okkara, which has been brewing beer since 2010 and is very famous for its collaborations with other breweries.
If you are planning a trip to the Faroe Islands, this airline may surprise you.
Read my blog, and you will find a lot of useful information for traveling around Europe.
--

Title: Palaeo, Copenhagen, Denmark
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Healthy. Organic. Paleo restaurant
Inspired by our latest trip to Berlin and how much wifey and I enjoyed the #SexyGood healthy delicious Simply Keto restaurant/cafe in Berlin, Germany, I realised how much I had enjoyed a similar experience last August when we had gone to Copenhagen Denmark.
The entire #SexyGood + links to the 3 visits to Simply Keto can be captured here https://medium.com/@abhijitpradhan/the-launch-of-the-true-life-metric-95a305856195
We had done a short 5 day trip to this amazing city for the following reasons
After paying homage to the Coffee Collective at their roastery outlet in Godthabsvej/Freidricksburg, we came to the famed Torvehallerne, the hip and happening food hall ( there are 2 big halls ).
And while hunting for lunch options, my eyes settled on Palæo which I had read about earlier. Luckily, as one could pick up food from any kiosk and sit together in one place, I didn’t have to worry about wifey, who was frankly not too interested in the place ! ( It took her a trip to Berlin last month to finally nudge her !). She looked at the different food options, but her attention quickly wandered off and she came back with a multi cheese platter as her lunch !
I went to the counter and the person taking orders was friendly and helpful. The place was more a snack/fast food/smoothie kind of place. Apparently there was a “restauranty” style Paleo outlet somewhere else in the city, but she told me the food was essentially the same.
I ordered a salad which was heavy on keto bread, avocado, nuts, berries, etc.
She suggested I go for the Sweet Potato chips. I did. And my main course was a “grass fed” Hot dog with the sausage wrapped in an egg omelette.
I was in seventh heaven as one did not get such treats back home-especially the grass fed hot dog !
The other thing that struck me after reaching Copenhagen was the sheer quality of their produce. Especially the vegetables. I told wifey that I could happily give up meat for ever, if I get a constant supply of such awesome vegetables. This theme continued throughout the trip and even in the Michelin starred restaurants that we ate in and loved, the vegetables were like from another planet !! #Swoon
Torvehallerne became a very convenient lunch spot for us. It was next to the hub station, Norreport, so it was connected to all places in the city ( Metro, train, bus) and dinners were strategically chosen and booked by wifey to feed her chef soul, so basically I got a license to have most of my lunches at Palæo ! Yay ! Think I did at least 3 :)
My favourite dish was discovered when I ordered their burger. The same friendly order taker told me the bread used for the burger was not as heavy as their regular bread as it used more seeds than nuts. Cool !
I loved it. The meat was obviously grass fed beef and from the first bite I was transported to my school days where my dream meal was in one of the fast food burger joints ( Hardees, Dairy Queen etc.) and my favourite dish used to the burger ( specifically the Mushroom & Swiss burger in Hardees).
I ensured that I had the burger again in my next and last visit here !
This experience gave me hope that Sexy and Good can co-exist and my recent trip to Berlin and Simply Keto has only reinforced that hope !! Also, it was heartening to know that Michelin star chef Thomas Rode Andersen was behind the design of the menu ! #SexyGood in action !https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/mar/02/fast-food-restaurant-caveman-diet-copenhagen
I had turned “Paleo” way back in 2012 and in fact tried to use that approach while running marathons but it didn’t work as after 30 k of running, the system would just revolt and scream for quick carbs. Energy gels, potatoes. I was eating more and more unhealthy stuff just to fuel my runs !
It was only in 2016 where I discovered “Keto” which actually gives me hope of plugging that energy crash issue that I always faced on the longer runs.
Paleo can be seen as High Protein ( which I realised was not actually good for me) + Low Carb + Low Fat whereas Keto is High Fat + Moderate Protein ( a crucial tweak) and Low Carb
When ( and if ) your body adapts to the High fat and low carb component of Keto, it slowly starts prefering to burn fat as a fuel ( which is far cleaner) rather than the extremely dirty and volatile carbs as source of fuel. I know now that if I had managed this during my marathoning days, it would have made a world of difference ! I don’t do long runs anymore as it took me a very long time to get over a knee injury and I realised that my body thrives on high intense short bursts of activity rather than the prolonged abuse that I was subjecting it to + after the recent Paris + Berlin trip, I re-connected with “walking” as it probably activates health in my system better than any other activity ! Wow.
The above is a short recap of how I arrived at #SexyGood in terms of diet, nutrition and exercise.

Title: Three must-visit spaces for Art & Design in Copenhagen.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When this Airbnb host in London decided to be an Airbnb guest in design-conscious Copenhagen, he found much to be inspired by in the galleries and museums. If you’re also looking for design/art inspiration, here are three spots you should include when visiting Copenhagen. (Although just being in the city itself seems to activate latent design genes…)
The SMK houses 700 years’ worth of Danish and Nordic art and sculpture with a clear demarcation between the original architecture built in 1896 and the stunning, light-filled modernist section built 100 years later. If you like a chronological context, you can work your way from the front and understand the big themes through the centuries with clever diversions into more obscure and ‘problematic’ branches every so often.
A short train trip north of Copenhagen takes you to another repository of modern art in a stunning waterside setting, housed in an architectural marvel.
Louisiana (named after the original owners three wives, all named Louise) is a day trip in itself. The permanent collection boasts works by Picasso, Klein, Arp, Moore, Warhol, Hockney, Giacometti and oodles more. The current exhibitions included a immersive retrospective of Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama, Lucien Freud and ‘Africa’, a hugely thoughtful and surprising treatise on architecture, art and culture from the continent today.
If Copenhagen can’t have a stunning museum of design, what hope is there for anywhere else? The museum has the lofty twin ambitions to both serve ‘as a source of inspiration for people active in industry’ while making ‘contemporary consumers both critically aware and discerning’.
This translates of course into a whole lot of #chairporn…
So, despite ostensibly taking a break from London, Airbnb and design, I find myself filled with a better understanding of how Danish design works. Now to bring some of that all important hygge to Kith & Kine.
Kith & Kine is a stylish two-bed property close to all the hip/tech action in Shoreditch, London. Come and stay and see how far we’ve got recreating some Danish hygge…
--
--
Two rooms in London via @Airbnb. Ridiculously close to the tech action. Has vinyl. Some bovine branding (but it all makes sense). Chief cowboy = @endaguinan
