Title: Copenhagen trip: 5–12Aug
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Just a day after landing back in UK, I was going off to Copenhagen for the family trip! Mom was flying off in the morning due to her flight being booked way before mine, and it being Norwegian airlines. Thus, she left by 6.45am and landed in Copenhagen airport at around 1pm. We booked the Zleep Hotel Copenhagen Arena, which was about 2 metro stops away from the airport. She took the train from the airport to ørestad station, then walked a few minutes to the hotel. It was a budget hotel — no kettle, coffee maker etc, just a shower with a 2-in-1 shower gel/shampoo, and a little study desk by the side near the windows. Very sparse and minimalistic, but suitable for just an overnight stay.
My flight was with RyanAir at 1855, so right after I cooked lunch and did my last minute checks, I left for Victoria station, carrying my backpack and duffel bag. I packed dinner already, so I wouldn’t have to buy expensive airport food. I took the Victoria line to Tottenham Hale station, whereby I then took the Stansted Express to Stansted airport. It was a pretty long journey — 1.5hrs in total, but quite smooth. It was crowded, as expected, since it’s the summer holidays and people are just taking this opportunity to travel again. I reached the airport around 3.45pm, and started queuing for check-in. It was crazy crowded and the queue moved so slowly, since there were tons of people and families travelling. After an hour’s worth of queuing and holding my pee, I finally reached the counter to check in and print my boarding pass. Heng I could sneak in my duffel bag! :P I then proceeded to the security departure area, which again was crowded but managed to get through it in good time. I was done by 1705, so I headed to Joe & The Juice to grab a table and eat my dinner. After that, I waited at the sitting area to just while away my time till it was time for the gate to be announced.
I waited… and waited… and waited until 1830, and I got really worried then — the gate hasn’t been announced yet and it was almost flight time. I went to the information counter, and the girl informed us that the flight had been delayed to 2130! Holy shit, that was another 2 hours wait in that goddamned airport! I felt awful — I was still jetlagged and really tired by then, and was getting a little hungry too. Plus, it was so inconvenient to drink water cause I’d have to lug all my stuff with me every time I went to the toilet, so I tried not to drink too much but was really thirsty. I read my ebook, then watched 2 episodes of “The Office” to try and kill time while saving my phone batteries. Finally, they announced the gate at 2030, and I walked to gate 42. It was a full flight, and lots of people were also tired like me. I queued in the non-priority lane, and finally boarded at the front of the plane since my seat was 12C. We had to wait in the drizzling rain whilst they slowly got us from the airport building, along the tarmac and up into the plane. God, I was so tired. We only departed at around 10pm, and landed at 11.30pm. I slept for the whole flight, but was still tired anyway. I was supposed to make my way to the Zleep hotel myself like Mom did, but since my flight got delayed and it was midnight by the time I’d make it through immigration customs, Mom kindly waited for me at the airport. Good thing too — the metro stopped at midnight, and the trains would only come every hourly. Hence, after walking from T2 to the customs, we took a cab to the hotel. It was really expensive to take a cab — 200DKK which was around 40SGD. Jesus christ. Stuff here is crazy expensive. Anyway, once I got to the room 529, I dumped my stuff, took a shower and started charging my phones. Slept and woke up at 6am.
Woke up early, probably due to being slightly jetlagged. Did some stretching and stuff, then headed down with Mom for a cuppa tea and coffee for her. Their Rooibos tea was really nice — so I had a 2–3 cups of it. We then walked around the outside area, passing by Burger King and Fields (supposed to be the largest shopping mall), before Papa arrived at around 8+am where he would meet us at the hotel. After he dumped his stuff in the room, took a shower, we walked to the Orestad station and took the metro to Christianshavn station, then took bus 2A to the Refshaleøen (Refshalevej) area, whereby we would be able to find the Grønt Marked. Refshaleøen is an old industrial area, home to huge shipyards and wastewater treatment plants. The Grønt Marked is a non-profit farmers market organisation in Copenhagen, with small individual farmers selling home-grown, local, fresh and seasonal produce such as kale, tomatoes, berries and potatoes. They even sold honey schnapps! They appear in different parts of Copenhagen depending on which Sunday it is, so since we’re here on the 1st Sunday, it’s located at Refshaleøen, the original location of the market’s beginnings. There were a few other visitors as well, and lots of them were queueing up to buy food from Lille Bakery, which was located at the end of the market. Whilst Mom and Papa bought their breakfast pastries — mushroom roll, jam cookie, berliner (some kind of sugared donut), and black coffee — I went to buy my tomatoes and blackberries. We left by 10.30am to catch the 2A bus back to Christianhavn, and walked around the area. We strolled along the canal, seeing lots of yachts and boathouses, as well as stopping by the Bolia showroom. Bolia’s stuff is really nice — typical minimalistic yet beautiful Scandinavian style furniture and decor, lots of beige and earthy tones, wool and ceramic materials used. We walked until around 11.30pm, then slowly turned back to make our way back to the hotel to pick up our luggage and head for lunch at Ciao Pasta, which was located near our apartment. We decided to go for lunch first, since we could only check into the apartment at 1pm. However, by the time we took the train and walked to the apartment, it was already 1pm. It was located at Gasværksvej 11, Ground floor, København 1656. Kinda old looking and when we arrived the cleaning lady was still there. There were 3 separate bedrooms, 1 big open concept kitchen, a living room and 1 toilet to share. There were basic amenities like cooking utensils, cups and bowls, and a little utility closet off to the side of the kitchen (vacuum, more soap, random stuff all dumped there). In the toilet, it was really spartan looking — just 1 toilet right beside the sink, opposite was a Miel washing machine and dryer on top, the tiled shower on the right. We just dumped our stuff, then tried to figure out how to get the door key, cause I realised that we needed one to be able to get back in. We spent a good 10–15mins trying and calling for help, but no answer. Our saviour came in the form of an upstairs neighbour who heard our troubles, and solved the issue by figuring out that the key to the door was in the lockbox, and that the lockbox code wasn’t to unlock the door, which we had thought to be so. Thus, we were saved and could finally go for lunch. Well, more of Mom and I going and then Mom dabaoing back lunch, since Kai had landed and Papa wanted to meet him to make sure he got to the apartment cause Kai is useless that way. Mom got the meat lovers pasta for them and herself the veggie loves, whilst I had my special order of the ciao lovers pasta with garlic, chili and added vegetables. The pasta was tortellini with some truffle filling, but I mostly ate the filling and veg cause the pasta was too much. Papa of course was pissed off with the whole apartment, making the usual black face and cursing his head off. Mom of course, felt awful and tried to convince him to go to ah hotel instead, but alas, no. How unfortunate.
Anyway, after I finished lunch, I headed to the nearby supermarket, Superbrugsen, to get some body soap (apartment only had shampoo and bar soap), salad, yoghurt (they only had skyr but same same), and some strawberries. Made it back only by 3+pm, and boy did everyone’s faces look like shit. It was drizzling by then, so the cloudy weather didn’t make anything better. I ate some yoghurt and berries, then after resting a bit, decided to go out and explore some more. Might as well see as much as I could instead of wasting the time away cooped up in the apartment with angry men. I walked towards the Palads Cinema, which was really pink and blocky. The Palads Cinema first opened its doors to the public more than 100 years ago in 1912. At the time, it was located in the former central railway station which had ceased operation a year prior. The cinema was extensively renovated in 1955 and was further updated in the 1970s. In 1989 the cinema received its signature coat of paint which itself attracts thousands of visitors every year. I then walked past the Axel Towers, which was designed by Danish architect Lene Tranberg and opened in 2017. Very modern looking, consisting of five interconnected towers, the tallest of which reaches a height of 61 meters. Whilst walking along the streets, I noticed how clean they were, and also how few rubbish bins were out — it was like Japan where they expected you to keep your trash with you and not litter. There were also lots of Burger King’s and 7-Eleven — their 7-Eleven was very fancy, almost like an M&S in the train stations back in UK kind of fancy. I walked past a Warhammer store and an Animerch store too, which sold little anime trinkets like keychains and soft toys. There was a Hard Rock Cafe too, which was my toilet stop. After the Palads cinema, I passed by the Wallmans Cirkusbygingen, which hosted cabaret acts and dancing. I then proceeded onwards to the City Hall Square, aka Radhuspladsen, and saw the Copenhagen City Hall. Just a very grand looking building, first opened in 1905. t was designed by Danish architect Martin Nyrop who drew inspiration from Siena City Hall and put elements of the Italian style in a Danish context. I passed by the Tivoli Gardens, but didn’t go in since family wanted to go there tomorrow or after. As I walked along the streets of Indre By, there was a Mentos promotion going on, with sales people just giving out free mini bottles of Mentol chewing gum. After a few minutes walk — all of these destinations were within 10–15minutes walking distance of each other — I ended up at Nytorv and Gammeltorv, 2 adjoining squares in the city. Gammeltorv is the oldest square in Copenhagen, dating back to the city’s foundation in the 12th century. Its most distinguishable feature is the Caritas Fountain, the oldest fountain in Copenhagen. Nytorv was created by King Christian IV and is located just to the other side of the former city hall. This old city hall, however, burned down in 1795 and was rebuilt in a different location on Nytorv. I then walked to the Church of Our Lady (Vor Frue Kirke), the city’s most important church and also known as Copenhagen Cathedral. The original church was built soon after the city’s foundation in the 12th century, but fell victim to a devastating fire in the early 14th century. The building has Neo-Classical architecture, and the inside was a large vaulted domed ceiling with lots of columnades at its sides. It was quiet and peaceful, and the white colours of the inside was soothing to the eye. I left the church and walked towards the Round Tower (Rundetaarn). It was this really tall brick tower that was erected in the 17th century under Christian IV, and functions as an astronomical observatory. You could pay to go inside the tower and see stuff, but seeing how boring the brochure looked, plus with a time limit (I had a dinner booking at 1730, and it was already 1630), I decided to make a slow journey back in the drizzle. Yup, still drizzling and cloudy and windy. I passed by Skindergrade Gyde along the way back, which was just a bunch of colourful old looking houses. I made a short stop to see the nearby supermarket Irma, which was much closer to our apartment and sold the skyr yogurt which I’m eating here, Thise. I reached back by around 1715, dropped off my backpack and charged my phone, then headed out again with mom for my dinner booking at Maple Casual Dining. I had pre-ordered the chicken thighs with asparagus instead of the potatoes, and the chef made an alternative sauce of olive oil, herbs and sliced chili. Really tasty, though kind of oily. Oh well. I ordered an extra bowl of veg (broccolini, green beans and asparagus), and it was really good. Mom accompanied me by ordering their mixed berries Nordic sorbet, but the sorbet looked more like ice cream, and her dessert came with these cocoa looking cereal. Of course, to appease Mom, I went back and ate more yoghurt. They were heading out for dinner with Kit and Emily at some other Restaurant Puk at 1930, so left by 1900. I had my shower and then tea afterwards, and just chilled and wind down. Ah, so peaceful without the angry men. I wish they’d just go and stay at a hotel rather than try to live with this and make everyone unhappy. I’m just really sad Mom has to deal with all their unhappiness and cursing, despite planning everything as best she could and scrambling after the funeral happenings. Also, such a waste that she couldn’t come on my little exploration today to see the sights despite the cloudy weather, cause the next few days are forecast to be rainy as well.
After their dinner, Kit and Emily are coming to the apartment to eat durian, so there goes the post-dinner peace and quiet, plus having to smell durian the whole night probably. Also, with only a single toilet to share, one can only pray that Papa doesn’t clog the toilet and that the windows can air it out enough.
Woke up at 5am, then tried to sleep more till 5.15am but couldn’t so just got up and made tea. It was sort of light by then, and there were some people on the street. Alas, it was still drizzling a little bit, so I’m not sure what the plan is for today. Did my usual wake up warm-ups, and hydrated. The Jing green tea and black tea Mom gave me was kinda light, not very strong flavour — oh well. Anyway, Mom got up at around 6am, then after washing up, we re-explored the utilities room and found: body wash, more body wash, and a ton of bin bags. So we actually didn’t have to buy body soap yesterday… dang it. So we decided to use the body soap provided as hand soap instead in the toilet, and the little body wash bottles as hand soap in the kitchen. Yesterday night Kit and Emily didn’t come over for durian as they said they were too full from dinner, and would come over tonight instead. So while waiting for stuff to open, I decided to just read and then drink more water and tea before heading out.
Mom and I left around 7.30am to head out for our morning journey, since Kai and Papa were not up for it and still sleeping, respectively. We walked to the København H metro station, then took the M4 train to Marmorkirken stop. I bought my Copenhagen City card which allowed us to ride all the public transport and access all the different attractions/museums in the city for different duration of times — 48hrs, 96hrs, 120hrs etc. So after getting off at our stop, we actually realised that right outside the station was Frederik’s Church, aka the Marble Church. It’s best known for its outstanding rococo interiors and its striking dome which dominates the cityscape. It was drizzling and really windy, but still manageable. We walked past Khmer Cuisine, a SPAR grocery store, and even a Michelin/Chaine restaurant Bistro Boheme. On our way to the Kastellet, we walked past the Churchill park, then crossed the Kastellet Bridge to enter the area proper. Also known as the Citadel, it is a star-shaped fortress that was once a crucial part of the city’s defense system. Although it is still under the command of the Danish Armed Forces today, it is also a popular recreational space for the locals — there were still people jogging and walking their dogs, even in the grey weather! The barracks were a nice brick red colour. After that, we made our way to the Little Mermaid statue, and on the way saw the Søfartsmonumentet, which is a huge statue dedicated to civilian Danish sailors who have lost their lives during WWI. The Little Mermaid statue was kind of small, being only 1.25m tall and just parked right in the middle of the sea. It was unveiled on 23 August 1913, presented by Danish brewer Carl Jacobsen as a gift to the City of Copenhagen. The sculpture is made of bronze and granite, and inspired by the Hans Christian Andersen’s fairytale of the same name, “Den Lille Havfrue” (The Little Mermaid). Carl Jacobsen fell in love with the character after watching a ballet performance based on the fairytale at the Royal Danish Theatre, so much so that he commissioned the sculptor Edvard Eriksen to create the sculpture of the mermaid. Fun fact: Erikson’s wife, Eline Eriksen, actually posed for the statue! After that, we walked a little further to find the Gefion Fountain, which is a huge fountain donated to the city by the Carlsberg Foundation, depicting the Norse goddess Gefjon driving a wagon pulled by oxen. According to legend, it was Gefjon who plowed the Danish island of Zealand out of Sweden. The Swedish king Gylfe supposedly offered her as much land as she could plow out within a day and a night. In order to accomplish this crazy challenge, Gefjon transformed her sons into oxen, which are seen pulling the plow. Just off to the side is the St. Alban’s Church (English Church), which was currently under restoration works. It was built in the late 19th century in a distinct British Gothic Revival style (aka Victorian style). The church has served the British-Anglican community in Copenhagen ever since and is one of the few churches with services in English today. It’s quite a beautiful structure, just a shame that we couldn’t go inside today. Since we finished seeing the few main sites in the area — and all within an hour! — we decided to head back to the apartment. After taking the train back to the København H metro station, I bought a squash and some fresh tomatoes from the outside grocer. Mom went to the train station to buy some coffee and pastries for breakfast for her and the angry men from Lagkagehuset — 1 espresso, 1 cappuccino, 1 raspberry swirl, 1 chocolate cinnamon swirl, 1 bread thing and 1 almond croissant. We then walked back and got back around 9.30am. After that, it was kind of chill time till they finally decide what to do — mostly the plan is to do indoors stuff as it’s drizzly and gloomy weather. Anyway, there was a lot of mixed up planning for where to go and etc after they finished breakfast, and there was a scramble for me to book another lunch for 6 at 1230pm at Restaurant Havfruen, which I was going for lunch to at today.
Anyway, we ultimately decided to head to the Amalienborg Palace, which is the residence of the Danish royal family since the 18th Century, after the original residence of the royal family — Christianborg Palace — burned down. Parts of the palace are open to the public, while others are reserved exclusively for the royal family. Whether any of them are at home is indicated by the flags hoisted at the palace or the changing of the guards. It was really drizzly and windy when we headed out, and waiting for bus 23 was quite miserable as there was no shelter. We took the bus to the Odd Fellow Palæet stop, then walked a short distance to enter the Palace. We were in time for the changing of the guards too, which was like that in Buckingham Palace. After that, we went to see the inside of one of the buildings available for viewing, and it was quite a short tour — only 2 levels, and just some old furniture and paintings to see. The museum shop was also really small — I got a bunch of postcards and a diorama of the palace, whilst mom got a bunch of fridge magnets. After that, mom and I left first for lunch, which was booked at 1230, but by the time we walked there it was already 1pm. Kai and Papa would settle their own lunch and meet us back at the Frederik’s Church after lunch, where we would go inside to see the interior. On the way to Restaurant Havfruen, we passed by Nyhavn, which was just a row of colourful buildings located along the harbour. We passed by the Royal Danish Playhouse as well, which is this really modern blocky looking building. It’s a mix of brick, stainless steel and glass, with some parts of the building hovering over the water and supported by Venetian-style crooked columns. The restaurant was quite small, and packed. I had already pre-ordered my baked salmon with asparagus, whilst Mom had the fish and chips. The food came relatively fast, and just in time too, cause shortly after we ordered there came a big group of 12 angmohs, American I think from their accent. The food was quite delicious, and while waiting to be served, I ate my blackberries, strawberries and tomatoes. After we finished lunch, I was still a little hungry, and wanted to eat my yoghurt but alas, it was back at the apartment. We strolled back to the church, passing by a little souvenir shop where Mom bought more magnets. We waited for Kai and Papa inside the church, and they finally arrived at 2.35pm. After a short look inside, which wasn’t very impressive unfortunately, we took the metro back to our apartment. Kai and Papa decided to go see the War Museum, so thank god it was only Mom and I. We went back and I got to eat more yoghurt to fill up a little, then we took the bus to Strøget, which was their version of Orchard Road. Not very impressive — just small versions of branded shops like Gucci, LV, COS etc. We also went into their shopping mall, Illum, but also quite chiam lah. We walked on a little further, and saw the Helligaands Kirken on the way to the metro. We then dropped by Lidl for me to buy dinner vegetables — kale, zucchini, red onions and edamame. And we made it back just in time before the guys got back. Mom kindly helped me chop my stuff up and then we just boiled everything in a pot. Ate dinner around 6pm, then waited until they left before showering and having some tea. They had dinner at nearby Ristorante Buono, which I had actually looked up for food but they didn’t reply my email. I planned tomorrow’s activities with Mom before she left for dinner, so she could discuss it with the rest of them during dinnertime. At least by the time they left for dinner, it had stopped raining and seemed ok. They came back around 9pm, and then ate the durian that Papa brought. Emily seemed ok, and it was nice to chat with her again. We discussed tomorrow’s plan, which was thankfully free and easy, just to meet at 5.30pm at Noma. Then, lo and behold, the neighbours smelled the durian smell and reported it to the fire station as a suspected gas leak. So there came 2 firetrucks, and the firemen came into our flat to investigate a gas leak. My god. REAL FIREMEN! IN THEIR SUITS AND EVERYTHING WITH THE TRUCKS!
Holy jesus. They came into and out of the apartment several times, carrying their carbon monoxide detector and trying to find the source of the “leak”. Oh boy, was Kai so pissed off. Mom opened the windows to try and air the flat out so the scent wouldn’t linger, and bagged up the trash for disposal tomorrow. I’m not sure what time they left by, cause I went to sleep first.
Woke up at 5.40am, and surprisingly Papa was awake too — or maybe not so surprising, since he has jet lag too, and worse than us. the day is gloomy but dry, which is at least 1 blessing there. Had my usual tea, and just read and started to revise a little about my case discussion for the PEG interview with Papa. Sian — the more I revise, and when discussing with him, the more stress and worried I get. And this is in addition to the OSCE retake I have to also prepare for once I get back from Copenhagen. Stress, stress stress. Waiting for Mom to wake up before I can finally move out and start walking to Nyboder, which is a block of red, orange and yellow coloured buildings, and people still live there too! They once served as the homes of Danish sailors and their families, and were barracks under the command of the Danish Navy. Eventually, 8am came around and Mom still wasn’t awake, so I decided to head off first and let her sleep in. I changed and walked to Nyboder, taking a straight route through Strøget, seeing the different stores and eateries along the way. It wasn’t rainy but crazy gusty today, and the wind was so strong that you had moments of just standing still trying to keep upright. Along the way, I saw a few wall murals that were quite nice, but incomparable to those in Argentina. I saw the houses in Nyboder, and I guess they were quite pretty, but nothing very impressive. Walked till the end of the block, whereby I saw the statue of Christian IV. I also saw a Jewish church nearby. I then began walking towards the Botanical Gardens, and passed by the SMK Museum at the same time. The gloomy clouds were beginning to clear a little, such that there was some sunshine coming through — makes all the difference man. The garden was ok — I was never really into all the plants and stuff, and it was too early for the Palm house to be open (most things open at 10am here). Mom finally woke up by 9am, so she called and we agreed to meet at the gardens. After seeing some of the sights, we walked to the nearby Museum of Natural History, which was part of the University of Copenhagen, where they were showcasing two special exhibitions: Monkeys — A Primate Story and the Wildlife Photographer of The Year. They also had a mineral exhibition going on, but we skipped that cause it was just looking at rocks and stones. The photography exhibition had a few different categories to look at, and the showcase was for the year’s 100 best images. They were really beautiful and so HD to look at. It was quite a short exhibit, so we finished it pretty fast. We then went to the museum shop, where I got this hand-sewn lion plushie thing, whilst Mom got some mineral stones. Before heading to the Rosenberg castle, we stopped by at a nearby coffee shop, Espresso House, so that Mom could get herself some breakfast. She ordered a cappucino, and had a cinnamon roll and a cinnamon-cardamom bun to go. After that, we went to the Rosenberg Castle, built in the early 1600s and one of Christian IV’s architectural projects. The castle contains Denmark’s crown jewels, and outside was the King’s Garden (Kongens Have), which has been open to the public since 1770. We toured the whole castle, seeing the many paintings and furniture they had — they even had a fancy toilet that was all tiles! Lots of gold stuff, ivory dioramas and handicrafts, plus fancy weaponry like muskets that were inlaid with mother-of-pearl engravings and decorations. The basement levels housed the crown and the more precious items, but beyond that, that was it. So far, all the palaces are pretty ok, not as impressive as I’d thought they’d be. After that, we headed back to the apartment for lunchtime, or at least for my lunch. I stopped by the Coop 365 discount supermarket and bought 2 more boxes of strawberries (they were really sweet!), and a Skyr yoghurt cause I was running out. Cooked the same meal as last night’s dinner — onions, zucchini, squash, tomatoes, kale. Mom had 1/3 of her bun for lunch, as she wanted to save her stomach for tonight’s Noma dinner. Basically everyone but me was saving their stomach for Noma. We finished lunch around 2pm, then left around 30mins later to go to Nyhavn to walk a bit due to the good weather, which would eventually lead us to Kongens Nytorv.
We took the bus to Nyhavn, and it passed by the Royal Library (Det Kongelige Bibliotek), which is the national library and one of the largest libraries in the world. We also passed by BLOX, which is this really modern building that was recently built in 2018 and houses the Danish Architecture Center. Lots of glass and concrete, steel beams. Walking towards Kongens Nytorv, which is the largest square in Copenhagen, which was laid out in the 17th century by King Christian V. After its completion, several notable buildings were erected around the square. To the south lies the Royal Danish Theatre from 1874; to the east Charlottenborg Palace; to the west Hotel D’Angleterre and Magasin du Nord department store; and to the north Thott Palace. In the centre of the square is an equestrian statue of the king himself. After that, we walked towards Agnete and the Merman, which is a collection of bronze statues submerged in one of the city’s numerous canals. They depict a merman and his seven sons, urging his daughter Agnete to return to them. This was done by Danish sculptor Suste Bonnen, who was inspired by a traditional Danish folk story “Agnete og Havmanden”. When we went, it was barely visible in the waters, so I felt kind of cheated… Along the way, we passed by the Charlottenborg Palace, which was originally constructed in the 17th century as a city palace for the half-brother of King Christian V. Since 1754, it has served as the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts, and also houses the art gallery Kunsthal Charlottenborg. The building boasts a Dutch Baroque style with Italian influences.
Our last stop before heading to Freetown Christiana was Holmens Bro — a bridge which is one of the 9 bridges connecting the island of Slotsholmen with the rest of Copenhagen. Nearby lies the Holmens Kirke (Church of Holmen), first built as an anchor forge in the 16th century but was converted into a church by King Christian IV in the early 17th century. We walked to Freetown Christiana, which is an autonomous district of Copenhagen that openly sells weed and cannabis. In 1971, a group of hippies broke down the barricades and began squatting there. Nowadays, approximately 900 people live in the area, comprising a community that has its own rules and regulations completely independent of the Danish government. They also have restaurants and cafes there, like the Sunshine bakery and Cafe Loppen. We walked around taking pictures of the colourful murals, but made sure to respect the online rule of not taking pictures of the drug dealers or anyone. When we were there, the scnet of weed as so strong — choking, almost. There was also a police raid happening at the same time, so we left to avoid any trouble. I wasn’t afraid per se, since it was still daylight and there were other tourists and families around, but definitely wary of the environment since it was drugs and weed all around. Nice murals, but Argentina’s are way more colourful and expressive. We backtracked to the entrance, then went to the nearby hotel for a toilet break before heading to Noma for dinner at 5pm. We actually passed by Kit and Emily on the way to the hotel, and they had just finished their canal tour and were going to see the Freetown now. We took the bus 2A to Margretheholm (Refshalevej) stop, and walked a little bit to reach Noma, which was recognisable by the bunch of greenhouses. There were other guests already there too, waiting for their dinner to begin. Papa and Kai had been there since around 4.30pm, and were just waiting for the rest of us to arrive. It was really windy out still, but at least sunny-ish. There was a greenhouse where they grew all their herbs and flowers, which would be harvested and used in tonight’s Vegetable Season dinner. After we all arrived, they brought us to our table and began the dinner — 12–13 dishes with 2 desserts, accompanied by a mix of non-alcoholic juices and tea (you could choose the alcoholic option too). It was beautiful and simple, and the tastes of the food prepared was exceptional. Small portions but very flavourful, lots of that tangy and sourish element incorporated into the dishes. They used a lot of fresh produce, such as oyster mushrooms, flowers, zucchini flowers. Each dish had a drink paired with it for either 1–2 courses. Dessert was a special “onigiri” — ice cream shaped into the triangular shape wrapped in a blueberry leather, and a dish of berries with this delicious almond-tasting sauce. Also, a piece of chocolate with a bunch of flowers on it. Yes, the first time in the past few years that I’ve decided to let myself eat dessert. Who cares about it tonight — Papa paid a hefty 700SGD for this, so I’m not gonna waste it. Plus, it’s a sign from Gonggong that the whole family was supposed to come for this dinner, so I will not let him down. I really enjoyed the dinner, and I think everyone else was impressed too. However, Kai and Kit were obviously still hungry, with Kai searching for dinner options to eat afterwards. But by the time we ended, it was already 9.30pm, so a lot of places have closed for the night except some burger places which Kai was too lazy to go and dabao from. After we finished dinner, we had some tea and then got the opportunity to tour the kitchen area. We got to see their fermenting area, which was like a science lab with some chim looking tools, and their huge buckets of kombucha and fermented items, like lupin and oyster mushroom fermented solutions. They cleaned up and closed shop by 9pm, with some of the staff sitting at the staff canteen polishing the silverware and tidying things up. During dinner, we discussed tomorrow’s plan, and eventually settled on leaving it free and easy again — Kit, Emily and Kai were planning to go to the aquarium in the morning, whilst Mom and I planned on seeing the Christianborg Palace in the morning, then afternoon going to see the SMK Art musem and Torvehallerne. We all took a cab back, as it was already dark out and got back to the apartment by 10pm. Kai didn’t want to go out to buy food, so decided to be hungry and sleep. Poor Kai, he should’ve eaten some lunch :/
Happy National Day! Can’t believe we’re celebrating it, or not really, here in Copenhagen with its gloomy skies and rainy days. Woke up at 5.30am as usual, but just a little tired, not too much. Did my usual warm up activities and tea, then did some Googling to see what could be open. Ultimately, I saw that the zoo was open at 9am, and was just a 30min walk from our apartment. So my plan was to go the nearby park at 8am, walk and chill until 9am, then see the zoo stuff till whatever time. I didn’t intend to eat lunch today, but an early dinner, so will just go straight from the zoo to the Glypotek museum, since Kit wanted to go there in the morning and meet Mom. Then, I probably will head to the Christianborg Palace, followed by the Medicine Museum and Design museum, seeing how the timing goes. We left for the Søndermarken shortly after 7.45am, taking a slow stroll in the drizzle and strong winds. The Søndermarken is one of Denmark’s oldest palace gardens, and is part of the gardens surrounding Frederiksberg Palace. At the end of the 18th century, Søndermarken was redesigned as a romantic landscape garden with meandering paths, allowing access to the Norwegian House, The Cisterns and the Chinese Pavilion. You could even get a view of the elephants in the Copenhagen Zoo! We walked along the paths and saw the Frederiksberg Palace, a yellow stately building, then continued onwards to the Chinese Pavilion. It was just a small little pavilion, quite cute. Mom realised her shoe was coming apart due to the rain, so we decided to go to a nearby cafe to warm up and rest a little. We walked out of the park and to a nearby cafe, Thiemers Kaffebar — very aesthetic and bookish, nice and small. Mom ordered a cappucino and ate a bit of her muffin thing from yesterday. We sat there for a while, then when it was around 8.50am, we left to take a slow walk to the Copenhagen zoo. It was pretty empty since we were the first few stragglers in at the moment of opening, and so we had free rein of the place. We decided to just make a loop around the area, and we managed to see the lions, tigers, elephants, penguins, seals etc. Most of the animals were hiding in shelter due to the crappy weather — poor guys, having to deal with this kind of climate. I saw a claw machine — 25DKK for a chance to win! The soft toys inside were monkey and tiger plushies, whereas the plushies in the out-of-order machine at the Elephant House had red pandas and elephants. Well, losers can’t be choosers! We didn’t have any coins with us, so I went to change a 100DKK into 20DKK coins to play. Upon my first try, I managed to get the claw to grab not only one, but two monkey plushies! :D First time I’ve ever been so lucky on the claw machine in my life! After that, we just finished up at the museum shop, and then left for the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek.
Mom had arranged for us to meet Kit and Emily there, but apparently Emily as busy working in the morning so they missed it completely. We took bus 7A from the Zoologisk Have stop to Hovedbanegården, Tivoli stop, then walked a little to reach the museum. The Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek is one of the most famous art museums in Copenhagen, primarily exhibiting sculpture from Ancient Rome, Greece and Egypt, in addition to showcasing a wide collection of Danish and French art. The founder is Carl Jacobsen. The permanent exhibitions were:
Then there were the special exhibits:
It was quite small for the special exhibits, and the other ones were just huge rooms full of sculptures and paintings, that my mind went numb after a few rooms. Nope, can’t do art for too long. I managed to finish it within 2 hours, and we actually met up with Kai and Papa there. The museum shop wasn’t very impressive too, so quite a letdown for Mom especially. Since I wasn’t having lunch with them, and wanted to go back for tea instead, I left first at around 12.05pm to take the bus back to our apartment. They would be having lunch at Restaurant Havfruen at Nyhavn, then I’m not sure what their afternoon plans are. For myself, I took the bus in the wrong direction for 1 stop, then swapped direction and got back by 1230pm. Had some warm tea and water, and updated the blog and read my emails.
After resting a little, I headed out to the Christianborg Palace. Unfortunately, it was still drizzling and cold, but whatever. Took the bus there and walked a little to enter the castle. Being blur, I queued up to go up and see the Tower, which would provide a view over Slotsholmen. I took the lift up to the top, but the view was ok, nothing special or wow. I guess the weather also kind of destroyed the opportunity to take a nice city view. After that, I found the right entrance to enter the palace, and toured the Royal Reception Rooms (Great Hall, Queen’s tapestries). The tapestries were really beautiful and vibrant, and it is said that these tapestries were made to mark the occasion of Her Majesty Queen Margrethe II’s 50th birthday in 1990, by ordering a gift of 11 tapestries. Bjørn Nørgaard painted the full-size sketches upon which the tapestries were woven, and they depict 1000 years of Danish history. I considered going to the ruins, but saw that it was a long queue, and it was almost 3pm. The Medicine museum closed at 4pm, so I took the M3/M4 to the Marmorkirken station and walked to the museum. It was quite small, and I finished it within 10 mins — nothing very good to see, all old stuff and quite terrible honestly. Along the way I passed by a 19th Century Russian Orthodox church, Skt Aleksander Nevskij Kirke, and a random small Roman church. A short walk away was the Design museum, and the queue was super long so I decided to just go to the gift shop and buy Mom a magnet. Mom they all met for lunch and had a seafood platter to share, but Kit and Emily left first cause they had a booking at the Rosenberg Castle. Mom, Papa and Kai then had dessert at the nearby Vaffelbageren Nyhavn, where they had churros with Bailey’s ice cream and some softserve too. They then walked along the Nyhavn canal and also to Strøget, before taking the bus back. I dropped by the 365 discount store near the Marmorkirken station, getting zucchini and pumpkin and skyr before heading back. So coincidentally, they got back just a few minutes before I did!
The moment I got back, I just dropped off my stuff and started prepping with Mom for dinner, eating my yoghurt and strawberries whilst waiting. I’m quite proud of myself for accomplishing so many destinations today, alone too! Of course, I wish Mom could’ve been there with me to see the sights, but oh well. Had dinner and finished by 1730, while everyone else went to nap before dinner. Tonight, they’re going to that Michelin place Bistro Boheme for a 1915 dinner. Hopefully it’s nice. Meanwhile, I will chill and slowly warm up at the apartment — I think I’ve done enough outdoor walking for today.
Man, I was really tired yesterday night — must be from all that walking, plus falling on my left knee yesterday at the zoo. I lay in bed just as they got home from dinner — Mom said the portions were good size, but food was so-so. Oh well. Usual wake up routine, and everyone else got up at around 7+am. We were going to the Kronborg castle this morning, to try and beat the hordes of tourists that would be sure to come later in the day. We would be meeting Kit and Emily at the Kobenhavn Hovedb. station and take the RE train to Helsingør station, where we would still have to walk a little bit to get to the castle itself. Today’s weather looks better — not raining, but still cool and windy. Fingers crossed it gets warmer and slightly sunnier as predicted by the weather report. We left by 8.30am to get to the station where we got the 8.42am train to Helsingør. It was around an hour’s journey there, and not much to see along the way. Kai was rather unhappy at the rush, cause he didn’t manage to get his breakfast. When we reached, it was kind of gloomy, and I found a cafe for Kai to get some food in before we went to the castle. The nearby Cafe Karisma was very quaint and nice, very coffeeshop vibes — Papa had an apple pie and hot chocolate with whipped cream, Kai had the spicy chicken sandwich and a cuppacino. We decided to wait for Kit and Emily at the cafe and then together we go to the castle. Whilst they were eating their breakfast, I decided to walk around the old town streets of Helsingør, seeing a few of the sights. It began to drizzle a little whilst I was walking the streets.
The first stop I had was to see St. Olaf’s Church, which was situated on the same spot where the city’s first church was built over 800 years ago. St. Olaf’s Church got its present look back in 1559, and it could therefore celebrate its 450th anniversary in 2009. The oldest parts of the church wall, however, are from the 13th century. The first church was established here on what was once the beach of the castle at the time, Drekrog, before Kronborg was built over it. The church takes its name from its guardian saint, the Norwegian Viking king and national saint, Olaf the Holy, who managed to both unify and Christianise Norway. When Erik of Pomerania began collecting the Sound Dues, St. Olaf’s Church underwent a transformation. The church had to keep up with Elsinore’s growing importance for the country, and it was therefore expanded several times. Since 1961, St. Olaf’s Church has formally become a cathedral, due to the fact that northern Zealand became an independent diocese. On the east gable of the church one can see a door leading to a burial vault. Above it, there is seen a skull and crossbones, the symbol of death. The French inscription reads: Thus do we all become. Inside the church, the interior is dominated by an 11.5-metre tall altarpiece from 1664. The altarpiece is constructed of 19 reliefs, depicting the life of Jesus Christ. There is also a treasure trove of Renaissance and Baroque art, such as the pulpit, from the year 1567. There is a yellow house, which lies on Sct. Annagade 6, that faces the church with a large mural — this was the childhood home of the composer Diderik Buxtehude (1637–1707). In the years 1660–1668, he was the organist at the Church of St.Mary, and he was known as one of the 17th century’s most important composers, inspiring famous composers such as Johan Sebastian Bach and Georg Friedrich Handel. The paintings on the gable across from Buxthehude’s house in Sct. Annagade depict the era of the Sound Dues. They show the cosmopolitan rich and very vibrant mercantile town, which for over 400 years profited greatly off the many ships that had to stop and pay the Sound dues. Along a small side street was GI Færgestræde, a very aesthetic cobblestone alleyway.
The second church I saw was St. Mary’s Church and the Carmelite Priory. St. Mary’s Church, together with the Carmelite Priory, is one of Northern Europe’s best preserved priories from the Middle Ages. The priory was founded in 1430, shortly after the introduction of the Sound Dues, when Erik of Pomerania invited the Carmelite monks, the so-called Whitefriars, to Elsinore. The church and priory were completed in their present form around the year 1500. After the Reformation, the priory was converted to a hospital in 1541. The priory also housed Elsinore’s grammar school, and in the 1800s it was a retirement home for those deemed in worthy need. Inside the church the floor is covered in numerous, partly worn down gravestones, which originate from the time where it was possible for wealthy citizens to buy a burial site in the church. The church’s prestigious chalk murals were made from 1440–1500. A main attraction is the church organ which was put there in 1662–63 — this was the same organ that Diderik Buxtehude used while he was the church organist. Following the Protestant Reformation, the church was intially desolate, but was later used as a stable for traveller’s horses. It was on the brink of being torn down, but due to the many foreigners in the city, Frederick I gave it to the German and Dutch congregation. From 1576, sermons were performed exclusively in German. In 1851, the German sermons were halted, but the many German inscriptions still bear witness to the long period where it served as a German church.
I also managed to find a few different murals that were painted on the sides of the buildings: Soul of the Walls; the Middle Ages and the Sound Dues; History of the Churches; and the Maritime History. Very beautiful, colourful large murals. There was also a side street, Stengade 64–76, which has a row of beautiful 16th-century stone houses part of the Sound Dues residences. They are merchant houses from a time when Elsinore was flush with the profits of international trade. By 1426, Erik of Pomerania had given the city certain special mercantile privileges, and for a time Elsinore was Denmark’s second largest city. Erik of Pomerania had pushed for the development of the city by ordering its citizens to “build your city, increase its size and improve it with good merchant houses.” To encourage this, the King tempted the residents with tax cuts: If you built your house out of stone, you would not have to pay taxes for 10 years. (Those who built their houses out of wood only had five years without taxation!) The houses were built concurrently with King Frederick lI’s construction of Kronborg. It is obvious that the houses were built with the assistance of the same foreign craftsmen that were building for the King. The buildings in Stengade 72 and 74 are called “Leyel’s Houses.” For a number of years, they were owned by the Leyel family, an aristocratic bloodline of Scottish descent who came to be very influential in the city. For the house in no. 72, the windows are encased in stone, whilst no. 74 has a stepped gable. Across the front of the building there is a band of limestone with Gothic writing, and upon it there is written in Latin: “For I know that my redeemer liveth, and that he shall stand at the latter day upon the earth. And though after my skin worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh shall I see God.” The horizontal bands were made during the Renaissance. In no. 76, it is the house of customs officer David Hansen. The property is one of the oldest pre-served private residences in Elsinore, built in 1579. The front of the building features bands of sandstone, and it is richly decorated. Above the windows, one can see a row of small busts. Two of the busts, made as portraits of a man and a woman, wear outfits from the time of Frederick II.
I then backtracked as it was around 10.30am, and after a quick toilet break, we walked to the Kronborg Castle. It was a short distance away, and thankfully the large tour groups hadn’t come yet. Kronborg Castle (aka Hamlet’s Castle) was the actual site that Shakespeare set Hamlet in — so you could see lots of Hamlet inspired souvenirs, and also staff doing tours in Hamlet outfits. Kronborg Castle has existed at Helsingør (Elsinore) since 1420. It’s been burned to the ground and rebuilt since, but always maintained its vital position at the head of the Øresund Sound. Ships passing into the Baltic Sea paid tolls at Kronborg Castle,and Helsingør was once one of the most important towns in Europe. In 2000, Kronborg Castle became a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It was quite nice, with the usual moat and large imposing walls. After touring the inside of the castle, which just showed some rooms and tapestries, I went to climb the Cannon Tower — 145 curving steps up to the top, and you got a pretty good view of the harbour. Gloomy day though, so the view wasn’t so breathtaking. After that, I explored the Casemates, which were the castle’s underground system of corridors and rooms. It was so dark and cramped, and I had to stoop many times to make my way through the tunnels, and at times having to use my flashlight just to light my way. I can only imagine how shitty and creepy it is at night… Oh boy. After seeing the light at the end of the tunnel, I regrouped with the rest of the family (they stayed for the short tour of the castle), and I went with Mom to see the chapel. Then, because I wanted to go off and see more stuff, knowing how slow the rest of them are, I left first. I went to the see their exhibition on “Monsters — Beastly beings with big emotions”. It was about monsters of the past, such as the basilisk, Kraken, with these monsters recreated from recycled materials by artist Shane Brox. His inspiration for this exhibition was human emotions — how everyone can feel and be a monster in their lives. He wanted to start a conversation about emotions in a fun and exciting way, because making the emotions visual through the monsters provide a creative and interactive way to explore this topic. It was quite a short exhibit, and the monsters were very cute. The souvenir shop sold these monster plushies, but they were unfortunately really expensive. Instead, I got myself this Kronborg castle coin. Before leaving the castle, I went up to see the flag bastion, which also provided a view of the sound. I finished everything by around 12pm, then walked to see the Museet for Sofart, or the Maritime Museum of Denmark, since it was just outside the castle. It was all about the shipping industry and history in early Denmark, and it also had on a special exhibition on the Haenyeo divers, showcasing photos and telling their stories. It was quite short and sweet, and I finished within 30mins. After that, I walked to see the Han statue (Han af elmgreen og dragset), this metallic sculpture of some guy on a rock. Then, I walked a little bit further to see the Dancer’s Fountain (Danserindebrønden af Rudolph Tegner), before heading back to the station to catch the RE train at 1303 back to Kobenhavn Hovedb. station. Mom and Kit they all had a light lunch at Helsingør, before taking the 1418 train back. The moment I got back, I went to the apartment and ate my strawberries and skyr with nuts for lunch. After resting a little and charging my phone, I planned to meet Mom directly at Torvehallerne. Torvehallerne is a food market selling fresh produce and fish, in addition to little stalls selling a variety of foods — smørrebrøds, pastries, empanadas, ice cream and more. I bought a few cherry tomatoes from the Torvehallernes Frugt & Grønt, which was located between the two glass halls — it sold such a wide variety of fruits and vegetables — tomatoes, purple carrots and cabbage, apricots, pumpkins — everything so beautiful and vibrant and FRESH! I wish I could’ve bought one of each to try… ah well. Mom bought the classic Danish treat flødeboller, which is a chocolate-covered cream balls topped with different stuff like pistachio, almonds, marzipan, from the famous stall Summerbird. It was packed with people, and just amazing to see the huge variety of foods available. By then, the gloomy weather had cleared and it was nice and cool, with some sunshine. We visited the nearby Flying Tiger shop, then walked to SMK, the National Gallery of Denmark. The National Gallery of Denmark (Statens Museum for Kunst) features Danish and international art from the past seven centuries. It features art from past and present Danish paintings and sculptures, French art, European art, as well as a special exhibit on Baroque art. Pretty nice, but too much art for my brain to handle. We finished it all within an hour, and then went back to the apartment to cook dinner. Initially, Mom told me she would have dinner with me, but as expected, she didn’t keep her word. She wasn’t willing to buy something back to eat with my cooked dinner, so I just told her to go eat with the guys at the Japanese restaurant they booked, Tokyo Restaurant. Ah well, what’s new there, right? At least she helped to cut and wash up I guess. Whilst the dinner was cooking, I made a quick trip down to Irma to buy another tub of Skyr, just to appease Mom that I was eating more food though I already ate at least 1kg worth of Skyr for lunch. Ah well, let’s hope I don’t get too fat then.
Quite happy with all the sights I managed to see today — basically everything that’s on my list and more, so that’s great. Tomorrow I plan to walk around in the morning until the Round Tower opens at 10am, then head to Tivoli to finally ride the rides and see it at 11am. Head for lunch, then see what else I can fill in the afternoon with.
Woke up at 6am, and surprised I managed to get a decent amount of sleep with the noise that was happening upstairs. Don’t know what they’re doing, but there was a lot of loud thumping noises and music too. Today’s weather looks good, as it is partially sunny and bright, so I think a good amount of walking is in order since its a rare decent weather. I found a few smorgesbrod places, since that’s something I haven’t tried and Mom too, and I think the best options are still at Tolverhavernne. But I also located a Vietnamese spring roll place, so I might go there after the bread, and then to La Galette for the buckwheat galettes and sweet crepes for the rest of them. After Mom woke up and had her coffee, I told her the plan and then got ready to leave. Papa wanted to come with us this morning, and as Kai was still sleeping, we decided to just let him be and inform him via Whatsapp that we were out. I was fine with Papa coming along, but made it clear to him that Mom and I would keep walking on first, and he could take his time to take his pictures. I decided to walk towards Vestre Kirkegård, where there was supposed to be a park. Along the way, there were some pretty nice murals to see — one of the wall murals was 85 years old, as we were kindly informed by this old gentleman. We also entered the Christ Church (Kristkirken), and it was a nice old church. We didn’t exactly reach the park, as it was almost 9am by then, and I had planned to go to the Planetarium before the Round Tower. Emily messaged me, and we decided to meet up at 10.20am at the Round Tower to go up together. So Mom and I backtracked to the Planetarium, which opened at 9.30am and saw the very very short exhibition on the Cosmos (about the Big Bang theory, stars, black holes), seeing a real moon rock and a very artsy exhibit on the Rings of Saturn. The museum shop was small, and they were selling popcorn which smelled so good. After that, we took the M3/M4 to Nørreport station, where we dropped by the Taffelbay bakery for Mom to get some breakfast — she got 3 small things to eat (almond florentine, like a little tart; a Berlinervaffel, looks like a dacquoise with a crunchy nut base and filled with mocha cream; and a Limonetti, a light Italian wreath cake with lemon zest) plus a cappucino. After sitting a while, we made our way to the Round Tower, passing by Normal and some lifestyle shop that looked like a Scandinavian version of Muji (we visited after the Round Tower). We met Emily, Papa and Kai there, and went up the tower together. There were just a few things to see, with the ultimate conclusion at the tower top where you could get a 360 view of the cityscape. There was also an exhibit on Meisen Kimono. The meisen kimono became popular in Japan in the first half of the 20th century. This happened after a cultural and technological exchange between Japan and the West made it possible to manufacture kimonos at lower costs than previously, when the silk kimono was preserved for the upper classes. Now, ordinary Japanese people were able to buy fashionable silk kimonos in bold new designs inspired by European art. Over the past 30 years, Danish artist and textile designer Henriette Fris has built up an impressive private collection of these kimonos. Her interest in kimonos was sparked when she was taught by a Japanese silk painter. Since then, she has collected over 100 unique and hand-sewn kimonos dating back to the heyday of the Meisen kimono between 1910 and 1955. During this period, Western art movements such as Art Nouveau, Art Deco, De Stijl and Cubism had a strong influence on Japanese artists’ kimono designs, and these kimonos later re-inspired Western textile design. The exhibition showcases long and short kimonos from Henriette Fris’ private collection. They sold some Japanese crafts like the cat and tote bags featuring the corgi and Japanese landscapes, but crazy expensive. After finishing the tower, Mom and I went to see Tivoli Amusement Park and the Tivoli gardens, passing through Jorck’s Passage. Along the way, we passed by the Frue Plads Marked, a 3-day craft fair that was occurring from the 10th- 11th Aug. It was full of people milling around the various artisan craft stalls, with most stalls selling ceramic handicrafts like cups, plates, and decorative vases. They were all so beautiful to look at, and the minimalistic designs and muted palettes were just so aesthetically pleasing. I wish I could buy a few of the pieces to bring back, but they were crazy expensive. There were a few stores also selling wool clothing and leather items, but mostly ceramic items. Mom and I decided to get a souvenir from the fair, this chameleon looking thing by a female artist — Mom got a vase and I got the chameleon thing itself. Though it was expensive, I decided it was worth the cost as I “made it up” from not going out for meals, plus I definitely did not intend to come back to Copenhagen again. Nope, just not appealing enough unlike Japan or Italy. By then, the sky had turned really gloomy and grey again, and we decided to drop off our stuff at the apartment first and refill water before heading to Tivoli. When we reached, it was packed like sardines, as by the time we arrived it was 11.30am. We managed to skip the queue with our Copenhagen card, but the card only guaranteed us a free entrance but not free access to the rides, where you had to pay 50–90DKK per ride. Nope. So we just walked around the fairgrounds and looked at the rides, seeing the very pathetic Tivoli aquarium, and generally just being disappointed by the whole thing. I believe it’s been overly hyped up, and that in reality it was just another amusement park, and not even as good as Disney World/Sea Japan. Oh boy, will Papa be disappointed. Anyway, we finished walking around, then took the train to Nørreport station to meet everyone else at Tolverhavernne Food Hall for lunch. We got there around 1310, and found Kai and Emily walking around, whilst Papa went to find a seat. Mom queued up a long time for the Hallernes Smørrebrød, getting the chicken salad (homemade chicken salad, bacon, and chervil), Danish meatball (meatball made with pork and veal, homemade potato salad, and thyme), Fish cake (fish cake made with cod, served with dill mayonnaise and hand-peeled shrimps) and I think the last one was Roast pork (roast pork with crispy crackling, homemade pickled red cabbage, and cucumber salad). Emily bought a hotdog thing to share, which Papa ended up eating the whole thing plus a Smørrebrød; Kai also got a hotdog too. Emily also bought cherries, figs, white and black cranberries to share, but ended up bringing back the cranberries cause it wasn’t popular. I got smørrebrød from Rørt: “leftovers” which was organic up-cycled vegetables from MATR, mushrooms, Jerusalem artichoke mayo, pickled cabbage and fried buckwheat on toasted rye; and their “Green Crush” which was smashed avocado, tomato relish, chili and coriander on toasted rye. After walking to find Papa, I finally settled to eat my first ever smørrebrød and it was DELICIOUS! My god, I loved the umami taste of it all, and just so creamy and tasty wow. Emily also got a green apple gelato since Papa ate her hotdog. Oh, I also got my purple carrot for dinner, and Kai bought chocolates for Heidi. After we finished up, we walked a short distance to La Galette, a French restaurant that is inspired by the Asterix French cartoon character. They served a variety of savoury buckwheat pancakes as well as sweet crepes — I ordered the Asterix (ratatouille, egg and chives), whilst Papa had the egg, bacon and ham one, Emily ordered the Confiture (sweet with black currant jam) and Mom had the Crêpe flambée (with banana and Grand Marnier). Mom got twice the dose of alcohol as the guy’s lighter didn’t work the first time round, so he came back with a fresh cup of alcohol to light up. It was really tasty and light, not heavy at all or overly salty. I really liked it, and am glad I decided to go for it today and not miss out. After we finished, Mom and I headed back to let me eat some yoghurt and strawberries, whilst the rest of them went to the aquarium. Kit unfortunately was feeling feverish this morning, so missed out the whole day’s outing, but thankfully was feeling better by lunchtime so would join for dinner. After yoghurt, Mom and I went to the Christianborg Palace, as Mom wanted to see the tapestries. I went with her to finish my tour of the place, seeing the ruins (just a bunch of rocks) and the kitchens (very boring). I bought Mom a magnet of the palace, and after that we departed back for the apartment. Papa was back before us, and that was cause he was tired and also Kai messed up. Apparently, he went to the wrong aquarium which wasn’t covered by the Copenhagen card, and entry was 120DKK. Papa didn’t want to pay entry, so left first. Oh well. I realised that Kai’s been creating a lot of negative energy this whole trip, making snide remarks about Kit to Emily, or making Kit seem like such a lazy shit who got lucky in life. He doesn’t even consider the fact that it may be embarrassing Kit or even Emily, and that maybe Kit actually is jealous of Kai being able to be a doctor. Jesus Christ. Anyway, got back and cooked dinner, finishing up my Thise skyr and feeling sad when I finished it cause I just wanted to keep eating more… oh well. Mom they all were going to El Meson for dinner, a Spanish tapas place. Hopefully the food is good, and no more food poisoning for tomorrow we’re all flying back. Papa’s flight was at 11am so he would set out first, while Mom, Kai and I would go to the airport later as our flights were around 2pm. I pray that Ryanair doesn’t delay the flights again, if not I’ll be so pissed. Really happy and proud of myself for eating the lunch out today and not caring about the salt/sugar content, but just embracing the delicious foods as is. I guess I knew that I would go back to eating a salt-free diet from tomorrow onwards again, and never intend to come back to Copenhagen, so 1 meal won’t kill me. And maybe it’ll actually help heal me. Oh yes, also am very surprised by how trusting the Danish people are — they just leave their bikes unlocked, supermarkets leave produce outside with no cameras or security guards watching. And their MRT station also uses a tap-in/out card that not everyone has to use, with no one really checking. Gosh.
Ah, last morning here in Copenhagen before heading back to the awful reality of life in the UK and school and OSCE retakes and PEG. Woke up at 6.30am, then did the usual warm up and tea time. Papa was up already cause his flight was at 11+am, so planned to leave the flat by 9.30am. Last night’s dinner was so-so according to Mom — they had meatballs, sausage, Iberico ham, paella etc. They wanted the grilled lambchops but they ran out! Anyway, they got back at midnight, as after dinner they went to Tivoli to see the lights. Mom said that all the rides were closed already, and they actually see Rick Astley performing live! Oh man, what a treat it would’ve been. Anyway, packed all the stuff to let Mom bring back on my behalf, and then I changed and left by 7.30am for Juno Bakery. Apparently, it was a really really famous and good bakery as it was opened by former cook of Noma, Emil Glaser. Their cardamom rolls are the most famous, and so I decided to try and get it for breakfast for Mom, Papa and Kai. The bakery was located at Århusgade, and I decided to talk a nice morning walk along the Peblinge Sø, which is like a river, and along the way saw some murals and this island of birds (Fugleøen, on Google Maps). The walk was nice and peaceful, and today was much warmer than usual despite it being cloudy. Lots of people out running and cycling, and the streets were quiet with few cars. By the time I reached the bakery, it was a really long queue. Suddenly, Mom told me that she wanted us all to leave at the same time as Papa, so I very stressed to get back on time. I queued, and bought 3 cardamom buns, 2 pistachio and 2 almond danish. I then chionged back for the flat, taking the M4 from Nordhavn station back to Kobehavn. Speed-walked back to the flat, and managed to get there by 9.30am for Papa and Mom to have a whole bun for themselves, fresh and hot (well, lukewarm). They really liked it, saying the pastry was soft and delicious. :D
After that, we took the train to the Copenhagen airport, and checked in. No queue for Papa’s business class, but a small queue for my Ryanair flight. Thankfully we reached by 10.30am, so hardly anyone there yet. Got my boarding pass and then proceeded through security. Kai was grumpy as shit, having to suddenly rush at the sudden change of plans and not being able to have a proper slow, sit-down breakfast. Oh well. After passing through security, the duty free shops and other shops inside the airport were pretty nice. I just walked around a little while waiting for Mom and Kai to pass through, and after a while managed to meet up with Kit and Emily. They had lunch at Yo! Sushi, and we all convened there eventually. After resting a while, and unfortunately not finding a 7-Eleven, I had to go to my boarding gate, F105. Sian, everyone else’s gate was C-something but mine had to be the furthest away. I was really tired and had a headache, but just powered through it anyway. No lunch, except for a few cherry tomatoes and nuts. Why can’t airports have shops selling greek yoghurt or skyr? Dang it man. Anyway, I’m just glad that the flight wasn’t delayed this time, though we did depart late by 20mins. Full flight, and I was so tired I dozed off for the majority of the flight. We landed at around 3.10pm, and then I went to the Stansted Express for the 3.43pm train to Tottenham Hale Court. Unfortunately, the train journey was extended, due to some guy trespassing on the tracks so yeah. After a 10min delay, we finally continued on and reached the station at around 4.30pm. I walked to the Victoria station line, and took another 30min journey back. By the time I reached Warwick, it was 5.05pm already, and Mom and Kai had just reached before me. Heidi was there already too — she was cooking them dinner tonight. I ate a few spoonfuls of yoghurt then got cooking, as Mom kindly helped me go sainsbury and the market man to buy veg and fruits. Man, was I so tired and my head was pounding. Whilst cooking, I boiled water to refill my bottles and unpacked at the same time. Only finished cooking by 6pm, and then finished by 6.30pm. Finally took a shower, and just updating the blog now. Man I am so tired…
Oh well, it was a pretty ok family trip, though lots of unhappiness and rough patches the first few days — ok, mostly everyday there’s something wrong. Just like today, Kit didn’t even bother saying or hugging me goodbye unlike he did with Kai and Mom. Guess I should just give up on him too.
--

Title: I Didn’t Have a Danish: Copenhagen (2)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This is a post about a couple of museums that I visited while I was in Copenhagen. As I was more determined nto not make my holiday into a busman’s trip, I somehow managed to find myself in yet another museum…
Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, or the New Carlsberg Museum, was founded by the same founder who launched the beer brand. The founding collection of the museum was the private collections of the Carl Jakobson. I wasn’t aware of how close the museum was from my hotel and had passed it many times while looking for other attractions.
The highlight of my visit was definitely the winter garden. When I was reading the information on tripadivsor, I thought it was another botanical garden. I didn’t realise how wrong I was until I arrived.
What greeted me first was a stream of different sounds: recordings of both natural sounds, such as birds’ chirping and wind, and artificial sounds. I heard something that reminded me the strange music of a theremin or a glass armonica. Sometimes the melody turned into a high pitch, but most of time it was as if the ruffling leaves were murmuring. The winter garden was smaller than I expected, but the magical sound somehow enlarged the place. I was lucky enough to secure a seat at the cafe next to the garden, and enjoyed a light lunch as if I were in the jungle (a very cold one indeed).
Another thing worth mentioned was a literary project for eight selected sculptures. Invited guest writers were asked to write a short passage, giving the marbles voice and perspectives. I was relieved when learning that the text was all translated in English and juxtaposed with Danish. Nevertheless, this was the moment when I wish I had mastered a foreign language so I didn’t need to rely on translation.
The visit was rather short, as a heavy rain in the morning soaked me through and I had to go back to my hotel to give an online talk to the Museum studies students at the Uni. Leicester. It was a fine museum; a typical “private-collection-turned-museum”. I appreciate the attempt of the literary projects, giving the collections new meaning.
2. Medicinsk Museion (Medical Museum), 1 Sep
I was over the moon when I learned that there was another medical museum in Copenhagen. No surprise, it is a university-affiliated museum, transformed with collections previously used in lectures. At first, I couldn’t find it upon arriving at the address: There was no sign on the street, but a thick wooden door. I then realised that thise must have been the feelings for many visitors when they went to the Whipple Museum: Being discouraged by the intimidating door, fearing that whatever was behind the door was far too important to be disturbed.
Originally I thought it was going to be another small and quirky museum that had no choice but to take advantage of every inch of space possible, that the arrangement and curation were going to be limited. However, I was surprised to find that first of all, the space was bigger than I thought (at least bigger than Whipple), and that there was a certain curatorial logic that went through different galleries. From a display that asked visitor to reflect upon difficult choices during Covid, to an interactive game about factors that extend or shorten humans’ lives expectancy, permanent displays showed a wide coverage of various yet common aspects regarding health and medicine. I especially appreciate the display of instruments for the visually impaired, such as Braille, typewriters, and computers. As a person who is severely myopic, I understand how these tools can make a huge difference to the blind.
www.museion.ku.dk
The Exhibitions “The Body Collected” exceeded my expectations. Making the best use of the human remains collected since the 18th century, the exhibition discussed life, death, deformity, and disease from macro to micro. Exhibitions as such always attracted people who simply wanted to snap pictures of the “freaks” and the “deformed”, i.e. skeletal remains or samples left by people with disability. I don’t deny that the power of genes never stops amazing me, yet every time I see a giggling teenager (usually they were there only because of some private summer camp, and that a cultural visit was a must to satisfy the parents) laughing while taking pictures of “things”, I understand more why there are rules in UK museums that forbid people from any photography. Visitors should always be reminded of the magnitude of historical superstition, prejudice, misunderstanding, and the emotions that accompanied all stillborns of deformity and victims of disease when being presented with human remains. On the other side, UK museums are probably the only country that actually put out signs that forbid photography when it comes to human remains, and not every museum abides the rule (e.g. archaeological remains). It is always surprising to see no effort is made in European medical museums to remind people of the ethics and respect, but truly, what position museums have to do so?
Before my visit ended at a strange temporary exhibition on germs and intestinal health (about digestion and of course, waste), I gladly found that I could buy acopy of the display text for “The Body Collected”, English available. I didn’t have time to read all the labels, but the book provided wonderful, high-res photos of the collections, accompanied with paragraphs written by the curators who explained the context and stories of the dead. After reading the book, I felt that the body parts, severed and partially presented, reclaimed a bit of humanity. It as very important for me.
3. Danish Architecture Centre, 5 Sep
I wasn’t planning on visiting the DAC, but eventually stepped inside since it was included as free entry in my Copenhagne Pass. I’m glad that I did visit this place, as it was very informative.
I had heard many positive comments about Danish architecture, that it was one of the best when talking about modern design. Although I never pay any attention on architecture, I can still apreciate the curatorial decision made in the gallery that presented the philosphy and creativity of Danish architecture. One thing I took away was the importance of techniques to make bricks and bricklaying, as well as the design to let all Copenhagen citizens enjoy water. When looking at the illustration, I remembered the long jetty that I walked by every morning in front of my hotel, where I imagined would be fully packed with swimmers in summer.
I did not visit that many museums when I was in Copenhagen; instead, I went to a few famous historical royal palaces. As my attention now is more focus on how museums manage and care for their collections on the public side, I don’t think I know enough to critique the management of royal palaces and heritage sites. As magnificent as they are, I don’t intend to make this blog into a travel diary.
Copenhagen was a beautiful place that reminded me of Amsterdam: Water, canal, bikes, and clear sky above neat city planning. Yet it is indeed a city of its own distinctive charm.
This blog post was very much delayed in publishing, as I was soon caught in a whirl wind of work and life changes when I came back to the UK: New job, new role, things to learn, etc..
--
--
