Title: Three must-visit spaces for Art & Design in Copenhagen.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When this Airbnb host in London decided to be an Airbnb guest in design-conscious Copenhagen, he found much to be inspired by in the galleries and museums. If you’re also looking for design/art inspiration, here are three spots you should include when visiting Copenhagen. (Although just being in the city itself seems to activate latent design genes…)
The SMK houses 700 years’ worth of Danish and Nordic art and sculpture with a clear demarcation between the original architecture built in 1896 and the stunning, light-filled modernist section built 100 years later. If you like a chronological context, you can work your way from the front and understand the big themes through the centuries with clever diversions into more obscure and ‘problematic’ branches every so often.
A short train trip north of Copenhagen takes you to another repository of modern art in a stunning waterside setting, housed in an architectural marvel.
Louisiana (named after the original owners three wives, all named Louise) is a day trip in itself. The permanent collection boasts works by Picasso, Klein, Arp, Moore, Warhol, Hockney, Giacometti and oodles more. The current exhibitions included a immersive retrospective of Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama, Lucien Freud and ‘Africa’, a hugely thoughtful and surprising treatise on architecture, art and culture from the continent today.
If Copenhagen can’t have a stunning museum of design, what hope is there for anywhere else? The museum has the lofty twin ambitions to both serve ‘as a source of inspiration for people active in industry’ while making ‘contemporary consumers both critically aware and discerning’.
This translates of course into a whole lot of #chairporn…
So, despite ostensibly taking a break from London, Airbnb and design, I find myself filled with a better understanding of how Danish design works. Now to bring some of that all important hygge to Kith & Kine.
Kith & Kine is a stylish two-bed property close to all the hip/tech action in Shoreditch, London. Come and stay and see how far we’ve got recreating some Danish hygge…
--
--
Two rooms in London via @Airbnb. Ridiculously close to the tech action. Has vinyl. Some bovine branding (but it all makes sense). Chief cowboy = @endaguinan

Title: From Odense to Copenhagen: The Transformative Impact of My Erasmus Exchange
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is dedicated to learning about the world around us. The topics covered here range from travel and geography to languages and cultures.

Member-only story
--
10
Share
Gabriela Trofin-Tatár
“Travel has been the fire that has shaped my current self, accumulating layers of complexity in my thinking, thoughts, and actions as a result of my journey’s successes and failures.” Gabriela Trofin-Tatár
My Erasmus University exchange in Odense, Denmark, during the spring semester of 2006 was an unforgettable chapter in my life. Immersed in the vibrant atmosphere of Tehnisk Kollegium, I discovered the power of collaborative learning through teamwork, an experience that would profoundly shape my educational journey.
Moreover, during the semester, I traveled both in Denmark and abroad, expanding my horizons and becoming more curious about my studies.
In the following sections, I invite you to read about events and places that had a positive impact on my love for Denmark and my cultural awareness during that time.

Title: Here Is My Alternative Tourist Guide To Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Supporting new writers to the Medium platform

Member-only story
--
2
Share
I am not often in Copenhagen. It is a one-hour drive from where I live. And I can get my shopping and entertainment needs covered closer to home. But I do go there occasionally. And when I do, I see reminders of our racist past everywhere.
I will start with a disclaimer. I am a white dude, who is soon approaching 40. I am a history buff. And I have always tried to fight racism where I can. But I am aware I can not fully escape my racist history.
Many Europeans acknowledge the blatant racism in the U.S. But they falsely believe that it is a uniquely American problem. It is not. The slave ships that brought these slaves to the U.S. sailed from our harbors.
Racism is a European invention. We had to invent it in order to justify our atrocities against people of color. And guess what. We think our invention was so smart, that we Europeans call the historic period where we shipped slaves and exploited our colonies “The Age of Enlightenment”.
Yes, racism is systemic. And trying to censor this truth in our classrooms will not make it untrue.
--
--

Title: #ResponsiveOrg — first meetup in Copenhagen.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

En samling af artikler til inspiration for #ResponsiveOrg interesserede i Danmark

--
Listen
Share
Based on a meeting in Copenhagen, one call to Australia, a number of tweets, Linkedin and Yammer posts, the word was spread and the first #ResponsiveOrg meetup in Copenhagen became reality Thursday 27. November 2014 — read about the preparation here ,
Eager to meet the people who signed up for #ResponsiveCoffee in Copenhagen on Meetup.com I got to the cafe about 30 minutes early…
tables where placed in a corner, and the coffee was just about to brew — we where ready to meet.
All interested and curious we gathered and the talking started by one to one introductions as people showed up, then the non existing agenda developed in this way:
6 men joined — Kenneth has listed ResponsiveOrg Copenhagen relevant tweets here — and here are the names of the 6 men at the first meetup
admitted - it looks a bit as a bunch of..
“..handsome, thoroughly clever, perfectly plump men in our prime” as Karlsson on the roof says
The conversation touched diversity and all agreed it is needed for future meetups. Also discussing the need for a meetup in english, which is obviously is an option if non Danish-speaking wants to join — please let us know at meetup.com or as a comment here.
I am not really sure, but I know that I have found likeminded people whom I want to share my experiences with, and I am sure they will share interesting angles on topics that relates to #futureofwork, #ResponsiveOrg, #worklikeanetwork — add the # you like, or tell the story as Matt Partovi
http://player.vimeo.com/103393370
One thing it instantly brougth was Kenneths scoop.it on Leadership a ressource of inspiration for future topics, and so much more.
And the all participants was featured in this tweet
Wanting to get into a series of meetups, the next meetup is planned as #ResponsiveMorning for the 14. January at 9:30 - you can signup via meetup.com
Do you want to give a 10 minute speak about a topic you care about? If so suggest a topic for the meetup, and suggest a topic anyway.
A big thanks to all of you showing up, and for those of you who showed interested but couldn’t find the time, come by in the future.
To all of you who liked, retweetet and shared the posts to make the noise — most appreciated!
--
--

Title: On re-routes and rainy Copenhagen days
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
August 4, Sabbatical Day 23
Sunday did not go at all like I had planned. I walk out of my apartment at 10:40am, planning to bike to church (that starts at 11am), only for rain drops to start falling. So I pivot to taking the train … only that adds to my travel time and makes me 10 minutes late to church. And I’m sleepy in my movie-theater seat in the back of the auditorium, fighting heavy eyelids. And if we’re being honest, I don’t get much out of the guest pastor speaking.
But I’ve still got the entire day, right? Only it’s pouring when I walk out of church, so I linger a little longer in the lobby, game-planning my day on my phone.
Church attendees are slowly making their way out (this church takes place in a hotel conference center). And one makes it’s way over to me. Glasses, ash-blonde air a little ruffled, lanky and crooked smile. No rain jacket.
“Were you at Hillsong?” He asks in heavily accented English.
“Yes, I’m visiting Copenhagen and every time I’ve come to the city before, I have come to church here.”
He proceeds to tell me that he just moved to Copenhagen last week from Bratislava, Slovakia. He’s staying in a hostel now, but wants to live by the beach. He tells me about the bike he bought from a guy a month ago (the guy just left it on the street for him to buy!), and how it was locked up on the street for the last month waiting for his return. I tell him about my journey to Copenhagen, my sabbatical.
Eventually I see the rain lightening up, and say my goodbyes. I walk off to the metro, planning on taking it to Norrebro to get this focaccia sandwich I dreamed about getting last visit. And just as I make it down the escalator, I hear an alarm going off.
“Evacuate immediately,” it says.
So everyone makes there way back up the elevator, crowing under the metro awning outside, because — mind you — it’s still raining. Sirens start in the distance, and a fire truck rounds the corner.
I make the call to try for the bus instead, since clearly this train station won’t be opening back up anytime soon. I walk back past the church, past the Slovak, and to a bus station a block away. The bus is 10 minutes late, but finally arrives. By this point, it’s nearing 2pm, and the sun has broken through — you’d hardly know it was so nasty 30 minutes ago.
I get my focaccia sandwich from Rondo, inhale it, and start walking back to my apartment to pick up my bike. I think I take a wrong turn somewhere along the way, because it’s taking longer than I anticipated. I’m cutting through Fælledparken, and start realizing — if I want to go visit Grundtvigs church, I need to do it now, since they close at 4 and are closed Monday. So once again, I backtrack to the bus station. And what do you know, the heavens open up midway. I wait under a tree for a couple minutes, waiting for it to lighten up, then make my way to the bus stop. The bus is late, which I’m starting to realize is a Copenhagen trend. I start seeing a bunch of people walking in the same direction with jerseys, and realize there’s a match on today. Do I want to go? I calculate the time it takes to get to the church, take a quick spin, then go back to my apartment to change, then go to the game. It’s a lot, so I decide against. This is all being thought through while I’m on the bus.
Eventually I get to the church … only to walk up and find that it’s closed due to water damage. And honestly, I’m more bummed about the hour of travel time round trip than the actual church being closed.
So I make my way back to my apartment, changing out of my church clothes and swapping my bag for coffee shop books and journals. There’s one right around the corner from my apartment that a guy from Hagen Espresso in London recommended. It’s pretty full for 4pm when I get there, so I snag a seat inside since there’s not a seat open outside to enjoy this gorgeous weather.
But right after my drink is delivered, one does open up, so I gather up my bag and cortado and relocate. I’m sitting outside for around 20 minutes before I see a young guy — who I think is not Danish — walk into the shop. He’s by himself, wearing a Cyprus cap, along with a green market tote bag.
He sits at the table to left of me, back to the street, while I’m facing the street, Mere Christianity in hand. I keep eying him — do I make conversation with this fellow traveler? After all, sometimes I’ve found some of my best travel moments behind starting a conversation. But how to start — do I ask him about Cyprus?
At this point, I pull out my phone that’s plugged into my power bank. And that’s my opening (or rather, his).
“Do you have a USB-C cable?” He asks, once again in accented English. “I have a power bank, I just need the cord.”
And this, reader, is where I thank God once again that I bought a power bank with several types of cords.
“No, but this has one in it. Here, you take it,” I insist. “Are you visiting Copenhagen?”
“Yes, I just arrived today.”
“Oh, and where are you from?”
“I’m from Ukraine, but I’m living in Italy now.”
“Oh, where in Italy?” I ask, thinking about my January trip there.
Outside of Florence, he tells me. “I’ve hitch-hiked here from Florence.”
Cue my jaw dropping.
“I first went to Berlin, where I stayed with some friends. Then hitchhiked here. I wanted an adventure, and I had things that I wanted to figure out for life. But now I think I know what I need to do next, so I’m going to just fly home. Plus hitchhiking is exhausting.”
The conversation that follows is not one that I could have predicted.
I find out more about his life — He lived in Italy from 2019 to February 2022, making money so he could come back to Ukraine flush with cash — rich in their eyes. This is when he says he thought his dream, ideal life would start. But he didn’t have to explain it too much — Russia invaded a month later. Eventually he got out of Ukraine (which he didn’t explain, but I know means avoided being conscripted). Back to Italy, working in services industry — a textile manufacturer, I think.
He said his life was comfortable, but he didn’t want to blink and life fly by. I asked him what his realization was, and he answered, “I need to leave Italy.” He has various gripes with Italy and Italians — lack of openness and diversity, lack of parks, lack of opportunities to connect with others. He also doesn’t know what to do work wise — he’s tried a lot of different things.
I couldn’t help but think at this point — “Oh buddy. You’re searching for a happy life, but that’s never going to satisfy.”
I ask him what brings him joy, and he says talking with people — at some points he struggles to find the words in English. He likes providing advice, or crisis management, as he says.
He asks about me, too. I tell him about my sabbatical, about processing life, what I want to do next.
“How satisfied are you with your life? Put a number on it.”
I tell him that while I love my life, of course there are things I’d love to be different. I’d love to be married, I’d love for experience physical healing. 75%, I say.
“That’s pretty high.”
We talk some about singleness — I say there are things I could not do if I was married. Like working with the youth kids that bring me so much joy. I probably could not do a trip like this if I was married. That’s when I’m surprised to find out he’s married (no ring). Just left his wife back in Italy to hitchhike for a bit.
I explain that in the south in the U.S., people get married younger. My sisters both married young.
“Do you feel pressure to? From your family?” He asks.
“Not really.” It’s more the pressure of my own timeline. But my parents don’t quite understand the different world I am dating in, and find themselves befuddled that being asked out is so non-existent for so many of my friends.
We shut the coffee shop down, and move to a bench next door. At some point, he has me follow him on Instagram so we can keep up with one another. How much, we’ll see. Near the end of our conversation, he asks me, “So what’s your plan from here?”
I clarify — “Do you mean for today, this trip, or my life?”
“For your life.”
Oof. How to answer this?
“Here’s the thing, I can make plans for my life, but ultimately, I could die tomorrow –“ He recoils a bit at this — “I mean, I hope not, but I know where I would be if I did. And here’s the thing, as great as all this is,” I wave my hand at the street in front of me, “Heaven is better. So I can make plans, my life is not my own. My life belongs to God. He has plans for me. One of the things I love about God is I can do x or y, but he’s going to use it regardless for my good and his glory.”
He’s watching me as I talk and I don’t know if I’ve entirely lost him. I feel the need for honesty not pontifications.
“Listen, is it easy to say that? Absolutely not. I want to be tight fisted with my life. I have to remind myself regular to let go, because I know his plan for me is so much better.”
He doesn’t respond to any of this, and that’s okay. I don’t need him to. The conversation peters out some from there — but before we part, I ask to take his picture and he acquiesces.
We stand — he’s VERY TALL — and bends at both the knees and the waist to give me a very awkward hug. “Don’t die tomorrow,” he tells me.
I smile at that, and tell him I’ll try not to.
I walk off in the direction of the grocery, reeling a bit. Did the last hour and a half just happen? I’ve never had a conversation with a stranger like that before.
I rewind through my day — the delays and redirects and ending up at Prolog Coffee outside at 4pm. It would be easy to look at my encounter with Bogdan (that’s his name) in a silo. But I can see the fingerprints streaking across the window of my day, and I can see how the fact that I ended up there was not happenstance. Who knows if any of that will stick with him, but it was as much for me as it was for him.
There’s this rewiring starting to happen inside of me on this trip.
Life with God is an adventure. I’ve said that before, but I’ve thought about it more in the large-scale sense. Adventure of career, dating, etc.
But now, now I’m starting to realize that every day is an adventure. To look at the margins — or lack of — and invite him in. Surprise me, God.
--
--
I heard someone say once that they had “a curiosity that spans the universe.” And I thought, “That’s me.”

Title: I Found Happiness (In Denmark) By Getting A… Bicycle
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Heartfelt, down-to-earth and real stories by women for women. Support our lovely Modern Women editing team @ ko-fi.com/modernwomen

Member-only story
--
38
Share
When I arrived in Copenhagen six years ago, after a particularly hard year in New York, I needed to regroup, re-think and reinvent myself. I was stressed out, exhausted and confused — everything you’d expect a New Yorker to be. My salvation came from the most unexpected source — a bicycle.
If in New York cycling was saved for hipsters, exercise fanatics and tourists at that time, in Copenhagen, it was (and is) the main mode of transportation. Bike roads run alongside car roads there, with dedicated traffic lights, and bicyclists are respected and given priority. In return, they obey strict rules and laws. The whole thing is very civilized. No yelling, no honking, no confusion.
After two weeks of taking overpriced buses like a tourist and gawking at masses of bicycles at intersections, I gave in and bought a used bike. Little did I know, my rusty two-wheeled companion was to become my best friend in Denmark’s cold capital and my best chance at finding happiness.
--
--

Title: Underground Bands — Hypnos, Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My old friend Kathrine invited us to stay with her a while at her new tiny house in Copenhagen. For our first night out, she looked at a number of options: There was a weird performance art piece by The Center for Militant Futurologi, drummers were needed for a climate change demonstration on two tallships sailing down whatever the big river in the middle of the city is called (I swear I can’t find this information anywhere), and a jam session was brewing in Freetown Christiania. Kathrine said her best bet was a metal show at a small bar called Lygtens Kro, with a headliner from Sweden (Gothenburg, naturally) who played in the style of the 1980s. “Power metal?” I asked, and her boyfriend said that sounded right to him. I became partly acquainted with the numerous highly-specific metal subgenres back in my nightclub days, and I do my best to keep up as the lexicon matures; but I’m never sure what names to use.
So we met at the Metro station, hit the bar, and got a round of Golden Ladies (a slightly-higher-priced form of Tuborg lager, analogous to ordering a Miller Genuine Draft instead of a Miller High Life). The opening band, I thought, was good but not great. They could use a new guitarist. Still, it was enjoyable enough, stoner rock with a vein of grunge in there that might have resulted more from a lack of rehearsal than an aesthetic choice. I figured this was what would be on the menu tonight. I couldn’t have been more wrong. After a short set break, during which I smoked a comically tiny joint outside, the headliners took the stage sans announcement and began to play. I happened to be near the door that was nearest the stage, headed straight in, and got myself an enviable position in the very front of the room to see and hear a band called Hypnos.
Holy shit, these boys could play. There was an Iron Maiden thing happening, sometimes escalating into Queensryche territory or putting its root down into Soundgarden. If you know those bands, then a certain kind of metal vocals are playing in your head now that speaks to a certain era of rock — “No one sings like you anymore,” as the late great Chris Cornell lamented — and you’re right on the money. This singer Linus Johansson was extra fun — a sensuous and playful front man with frizzy blond hair and a porno mustache, with a voice like Geoff Tate and moves like Robert Plant, graceful arms and serpentine torso, with penetrating eye contact at such close quarters. This bar didn’t even have a stage, so I was just standing right in front of these guys, able to really get into what the players were doing, and they were doing plenty. The lead guitarist, Pontus Isebring, was positively fucking rad, an inspired shredder in a paroxysm behind his veil of dark brown hair yet locked in tight with the rhythm section. To call them a rhythm section is to undersell them a bit, in fact: The younger-looking second guitarist Oskar Wersall often harmonized with solos and melodies note for note, leaving the chugging rhythmic floor to dead-serious bassist Anton Kallmin; and even that mustachioed and muttonchopped warrior was doing some pretty fancy shit when space opened up on the bottom end. Drummer Oskar Brindmark was a beast and a scientist, not a drop of sweat on his brow as he assembled and deconstructed patterns with breakneck speed. They were one sick five-piece metal outfit, my friends. This isn’t even my kind of music, particularly, but I know greatness when it’s blasting me in the face.
It wasn’t all about technical chops, either. Part of what made Hypnos so much fun to watch was that they were all having so much fun, enjoying one another’s company on stage in a way that lots of bands fail to do even in their honeymoon years. Anton and Oskar W. stepped in to share backup vocals on a single mic, eyes flashing and heads bobbing at one another. Linus couldn’t get enough of Pontus’ solos — every time the latter cut loose, the former sidled up real close and let his own fingers wiggle up and down his mic stand in a celebratory air guitar dance that brought to mind Bowie/Ronson in the Spiders From Mars years. I guess this singer isn’t even the original guy — he joined the band in 2017 — but having watched them play I can hardly imagine Hypnos without him. That this band remains so infatuated with the stage and with each other on their fifteenth year of performing says much about their special chemistry, and for an audience member it makes all the difference.
At the end of the set, Linus asked us to make sure and buy something at the merch table. “We don’t have any money!” he cheerfully informed us. Sadly, I hadn’t a dime to spare at that very broke point in my own independently-booked tour of Europe; so the best I could offer was my congratulations and this article. Hypnos seems to be on tour at all times, releasing music on The Sign Records that you can buy right now and generally doing the work of a rock and roll band in the prime of life. You should find an opportunity to see them play live, ideally in a small venue, and bring enough cash for the CD or the t-shirt or whatever. Folks like us are out here scraping by in 21st-century showbiz, even living metal gods from Sweden, and time shovels dirt over all of us soon enough. It’s up to the fans to keep the scene alive. As long as there are heads in the club, Hypnos is sure to keep them banging.
--

by Jim Baggott
[Note from Massimo: This article by my friend Jim Baggott is a bit on the technical side. But if you care about our deep understanding of the world, or about the nature of science, or about the relationship between science and philosophy, enjoy.]
I read Massimo’s essay “Physicists don’t know what the world is like, at bottom” (29 May 2020, also here) with considerable interest. And no little frustration. In the epilogue of my new book Quantum Reality (published in the US in September) I close with a brief analysis of a survey of attitudes on the interpretation of quantum mechanics that was conducted among physicists in 2011. Massimo’s essay concerned a more recent (and more extensive) survey published in 2016, which I’d overlooked. Thankfully, in most respects both surveys produced similar results.
Massimo observed that, despite all the popular media attention given to fantastical interpretations which invoke the existence of multiple, parallel universes, the Copenhagen interpretation remains the most favored. (And I heaved a sigh of relief, as this was true also in 2011.)
But what I found even more fascinating is that the 2016 survey, conducted by Sujeevan Sivasundaram and Kristian Hvidtfelt Nielsen at Aarhus University in Denmark, included questions which allowed them to go beyond this simple statement of…

Title: Copenhagen & Christiania: The Yin & Yang of Scandinavia
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I took fairly easy train ride from Stockholm, through Malmo, and then over a gigantic bridge that spans the sea between Malmo and Copenhagen. I had no idea what to expect from Copenhagen, but somehow I knew I was going to enjoy my week in the home of Carlsberg. It turned out to be one of my favourite cities in Europe and the first time I stayed in a hostel with triple bunk beds.
Copenhagen was a fascinating city with an interesting mix of old and modern architecture in addition to many parks areas and canals. The bike lanes were also the best i’d used in Europe. I was able to skateboard on them anywhere I wanted in the city without having to go on the actual roads at all.
Apparently there was a study done about the Copenhagen bike lanes and the conclusion was that it was actually faster to use the bike lanes to bike to your destination than to drive within the city.
Copenhagen also had what I consider one of the best modern art museum that I visited in Europe, the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art.
Set a bit outside of the city on the coast, the building is at first unassuming by appearing to be a diminutive house, but when you enter it opens into a vast underground exhibit area.
In the surrounding grounds there was a pond with a small forest and various sculptures perched around some walking trails.
There were also some large open lawn areas with more sculptures and installations overlooking the sea. It was a beautiful place.
After being in the Copenhagen for a few days I could notice some contrasts between there and the Stockholm, most notably the liquor laws. Stockholm’s laws were more conservative than the redundant Canadian laws, forcing you to buy alcohol from specific government run liquor stores that close around 7 pm on weekdays, 3 pm on Saturdays and are completely closed on Sundays. Furthermore it was illegal to drink outside of establishments, and the latest almost all bars and clubs stay open till was 3 am. In contrast, in Copenhagen you can drink on the streets, buy alcohol from the corner store and party all night if you want to.
An interesting thing to note is the bottle deposit is so high on beers cans and bottles in Copenhagen that anytime I was sitting in a park enjoying a beer with some friends there would be at least five people coming up to you to ask for your empties, which was great because you never had to concern yourself with finding a garbage can to dispose of them. Win for the Danish.
During my week in Copenhagen I went to three music festivals. The best one was a free festival the city put on in the middle of a park called the King’s Garden that had a castle on a hill. Everybody was chilling on the grass drinking beers and enjoying one of the nicest days of the summer while music blared from a stage set up underneath the castle. I met some friendly people and ended up being invited over to somebody’s house for some after party drinks.
One of the most compelling aspects about Copenhagen was the existence of Freetown Christiania. Christiania is a place that exists in the city center of a Copenhagen, which is a self-proclaimed republic that stemmed from squatters living there since the 1970s. Christiania is it’s own world.
There were only about 800 official residents living there that have built themselves all kinds of strange houses and have even built their own schools to teach their children their own curriculum.
Street art was splashed everywhere all over the buildings and there were numerous small cafes and restaurants around that only accept cash.
The part about Christiania that most people come for though was the open selling and consumption of marijuana. There was a street called ‘pusher street’ that was lined with at least 20 stalls selling all kinds of hash, marijuana and edibles.
Here you can buy a joint, light it up, smoke it and nobody will bother you. It is fascinating that such a place existed right in the middle of one of the most modern cities in Europe. Still what happens in Christiania was technically illegal so the residents had established two rules for visitors. The first rule was no running, because if people are running the residents assume it’s a police raid and they will start to run away as well. I later met some Danish dude that told me if you are caught running in Christiania you will receive quite the beating. The second rule was no photos, which was unfortunate because there are some many cool art installations and works of street are littered around the self-proclaimed republic.
Still I was able to sneak a photo or two, but there was one instance where I took a photo of the entrance sign with a resident in the photo and he came up to me and made me delete the photo from my phone.
In the end for me Copenhagen was an ideal blend of south Europe and Scandinavia. It was a clean, organized, well thought out city that has a little bit of everything for everybody where you didn’t have to look over your shoulder to go drink a beer. I actually looked into immigrating there, but unfortunately I would have had to learn the Danish language, which, according to one of my Swedish friends, takes the Danish more time than any other group of children in the world to learn their native language.
Don’t forget to visit my travel blog https://thezeetree.com for more stories.
thezeetree.com

Title: The Copenhagen Interpretation is Wrong; Here’s Why
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Fermion Physics
The Copenhagen interpretation is one of the most popular interpretations of quantum mechanics, and it is the orthodoxy in physics. It is usually related to all the weird things about quantum mechanics you may have heard, like Schrodinger’s Cat. But what if I told you that the copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics — is wrong? Here’s why
Before I write the rest of this article, I want to say that my beliefs here are not the orthodoxy in the physics world — most physicists believe the copenhagen interpretation and most of the rest don’t care. I’m not claiming to have made some new discovery. What I’m doing here is providing an argument against the Copenhagen interpretation. I’m not saying it is a complete fabrication. But what must be kept in mind is that most physicists believe the copenhagen interpretation simply because that is what is usually taught in universities. Many don’t really care to look for actual justifications or an alternative explanation. A majority of physicists agreeing does not make them correct, and it also does not make them wrong. Even though the measurement problem is not a settled issue, the arguments I present here will be as objective as possible and as reasonable as possible. If you disagree with any of my arguments, great! Tell me why I’m wrong in the comments. With all that said, let’s begin.
It would be great to start out by defining the copenhagen interpretation. The Copenhagen interpretation turns out to not be well defined, and there is many disagreement between self identified proponents, but the copenhagen interpretation could be summed up as
These are the postulates of the Copenhagen interpretation.
The way the copenhagen interpretation is formulated is already problematic. It does not define what a measurement is, it does not talk about the eigenvalue of a system before a measurement, and it does not say why the wave function is related to the probability density. It turns out that this is by design. The copenhagen interpretation is intentionally formulated to be vague, and to just describe what is measured. If a scientist walks into a lab, and does a measurement, the wave function will indeed tell the scientist how likely he will get that measurement. The copenhagen interpretation could be thought as the instructions a medicine container has. “Take 1 pill each day and your sore throat will be cleared.” These instructions do not tell you how the pill clears your throat, it does not say what the pill is doing inside your body, it just tells you what happens. The same thing happens with the copenhagen interpretation. It just tells you what you’re gonna (likely) get, and dodges all other questions. For many physicists, this is satisfactory. They have a theory that can predict stuff, so why will they care more about what’s going on beyond the math? I will respond to this point later, but right now I want to give more arguments about why the Copenhagen interpretation is wrong.
Like I said earlier, it doesn’t say what counts as a measurement. Does the measurer have to be conscious? Does the measurer play by the rules of quantum mechanics? Does the measurer have to be outside the system? It doesn’t answer these. Does the system before measurement even have an energy? It doesn’t answer this either. All it does is it tells you what you might get. Some people will try to answer these questions though and still claim they are copenhaganists. A common answer is that before measured, the system is in “all states at once” or “smeared out into a wave”. This is not the copenhagen interpretation; it’s an objectively false description of quantum mechanics that I debunked in this article.
Another statement is that the object does not have a definite value before measured. This statement, though not directly incorrect, is going a step further and talks about the actual nature of a particle before measurement. The copenhagen interpretation only talks about probabilities before measurement (states are probabilistic), not the status of a particle having a certain quality before measurement. So if that stance is taken, then it is no longer the copenhagen interpretation. That stance is also very problematic: If I never observe an atom decay, does that mean that it does not having a decay status at all (ex. it has neither decayed nor not decayed)? This statement is an oxymoron. An object can either decay, or not decay. This is one of the basic principles of logic: a is not “not a” by definition. Some people decide to bite the bullet, and accept that oxymorons can still be true. This is a philosophy called “trivialism”, which is a topic for next time.
A common belief among Copenhaganists is that the measurement devices have to be outside the system. This makes sense, since the opposite would apply that systems can measure themselves, which would imply that systems always exist as having definite eigenvalues since they are constantly measuring themselves. It is this element of the Copenhagen interpretation that destroys itself from the inside. What I want to stress is that what follows is not personal interpretation, but actual undisputed fact about quantum mechanics. When we have 1 particle in our system, the wave function is a function of that one particle: it maps the locations/momenta/energies of that particles into another dimension (the axis of the wave function). In other words, it is a function that maps one input to an output. For 2 particles, the wave function is a function of 2 particles. For 3 particles, the wave function is a function of 3 particles. You get the idea. What I’m describing here is what is called “configuration space”, the space that contains all possible configurations of a system. We can go higher and higher and higher. Quantum mechanics implies that there is a wave function that is a function of every single particle in the universe. Again, this isn’t an assumption or interpretation. It is just quantum mechanics itself: The wave function if a function of n-particles in an n+1 dimensional configuration space. Just replace n to the number of all particles. So now we know that there is a wavefunction of the universe. What does this mean under the Copenhagen interpretation? Well the Copenhagen interpretation requires the measurer to be outside the system, but the system in question is the universe! This means that for the wave function to collapse, then someone outside the universe would have to measure the universe — but wouldn’t this person also be a part of the system? So you’d need another person outside everything else in the system to measure the person inside the system, and you get an infinite regress. Unless you believe that there is someone outside the universe that is collapsing wave functions left and right, then this is huge trouble for copenhaganists. Again, what we did was just normal quantum mechanics. We showed that the Copenhagen interpretation cannot even reconcile with this without postulating an infinite regress of measurers outside of our universe. Now since we actually do measure things inside the universe, this is a direct contradiction of what is implied by the Copenhagen interpretation, making the copenhagen interpretation (the way it is usually presented), false. Someone could try to save copenhagen by saying that systems can measure themselves, but that would mean that a system will have a definite value prior to us measuring it (since it had already measured itself), which would be a hidden-variable theory — something many copenhaganists are against: you can’t have your measurement device and eat it too.
Some people say, “we shouldn’t ask about what happens before it was measured since we aren’t measuring it.” This statement is self defeating. Quantum mechanics talks about probabilities before measurement, so with the logic, the copenhagen interpretation shouldn’t be talked about at all — no quantum mechanics should be talked about at all. But the stance itself is one on quantum mechanics, so it is a self defeating point. This is somewhat analogous to what happened to philosophical logical positivism.
Some people simply don’t care: a usual statement they give is “well all the interpretations lead to the same results”. The people who genuinely believe this are a danger to the progression of physics. It is no secret that particle physics has been somewhat stagnant over recent years. And in my opinion, it is precisely because of people like this: the moderate. The moderate does not care about any deeper insight or intuition in what their mathematics describes. All they care about is performing a calculation. But physics isn’t just about performing calculations — it shouldn’t be just about calculations. Did Newton study the nature of light just to perform a calculation? Did Einstein theorize atoms just to perform a calculation? Did Georges Lemaitre, when he theorized the Big Bang, do so just to perform a calculation? The answer to all 3 of these, if you haven’t gotten it already, is no. These physicists did physics to better understand the world around them. They wanted to understand what made the universe tick. They wanted to fundamentally know the nature of material objects. All of these discoveries of course used calculations, and needed calculations, but calculations are what physicists use to guide them into understanding nature — they do not do calculations for the sake of calculations. One who only does physics for calculations is no different than a calculator; they do not need a job, because a calculator can do it for them — probably better. The reason as to why we do not have many “New Einsteins” or “New Diracs” is because many physicists of this modern age do not question the very meaning of the equations they write. They do not care to see beyond the math. They do not bother to ponder where the lure of physics is leading them — they only care about publishing that paper with some calculation. It was Galileo questioning the geocentric model that contributed to heliocentrism, it was Newton questioning the epicycles that gave us Newton’s laws of gravitation, it was Einstein questioning the works of Newton — looking deeper into the meaning behind the math — that gave us general relativity. It was even Einstein’s challenges towards the quantum mechanics orthodoxy that sparked even more interest in the subject, and an increase in much new exciting material like Bell’s Theorem and Entanglement that became something bigger than intended. All of this started with people looking beyond the math and asking: “what does this all really mean at a fundamental level?” If physics has lost people like that, then it has lost everything.
--
--
2
One who understands nothing understands everything

Title: Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
After I left Amsterdam, I traveled to the beautiful, and quite similar, city of Copenhagen, the capital of Denmark. This Scandinavian city located in between the Danish mainland of Jutland and Sweden is surrounded by the sea on three sides, giving Copenhagen some of the most splendid waterside views next to the many canals, harbors, wharfs, and rivers found throughout the city.
Copenhagen has become one of my favorite cities in Europe. I enjoy its relaxed atmosphere, its abundance of picturesque sights, and its friendly people. Denmark has often been ranked the happiest country in the world, and I can see why. In addition to having a beautiful capital city, the Danes take time to enjoy life, often lounging with friends next to the waterfront, having drinks together at a cozy bar, or cruising on yachts and sailboats. When I studied abroad in Hong Kong in the summer of 2016 (right before my freshman year of college), many of the students I met there were Danish, and I learned that Danes travel quite often and are encouraged to do so with lots of vacation days and financial sponsorship for university students. This societal emphasis on enjoying life makes the typical Dane a happy and amiable individual.
The Danish lifestyle also contributes to the well-being of its citizens. American-style fast food is rare here, and people often eat healthy meals sourced from the surrounding countryside and the sea…

Title: How to live like a local in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Danish Lockdown Diary

--
1
Listen
Share
The thing that struck me after my first few days in Copenhagen is that the city feels, at once, foreign and familiar. Familiar, not because I’d been before, but because it feels livable and relatable. Foreign, because it’s dissimilar enough to be interesting.
After spending a month digesting and absorbing life in the Danish capital, I’ve learned some of its norms, and more importantly, a few insights on what can help you feel a little more integrated as you’re settling into this fine city.
Getting Around: Biking is going to be your most efficient — and exhilarating — mode for getting around the city. Be mindful, however, of cycling etiquette and left-hand turns. Cyclists use hand signals here like they’re a new form of communication. Look for the upward raise of the left hand to signal one is stopping on the curb or shuffling to pedal up to make a left hand turn (what they call a box turn, or the “Copenhagen Left”). Refer to diagram below:
It’s super confusing until you do it.
Catching the train or metro from the airport is easy, and takes just 13 minutes to arrive in the city center. Uber is also available, though I’ve found their estimated arrival times to be consistently inconsistent, so if you’re in a rush, better to hail a cab.
Dining: The Danes eat well, and by well, I mean flavor-forward and nutrient dense. Decent attention is being paid to sourcing ecologically and locally, though farmers markets are hard to come by. The closest example is the stalls at Torvehallerne. A few chefs are working to change this, but en masse, it’s slow.
There’s no shortage of delicious smørrebrød. A couple of my favorite establishments include Aamanns and Schønnemann’s. Aamanns is a bit more progressive; Schønnemann’s more traditional. They have an incredibly diverse selection of snaps, which is the classic accompaniment to a Danish lunch of smørrebrød.
Christian Puglisi, one of the two most notable chefs in Copenhagen, owns an empire of four establishments: Relæ, Manfreds, Bæst, and Mirabelle, a bakery. His founding story between Relæe and Manfreds (originally published in Fool Magazine) is a fun one, and worth a read.
And delighting nearly every palate, former Noma chef Rosio Sanchez, originally from Chicago and with Mexican roots, is upping the global taco game with her handmade tortillas and house made cheese, made with Danish milk and cheese cultures shipped in from Mexico. Her tacos are ridiculously good and unique in flavor.
Move that body: While you’re loading up on all the carbs from rye bread (rugbrød) and beer (øl), think about taking a jog or a dip in the ocean at Kastrup Søbad.
The Danes love their exercise. Jogging around The Lakes is popular, as is through the public park, Superkilen.
Danish design: Danes love usefulness, clean lines, minimal pigment, and natural materials. From wooden countertops and bathroom paneling, to slate and tile floors, brick and stone, the home is an expression of the natural resources of the region. As it gets dark early in the evening in the winter months, you’ll find the custom of large, round, warm sailing lamps in many establishments, especially low-hanging to emphasize contrast and focus on the activity at hand. Candles burn nearly everywhere. They provide warmth and the symbolism of energy, when all the world outside is oft grey, damp, and moody.
Sights: Rundetårn is a remarkable monument to explore. The round tower, dating to the 17th century, was built as an astronomical observatory. Most notable is its equestrian staircase — and one of the best views above the city.
A visit to the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art, just 30 minutes north of the city by train, is a must.
Fashion: In terms of fashion, CPH is the capital for the sharpest in Scandinavian style. Home to brands like Norse Projects, Wood Wood, Henrik Vibskov, Dansk, Libertine Libertine, Mads Nørgaard, Won Hundred, and Samsøe & Samsøe, it is the Scandinavian capital to compose your look.
Hay House is a perennial must for lifestyle house and writing wares.
Where to stay: Airbnb is a great option for longer-term housing. If you want a place to simply crash for a few nights in style, I recommend the newly-opened boutique hotel, SP34, from the Brochner Group. They have a strong pillow game, and all of their furniture is custom.
In terms of neighborhoods to call home in central Copenhagen, Vesterbro is up and coming. Quiet, mainly residential, it is home to the Meatpacking District with a small handful of restaurants, galleries, and clubs. Dyrehaven is popular among Danes and expats alike. There are also a few co-working spaces clustering and a burgeoning tech scene in this neighborhood.
Adjacent is the town of Frederiksburg. Technically it’s a town surrounded by Copenhagen, but it’s literally in the middle of the city. Today the neighborhood is primarily residential, though it is home to a few great cafés and green spaces. One of the notable boulevards for taking in the scenery is Frederiksberg Allé.
Nørrebro is my preferred neighborhood, primarily due to its proximity to Christian Puglisi’s empire (Bæst, Mirabelle, Relæ, Manfred’s), Superkilen and the famous cemetery Assistens Kirkegården, the center of the city, and one of the best bars — The Barking Dog (and its accompanying shop which sells rare liquors by the 100g).
You, of course, have the city center, Københaven K. Tons of shopping, cafés, cobblestone streets, and palaces. Lastly, a few small neighborhoods linger to the east, namely Christianshavn, which encompasses a few smaller neighborhoods, including the rapidly evolving area where the future Noma will be located.
With the grey, brisk autumn days, you might fancy a coffee to keep you warm and awake. I recommend Coffee Collective, Enghave Kaffe, Democratic Coffee, and Koppi.
Rules to Live By

Title: Revisiting the Film “Copenhagen,” 10 Years Later
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Having experienced the issue of connecting someone only to later find out their real age, I’ve always been a fan of this a film, which is a nuanced take on romance that explores maturity, emotions, love, social norms, human dynamics, traumas, and human development. It borderlines on problematic and creepy, but carefully treads that path in an artful and truthful way.
The primary dynamic is the relationship of Effy, from Copehagen, and William, who is an American trying to locate his Danish grandfather, who we later learn was a Nazi and a bad father.
This film does an excellent job of making it difficult to first know Effy’s age. She smokes and is first introduced working at a hotel, which an American could easily attribute to someone older than 14.
Considering the actress who played her was 20 at the time of filming, the character is believable as possibly older, but the actress also does a great job of channeling younger mannerisms and making her age ambiguous.

Title: Food Places You Cannot Miss in Copenhagen (vegetarian-friendly) [2025 update]
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Nordic countries have many gems waiting for a hungry explorer to discover. The places which surprise though often lie in unexpected corners — food stalls in Reffen or Broens Gadekøkken, offering a taste of home origins of generations who migrated to Denmark decades ago, or refined restaurants which skilfully combine cooking and tradition. There is much more than Noma, Geranium, or Jordnær. For example, Michelin-Green-Starred restaurant ARK is by far my favourite vegetarian destination in the world (and here I mean all 38 countries I have travelled to).
This article is divided into four sections:
Copenhagen breakfast options are poor. If pastry for a morning bite is not enough and you are the type who needs a fulfilling meal in the morning, I have bad news for you.
Quality = money formula is incorporated in The Sixteen Twelves and Riviera, but the rest of the places — Ø12, Sonny, Darcy’s Kaffe, Atelier September, or Wulff & Konstali — are somewhat overpriced, standard in taste, indecently simple eateries.
Let’s start with the places I can genuinely recommend.
The Sixteen Twelves must be squeezed in every tourist’s tight schedule! The cafe serves comfort food, but the savour combinations can surprise even the pickiest foodies! For example, stracciatella and pickled rhubarb, or turmeric pickled egg and goat cheese, or brioche with salted and roasted coconut…Yummy! The drinks vary from mango lassi to turmeric latte so make sure to try one of those.
The demand is ridiculously high, so I recommend arriving at the opening or during the week.
Summary:
🌱 A few vegetarian options.⭐ 4/5 for interesting taste combos and iconic turmeric egg.💸 €20–30/ person
Riviera offers granola, toasts, summer salad, scrambled eggs, and many traditional Danish pastries such as tebirkes (remonse bun with poppy seeds) or kardemummabullar (cardamon bun). It is just good for its price. Scandinavian spacious interior with wooden tables and chairs is warm and welcoming, and there is a terrace for all resistant to cold.
Summary:
🌱 Plenty of vegetarian options.⭐ 4/5 for good quality of morning meals.💸 €20–30/ person
A bustling spot called Ø12 won’t be a local’s first choice, but if one is on lookout for a homelike breakfast and coffee, Ø12 checks all the boxes. I usually take the pancakes with fresh berries and vanilla cream, but there are other options such as avocado on sourdough bread, Benedict eggs, or oatmeal. Fresh juices taste excellent and brewed coffee is good as well. The food won’t leave anyone on a cloud nine but should at least satisfy one’s hunger.
Summary:
🌱 A few vegetarian options.⭐ 3/5 for a regular breakfast.💸 €20–30/ person
Atelier September closes the breakfast list. The food is rather standard in taste, and the portions are on the smaller side. If you suddenly find yourself in the city center and crave a quick familiar bite, this will do. The breakfast covers all the popular positions: pancakes with berries, avocado toast, yogurt with granola, eggs on bread, and so on.
Summary:
🌱 A few vegetarian options.⭐ 3/5 for a regular breakfast.💸 €7–30/ person
Probably one of the top-three restaurants in the world I have been so far is ARK. Vegan to its core, distinguished with a Michelin Green Star, ARK served the hellishly delicious tasting menu with the dish I will probably never forget — a vegan version of Chawanmushi.
As per the authentic Nordic philosophy, the restaurant strives for sustainability, and in my humble opinion, they are doing an amazing job! ARK has its own fungi farm, serves natural wines and creates its magic using only local ingredients!
Along with mentioned above Chawanmushi where egg was replaced with asparagus foam, I savoured burnt cabbage leaves with tomato, camomile, and red wine infusion, caviar made of black garlic seeds, peas and beans with Koji sauce and elderflower vinegar, and the most surprising dessert I have ever eaten — carrot creme patissiere with carrot pieces, coco crisps and rice paper soaked in Calvados and dill oil. I think before, I had never imagined that dill and carrot flavours marry so well together.
Summary:
🌱 100% vegan.⭐ 5/5 for making vegan food perfect.💸 €175 for a menu without wine/ non-alcoholic pairing
Bistro Lupa is a more affordable sister of ARK. It is a vegan restaurant with a won’t-remember-the-next-day interior, but excellent service and tasting menu. I strongly encourage you to add a serving of Lupa’s mushrooms once you embark on a tasting journey. Same as ARK’s, the core idea of the bistro is to use every piece, slice and crumb of ingredients in the dishes it serves. Fruits, vegetables, flowers, and herbs are being served together and each of the products opens up differently, depending on the combination. The amount of food on the tasting menu feels just right and if one goes for a la carte, five dishes for two people is sufficient (plus a portion of milk buns).
Summary:
🌱 100% vegan.⭐ 5/5 for making vegan food perfect.💸 €70 for a menu without wine/ non-alcoholic pairing
Aamanns 1921 is on the pricier side and offers traditional Scandinavian open-faced sandwiches. I was happy enough to have the opportunity to try one of those considered that original recipes always taste either fish or meat.
Two smørrebrøds make a perfect portion for one, and I tried a vegetarian, and a fish option — only to realise that smørrebrød is just not my cup of tea. Aamanns 1921 is worth a try, however, if meat and fish is what you like, head to Restaurant Schønnemann (book in advance!).
Summary:
🌱 3 vegetarian smørrebrøds.⭐ 3/5 for vegetarian options.💸 €40–50 for two smørrebrøds and a glass of wine.
There are many pizza places like Pizzeria Luca or Corsa pizza, but I prefer a place with a more nonchalant vibe — Flere Fugle. It is located in the underground neighbourhood Nordvest, and makes a good stop for lunch before taking a stroll along the rapidly developing area. Flere Fugle offers excellent coffee, but if you want to make an adventure out of the regular lunch time, go for coffee to Kaffedepartementet, and take a look at the The Library at Rentemestervej — a book heaven for kids :)
Summary:
🌱 A few vegetarian options.⭐ 5/5 for the chill vibe.💸 €19–25 for a pizza.
It is difficult to find a bad bakery in Copenhagen (with one exception mentioned in the ‘Eateries which are not there yet’ section). My top pastry shops are probably Skt. Peders Bageri, Flere Fugle, and Riviera. Depends on the area I am in when the sugar craving hits. First one is a go-to for pistachio cruffins, and traditional Danish pastries, last two are responsible for aromatic cardamon buns which are my favourite among all the pastries.
The traditional, the oldest, the Danish one — Skt. Peders Bageri. After a long dispute with a friend we concluded that the cardamon rolls they make are the tastiest in Copenhagen. I can also justify why a pistachio cruffin magically appears in my beg every time I pass the bakery (look for those between 10–13 every day as after 13 they disappear quickly).
💸 €5 for a bun.
Riviera is another decent pastry shop. What is nice about the bakery is that it is very spacious, making it a cozy place for snack and some reading. It also offers breakfasts for those who become hungry once they smell coffee :)
💸 €5 for a bun.
If you are on the hunt for traditional Danish desserts, Conditori La Glace is the right place! A wide range of cakes, candies, desserts, cookies and an excellent tea collection make La Glace a lovely place to sit, reflect, read a book and enjoy the treat (works only if one arrives before the tourists pour in). I always take Kartoffelkager which is best of all (you can get one of those in Sweet Valentine in Torvehallerne as well).
💸 €11 for a slice of cake.
Juno the bakery is a very mainstream bakery, targeted at tourists. Their cardamon rolls are indeed delicious, but not exceptional or different from Skt. Peders Bageri, Riviera or Flere Fugle. If you are on a curious side and strolling around Østerbro — go for it, but consider the lines in the morning and during lunchtime.
💸 €5 is what you will pay for a bun.
The beloved Copenhagen spot Hart Bageri (there are few around the city) makes the best cheesecake in town (and no one can convince me that it’s not true). Their crispy sourdough bread makes an impression as well.
💸 €14 for a slice of cheesecake and a coffee.
Another must-visit bakery is Andersen Bakery. They make sweets, candies, and desserts of all possible kinds. Here you can also grab a sandwich and sip a coffee in the sun.
💸 €14 for a slice of cheesecake and a coffee.
This is the pastry shop I visit every time I am in Copenhagen. Small, cozy, Leckerbaer reminds me of a doll house with doll-like cookies. It is slightly overpriced but serves as an excellent present.
💸 €19 for an 8-cookie box.
I tried a 5-course menu in Høst in June 2024, and to my disappointment I liked only one of the dishes. Even the surprise treats which Høst generously brought didn’t convince me. The food tasted just fine but not enough for that price.
The beetroot with raspberries and goat cheese had an interesting crispy texture and was quite tasty but the rest disappeared from my taste buds’ memory as soon as I left the restaurant. Considering the opinions on the internet, their pescatarian or meat menu is much better, so if one doesn’t have any preferences, Høst might be considered a place worth trying.
Summary:
🌱 Vegetarian 3 or 5-course menu.⭐ 3/5 for nice treats along the meals.💸 €70 for a menu without wine/ non-alcoholic pairing
If I were to describe Theo in two words, they would be salty and hard. I tried a smaller dish, which were potato gnocchi, and a main course — agnolotti with zucchini, lemon, and riccota. Both were quite similar in taste, and so salty, that it was difficult to taste each of the meal components (I didn't feel the sage at all, even though it has a strong flavour).
Summary:
🌱 A few vegetarian options with one vegetarian main dish.⭐ 2/5 for vegetarian options.💸 €50–70 for a la carte lunch.
A place in Torvehallerne called Il_mattarello serves basic pasta made on spot. The word ‘basic’ perfectly describes the pasta’s flavour, and I can reassure you there are better bistros for a pasta or a quick lunch.
Summary:
🌱 One or two vegetarian pastas.⭐ 2/5 for making their own pasta.💸 €20 for a pasta
Mexican street food chain Hija de Sanchez might provide delicious tacos with pork but tacos with kale were far from good. And I am not talking kale here. The meal was extremely greasy, and oil was almost the only flavour on my tongue.
Summary:
🌱 Vegetarian tacos as the only option.⭐ 2/5 for trying.💸 €15 for a portion of three.
Regarding the bakeries I didn’t like. Albatross & Venner in Torvehallerne left me unimpressed. It is definitely not the place to look for Danish pastries.
Regarding the breakfast eateries I didn’t like. Sonny, Darcy’s Kaffe, and Wulff & Konstali are overpriced and not worth your time. The portions often aren’t big enough and should be called snacks instead.
I am always on the lookout for new places, so this story is being updated on a regular basis :)
--

Title: Copenhagen trip: 5–12Aug
Content:
