Title: Working in 3 Labs Over 5 Weeks in Copenhagen— What I Learned
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In the ninth grade I came across bioplastics, plastics derived from renewable biomass, for the first time. Since then I have spent hundreds of hours researching the space and coming up with an idea for a bioplastic made from duckweed. The thought process was that bioplastics today generally come from biomass like corn, potatoes, sugar cane, etc. but these take up acres of land to grow and need to be consumed by humans (especially with the rise in climate change causing a shortage in food supply). Thus, duckweed, although possessing a bit of an odd name, has been a large focus of mine for two years now.
Shortly after I discovered bioplastics, the CEO of Pond Biomaterials became a mentor of mine. Pond is a startup based out of Denmark and I have been working with them (virtually) for these two years. This summer, though, I finally got to come to Denmark in person and Pond set me up to work in three labs across Copenhagen for five weeks, including Novozymes, the Technical University of Denmark, and the University of Copenhagen.
The reason for three labs instead of just one is that to build this project requires work in many different areas of science, including microbiology, biochemistry, and chemistry.
Below, I will go over what I worked on in each lab as well as my biggest learnings / takeaways.
Novozymes was the first lab I worked in. This is a private company, and the world leader in industrial enzyme production. I had never worked on my project in a lab that was not in a university, so this was a very different experience. I worked closely with Ulla Rosenberg and Kim Borch, two individuals I am incredibly lucky to have met. I always had help in the lab and the support was unreal. My days were usually 9–11 hours long but there was always someone by my side sticking it out with me and it was honestly so much fun.
For the first week I worked on an optimized enzymatic procedure for the duckweed. We experimented with different parameters and got the highest glucose concentrations I have seen out of my duckweed. I learned a lot about enzymes themselves, dilution series, and how to run an assay.
The next few days, I worked on fermenting the sugar solutions where I was in the microbiology lab with Robin Dorau trying to produce lactic acid. Some of the things I learned about were buffering capacities, measuring the optical density of bacteria via a spectrophotometer, and how to ensure the bacteria had enough nutrients. We ended up getting very high lactic acid concentrations, although I also learned about some other compounds present in my mixtures that have led to more discoveries about the duckweed and experiments themselves.
We were working large scale, with hundreds of grams of duckweed, so we had to be innovative with our setups. It doesn’t matter what lab you are working in: you always have to do some improvisation. Here are some examples of us simply having to figure it out:
1.) We had to have our samples stirring at a certain temperature for the enzymes to optimally operate, however our system kept dropping in temperature. In order for the setup to be self sufficient, we improvised and used aluminum and towels for insulation, and poured boiling water into the tub our samples were in. It worked like a charm, but definitely looked a little interesting.
2.) Another scenario where we had to just figure it out was when our samples would not filter prior to fermentation. I have been working on a smaller scale in Ottawa so although filtering was an issue I wasn’t on as much of a time crunch and had less material to work with. What we ended up doing was going to the brewery lab and their pressure filters (used for beer) worked perfectly. This taught me another valuable lesson, which was the importance of interconnectedness and asking others — even if in a completely different space of work — for help. Working at Novozymes was so unique because there are so many individuals working on different things and yet everyone can help each other, even a beer brewery lab and a biotech lab.
One more valuable lesson for me was to not always trust the results you get. When we did colorimetric analysis (basically determining the concentration of a chemical compound using a colour reagent) we got very low lactic acid concentrations which was honestly very disappointing because I never would have expected my results to be in this ball park. Later, though, we ran an HPLC (high performance liquid chromatography, a method that is much more precise) and our results were over 20x higher than we had initially thought. This really changed the next steps that had to be taken, so it’s important to ensure that when doing a test like an assay or something generally less precise (usually because they are easier and cheaper) they can have large margins of error in the results they yield.
The second lab I worked in was at the Technical University of Denmark, DTU. Here I was working on something I had never done before: the separation of lactic acid from the fermentation mixture. This process was quite difficult and was certainly not a success, but I learned a lot about purification technologies and namely, their complexity.
My biggest takeaway was to not underestimate how much time something new can take. I would have figured I would have learned this by now but it’s easy to have too high of expectations in science. Since I had never worked on the purification side of things before, I did not fully comprehend the difficulty of it until I tried it out. Researching and ideating is one thing, and actually doing it is something else entirely! For example, we attempted something called an azeotropic distillation on my first day (see the photo below) which theoretically should have worked quite easily but in fact did not at all. Even removing the water without evaporating other compounds was hugely complex and when I researched what to do, I was greeted with hundreds of research papers.
Thus, I learned something else that was very important which was to keep my solutions as clean as possible. What I mean by this is that in prior steps to the purification I am adding enzymes, buffers, extracts, etc. to my mixtures, but I have to in reality remove everything to get pure lactic acid at the end. When working on prior steps it is very important to keep in mind the end goal and future steps that must also be optimized for.
Another takeaway was to utilize online videos for the use of analytical equipment because there is so much online that can help. I had to be much more independent in this lab, and through a video I learned how to do infrared spectroscopy which was very helpful.
I had a hard time coping with failure at this lab overall but it offered many insights into what comes next in this project, as this step will be the key to producing the bioplastic and will be a challenge on its own.
Finally, I worked at the University of Copenhagen with Peter Ulvskov, a professor in plant biology. This tied more into what I had been working on at Novozymes, but instead of optimizing the enzymes being added to the biomass we were working on what could happen even prior to this: cell wall degradation, mechanical methods of breakdown, etc. Honestly, I found this so much fun and full of learning. I truly got to understand the duckweed to a greater extent, like what exists in it that may inhibit bacterial growth, what polysaccharides it contains, and how the starch granules behave. For the first time I got to look at the duckweed under a microscope — microscopy was actually key in my work at KU. For example, before degradation of the cell walls, we could see the starch granules stuck in the duckweed cells (left image, where the granules are dark blue) and then after we could see the granules released from the cells (right image).
Something else we worked on was the removal of pigmentation from the duckweed to explore how this may hinder future steps in my procedures (see the below picture, where the rightmost beaker contains a much lower content of chlorophyll). I found I was looking at duckweed through a different lens because of how much unique experimentation I got to do at the university.
Likely my biggest takeaway was the significance of writing absolutely everything down and taking many pictures. This is of course something I have always had to do in the lab but Peter put a lot of emphasis on organization and I came up with a much better system for taking notes, keeping track of which photos are which, etc. It can be easy to recognize what a microscopy image is showing a few minutes after you’ve taken it, but a month later, the importance of that image to you may be gone.
My second takeaway was to keep in mind everything that is required for each part of my project and look at how this may translate to a real world protocol. For example, when we were grinding the duckweed we made sure to use equipment that could be scaled up easily as opposed to only something that works small scale.
Another one of my learnings was the importance of going back to the very beginning — the foundations of a project — because this is where the most improvement can transpire. Breaking down the cell walls to a greater extent was not helping me in the purification of the lactic acid, but eventually it could help me get more lactic acid to work with by creating improvements in glucose yields. Every step holds weight.
All in all, getting to spend time in Copenhagen was such a neat experience and I am so grateful to everyone who helped me. I also felt that I became a more independent person as I lived alone for around five days which I have never done before! Getting to meet my supervisor Martin from Pond was a huge highlight, as well as exploring the wonderful city (and the crêpe stands👩🏽‍🍳).
Thank you so much for reading this! I’m a 17-year-old learning about where sustainability meets technology, and am the author of the “Chronicles of Illusions” duology. If you want to see more of my work, connect with me on LinkedIn, Twitter, or subscribe to my newsletter!
--
--

Title: On the hunt: Malene Sabinsky (DNK)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
World’s leading street art platform, connecting artists, photographers, festivals, galleries and cities through urban art. Cities can join our ‘official partnership program’ and showtheir open air gallery to our international audience.
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
Name: Malene Sabinsky
What do you do all day? Boss people around and talk very loudly– no really, that’s what project managers do. *laughs*
Hometown: Copenhagen, Denmark
Hunting territory: Copenhagen and beyond
Can you tell us a bit about the difference between the street art in you town compared to the rest of the world? As in, what makes your town really stand out!? I don’t know if there’s a major difference, as a lot of international artists have made pieces in Copenhagen too, but of course the local artist make it completely unique.
Where do most artists get there inspiration from in your town? That would be unfair of me to answer, as I don’t know.
Is there more currated or illegal work? The murals are mostly curated, but there is also a fair bit of illegal activity
What is that one artwork you need to see in your hunting territory? I have to cheat and choose two: DALeast because I cycle past it everyday, and never tire of looking at it. Copenhagen, for me, wouldn’t be the same without it now. And ‘Creativity is Freedom’ by Danish artist Don John. I really love his work, and there are so many great pieces by him around town.
Who introduced you to the street art scene? Nobody did. I am still waiting for my official introduction :-)
When were you infected with the hunter virus? I’m a newbie really *laughs* I’ve had an interest for at long time. I lived in London for many years, and it’s hard not to notice and appreciate street art when living there. But it didn’t actually become a real (active) passion until summer 2015, when i saw the Surface exhibition by Danish photographer Søren Solkær in Copenhagen. And alongside this, I followed the creation of new murals for “Outdoor Surface” (the DalEast piece being one of these).
My hunting kit includes: It’s a very simple kit: bicycle, iphone, headphones and wind in my hair.
When you are out shooting, how much of it is instinctual versus planned? With increased passion comes increased planning! Of course I still stumble upon new pieces when on general eplorations, but mostly I plan to go to a certain place, because there is something specific I want to see.
Do you take photos more for yourself, or for others? Mostly for myself, but I don’t mind sharing :-)
How would you define your style in taking photo’s or writing a (instagram) post? Lacking style in general! I’m not a skilled photographer, so it’s a good thing the art speaks for itself. The same goes for posts. I’m too impatient to write a lot, so an artist credit and an emoji tends to suffice.
Who are some of your favorite classic photographers, and how did they influence you? I like a lot of photographers: Cindy Sherman, Martin Parr, Nan Goldin, William Eggleston, Andreas Gursky etc. And of course I have to mention both Søren Solkær and Martha Cooper, for combining the art of photography and street art. They haven’t influenced me in any particular way, I just admire their skill and art.
What is your biggest challenge of being a hunter? Too much rain, and too little time.
What is the best piece of advice I can give to newbie hunters? Be curious and open-minded. Credit artists where you can , they deserve it. Do it out of passion and interest, not the likes.
Or ignore all that, and just download the app and get yourself a bicycle.
Can you tell us the most exiting hunter story? Any close calls with getting your equipment robbed or caught by the police? Haha, no close calls at all. I’m too well behaved.
I will share a non-exciting, but vivid hunter memory with you though: I was touring California (and beyond) with my two kids a few months back, and when we stopped over in Vegas, we had to go hunting. I had no connection on my phone, so my son got the job of navigating using the Street Art Cities website (see, it’s so easy even a kid can use it!). After some time with no results, I was getting pretty hot and bothered, but suddenly my son stops and points. And I very loadly exclaim: “Woaw, Martin Whatson”. The look of pride in his eyes for having found it, combined with the beauty of the wall, was just priceless.
My most recent discovery in the street art scene is: Not so recent, but during the summer I found some great stencils in Copenhagen, there are four really close to each other. I haven’t found any more across town, and don’t know anything about the artist, apart from the signature ‘Jochum’. I’m dead curious, really like the pieces, and want to see and know more.
Name a few artists you like to follow and why. These artists are all Danish, have their very own style, are super talented, and can be found around the streets of Copenhagen:
Do you collect art books, T-shirts, and other things? What’s the most valuable item for you? No, I’m not much of a collector as such, but I’m dead chuffed with a small piece by Tankpetrol, I bought and just received in the post the other day.
What is your favorite location fellow hunters should definitely visit? Don’t miss a visit to Bolsjefabrikken where local artist make new pieces all the time, cruise down Rentemestervej — possible the one street in Copenhagen with the mist murals. And of course Christiania — for art and the rest — but don’t pull out your camera on pusher street unless you specifically are collecting “exciting hunter stories”.
What are the benefits you find being part of a street art collective? Having found so many people with the same passion and so many of whom are very knowledgeable, and great photographers. I will start inviting myself for coffee and tours when I travel, so be warned.
Last but not least. What is the most valuable thing about Street Art Cities? The app is fantastic. It’s a great resource when travelling.
--
--

Title: Finding Hygge in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I remember seeing the term Hygge for the first time while looking for Airbnb experiences in Copenhagen. A quick google search showed that Hygge meant “a cozy quality that makes a person feel content and comfortable”. It gave me the image of resting by the fireplace on a cold winter’s night, which didn’t feel too relevant for my upcoming summer trip, so I kind of forgot about it.
When I was in Copenhagen, I remember feeling occasional waves of inner joy, in a “just glad to be here” kind of way. It was otherwise sublime and hard to describe, and even harder to attribute the cause. I didn’t try to analyze it too much — after all, I was on vacation and taking in the idyllic vibes of a Danish summer.
On the metro to the airport, we zoomed past a father and his child running through some grassy expanses with the backdrop of the sea. I remember feeling a sense of delight and ease, and recalled the term Hygge; that’s when I realized I had profoundly learned what it meant during my trip.
I won’t try to describe what Hygge is; I reckon you have to experience this for yourself to understand. But I’ll tell you some things when I was in Copenhagen that brought me Hygge, and also some that did not.
Things that brought Hygge
Things that did not bring Hygge

Title: Learning from best practice — a visit to the Copenhagen Heat Network
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Can London follow Copenhagen's heat networks example?
All London boroughs are working to reach net zero, and decarbonising how we heat our buildings is a crucial part of that journey. One key solution here is the implementation of heat networks. These currently exist in pockets of London, but we must introduce new networks and connect more households to help us towards net zero.
In May, London Councils and The Danish Embassy in London worked together to take a group of London borough officers to visit the Greater Copenhagen area, a world leader in heat networks. The visit was funded by the State of Green (a not-for-profit, public-private partnership between the Danish government and the country’s three leading business associations) and provided valuable insights into Denmark’s successful adoption of heat networks and offered lessons that could be applied to our decarbonisation efforts in London and across the UK.
Denmark has made significant progress in adopting heat networks, with over 64% of Danish homes currently heated through this system. This figure is expected to rise to approximately 72% in the near future. Denmark’s’ heat network journey began in 1903 with the installation of the first district heating (DH) plant.
However, it was the 1970s oil crisis that triggered a rapid expansion in the use of coal-powered district heating, which was followed by the introduction of natural gas. Over time, Denmark has shifted towards incorporating energy from waste and biomass, and is actively exploring various waste heat sources to further reduce emissions — as we know London boroughs like Islington are also doing.
The Greater Copenhagen Heat Network
The Greater Copenhagen Heat Network stands out as an impressive example of a large-scale district heating system. It supplies heat to approximately 500,000 households — with almost all houses connected in the inner municipalities of the region. It relies on various heat producers, including combined heat and power (CHP) plants, waste-to-energy facilities, and reserve and peak load plants burning fossil fuels. The network also incorporates heat storage systems to ensure efficient and reliable distribution.
What did we visit?
During the visit, we had the opportunity to explore different aspects of Denmark’s heat network infrastructure and solutions. We learnt about the background of heat network development in the Greater Copenhagen region and witnessed initiatives such as the District Cooling system in Copenhagen, a large waste-to-energy facility in Roskilde, and the consumer-owned Greve Municipal District Heating company. We also observed smaller-scale innovative solutions, such as a Danfoss project to capture and recirculate heat from supermarket refrigerators in Energy Lab Nordhavn.
We gained insights into energy-renovated social housing and a low-temperature heat network in the Municipality of Albertslund. We also saw an exciting new heat pump system being installed to that extract energy from drinking water in Frederiksberg, in the heart of the city region of Copenhagen.
We learnt about the vital role of local government and municipal companies in planning, financing, developing, and operating heat networks in Denmark. The experience showcased the importance of effective and resourced local government to drive collaboration among stakeholders, all underpinned by strong regulation which gives price certainty to consumers.
We also learnt how heat networks have been expanding rapidly in response to global energy price increases, and that demand is higher for houses on heat networks.
The visit highlighted both some key differences and similarities between Denmark and the UK in terms of how we heat our buildings. However, both countries share similar climates, building characteristics, and ambitions for achieving net-zero emissions so sharing knowledge will help us both. We were happy to learn that the UK government is actively working with the Danish government to develop UK heat network policy, with a focus on introducing heat zoning which will help increase the uptake of heat networks.
This visit to Copenhagen offered valuable insights for London’s decarbonisation efforts. The Renewable Power for London Programme will be incorporating these as part of its Decentralised Energy workstream to help London Local Government accelerate our transition.
Please email Zak Bond at zak.bond@londoncouncils.gov.uk if you’d like to know more about the trip.
Zak Bond — Principal Policy Officer, Climate Change
This Medium space is for London borough officers and London Councils’ climate programmes to share their work on net zero and adaptation. If you wish to contribute by writing a post or have any questions, please get in touch with Katrin Vangelova — Climate Change Communications Officer at katrin.vangelova@londoncouncils.gov.uk.

Title: 5 Must See Places in Copenhagen — The Capital City of Denmark
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Before you actually begin your dream journey, your Copenhagen Trip Planner is here. Copenhagen is the largest city in the country and also the capital of Denmark. Sitting on the two coastal islands, Zealand and Amager, this beautiful city is full of historic attractions. Consulting your vacation guide can be a good option if you do not want to miss any particular places of interests here. Every year a huge number of tourists visit this city which still possesses a distinct touch of European culture. Copenhagen is packed with various great attractions and tourist spots. Here are some of the best places that you can include in your travel planner if you really want to make most of your time here.
Among the various interesting places in the city, including Christiansborg Palace in your Copenhagen Trip Planner as top priority can be a brilliant idea. Located in central Copenhagen, on a small island, this palace is still used by royal families as the seat of Danish Parliament, Prime Minister’s office, and Supreme Court. Boasting more than 800 years of history, this palace has plenty of attractions to offer you, such as the royal reception hall, the Chapel, the Ruins, and the Royal Stables. The tallest viewing platform of the city is in this palace which offers an excellent panoramic view of this beautiful city.
Tivoli Garden is basically an amusement park in Copenhagen and is a must visit for all tourists. Founded in the year of 1843, it is known as an international attraction and also a national treasure of Denmark. With more than twenty types of different rides, various cafes and restaurants, Tivoli Gardens has become an absolute wonderland for the visitors. It is also the second oldest functioning amusement park in Denmark.
Your trips to this Danish capital may remain incomplete if you do not add a visit to the Little Mermaid in your Copenhagen Trip Planner. Made of bronze and granite, this sculpture was a gift to the city from the Danish brewer C. Jacobsen. Apart from being the city’s most famous tourist attraction, it is also the official emblem of the city.
If the history and culture of a new city are something that truly interests you then your journey guide may suggest you visit the National Museum of Denmark. You can find exhibitions from almost all the different periods and ages here. Exhibitions from the Stone Age, the Middle Ages, the Viking Ages, the renaissance period and modern Danish history are perfectly displayed here.
Nyhavn Harbour can also be there in your travel plan. At the very end of the harbor, you can witness the anchor which is kept there as a memorial of those Danish sailors who lost their lives during World War II. With the brightly painted houses by the harbor and the museum ships, this place happens to be the most featured one in the photographs, describing the city.
If you have not yet included Bakken in your Copenhagen Trip Planner, then it’s high time that you would. Being the oldest amusement park in the world, Bakken is a wonderful green area where you can enjoy various exciting adventure rides. In the entire Scandinavia, it is the only amusement park that has more rides than any other in the country.
By including these most-visited places of Copenhagen in your vacation plan, you can have the most unforgettable experience in your life. Let’s keep your Copenhagen Trip Planner with you as your best guide and start exploring the majestic city Copenhagen.

There’s a particular kind of focus that lives in voiceover. Not just technical — emotional, too.
As an actor, I’ve found something grounding in the simplicity of sound: a way to stay close to character, even between larger productions. Whether for narration, commercials, or more character-driven work, I approach VO as an extension of acting, just pared down to its essentials.

Title: A Tale of Three Cities
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Japonica: the publication for everything Japan: culture, life, business, language, travel, food, and everything else.

Member-only story
--
1
Share
I’m a New York City girl.
I grew up in the neighborhood of Washington Heights, the area of Manhattan north of Harlem.
On the street I lived, everyone knew everyone. Apartment doors were often left open so kids could run back and forth. If we were out late —which meant once the streetlights were on — we’d be told by an adult, any adult, it was time to go home.
Home for me was on the fifth floor of a tenement building. And our apartment stood out in that drab building because our windows were covered with climbing blue morning glory my father planted every spring.
Those flowers were a bright spot on an otherwise colorless city street.
It’s years since we were back, and this summer it was a trip down memory lane when my husband Billy and I visited “the City”.
Billy grew up in Greenwich Village. Long the home of artists, his father, the abstract expressionist painter Harold Anton, had among his contemporaries, Jackson Pollock, as well as the…

Title: Israels Plads, Copenhagen: A study in successful public spaces
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
ISRAELS PLADS
Copenhagen, Denmark
Introduction
Israels Plads is an urban plaza situated in Copenhagen, Denmark. It was conceptualised by Sweco Architects and Cobe in 2007 when the Copenhagen municipality invited Danish architects to reconstruct Copenhagen’s largest public square, which had fallen into disrepair as a derelict parking lot. [1] This essay will analyse the aftermath of the project to determine how successful the architects were in terms of heritage integration, user experience, and inclusivity.
Copenhagen is the capital and most populous city of Denmark. It was previously a Viking fishing village, and became the capital in the early 15th century. Since the early 2000’s Copenhagen has seen some strong urban and cultural development, led by the Copenhagen Municipality, through investments in its institutions and infrastructure. Israels Plads is one such urban regeneration project.
According to Cobe, the idea of transforming Israels Plads was to celebrate the significance of the history of the square, and to revitalize it, by turning it into a “vibrant, diverse plaza for leisure and sport, used by all kinds of people.” [7] Right from the get-go, we see that the architects placed a lot of importance on heritage integration, user experience and inclusivity.
The new site consists of an underground car park, with two blocks of buildings (a retail park and a private educational institute) to the North-West and South-East, along with two large market halls (“Torvehallerne”, which opened in 2011 and quickly became very popular, currently housing numerous cafés) to the North-East. The Plads also provides a link to a massive park (“Ørstedsparken”) to the South-West (Fig 1), acting as a transition from the bustling city to the serene park. [7]
Figure 1 Israels Plads seen as an urban carpet (Cobe, 2014) Edited by author
Above the underground car park, the plaza acts as a multifunction space, housing a large playground, sports arena, skatepark, and areas for people-watching. At the centre of the square is an “egg-shaped area” (Fig 2), used by nearby schools as an extended recreational zone for all age groups. [2]
Figure 2: Landscaping Plan of the Site (Cobe, 2014) Edited by author
History
The space has historical significance dating back to the 13th century when Denmark built their stone wall fortifications and established a central plaza at this spot, where the city ended in a ring of protective ramparts. During the city’s extension in the late 19th century, with the demolition of the old city walls (that were now outdated defence mechanisms), the site became a vibrant market square. Israels Plads is placed on top of these historic ramparts (Fig 3).
Figure 3 Diagram of the city’s old fortifications, and Israels Plads’ location relative to the ramparts (Cobe, 2014)
According to Zerlang (2008), the square served as a starting point and meeting point for the forces of modern life [1], since its inception in the 1870s (Fig 4) and its renaming in 1968 as “Israels Plads”, to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the “rescue of the Danish Jews”.[3]
Israels Plads was previously the home of Grønttorvet (1889–1958), a major market for fresh produce known for its special atmosphere (Fig 5). Due to the increase in traffic around the market and growing logistics needs, the market was relocated and the once-bustling square degenerated into an inner-city eyesore and occasional parking lot (Fig 6). [2]
Figure 4: The site being used as a market in 1889–1954
Figure 5: The Food Market, around 1990 (Copenhagen by Design, 2015)
“The plaza used to be empty, especially in the evening, and there were a lot of drug dealers” — Hans Peter Hagens (Architect of the Torvehallerne, adjacent to Israels Plads) [13]
Figure 6: The site’s usage as a parking lot in the 1950’s — 1990's
City Scale
The main reason for the decline of Israels Plads was the city and traffic planners’ inability and unwillingness to put city space and city life high on their agenda. Attempting to ensure the best conditions for car traffic, along with the mismanagement of the city-planning sector has led to multiple public squares such as this one being converted to dingy parking lots, teeming with crime and making the city unsafe, unsustainable and unhealthy. [4]
Jan Gehl, in his book “Cities for People”, criticises the Copenhagen municipality, for putting a low priority on public space, pedestrianism and the role of city space as a meeting place for urban dwellers. However, in recent decades, the government has realised its folly, and started reversing its erroneous moves by restructuring their street network, removing driving lanes and parking places in a deliberate process to create better and safer conditions for bicycle traffic. [4] The city of Copenhagen has a goal for its residents to “spend 20% more time in public spaces by 2025,” [7] and Copenhagen’s bicycles now save 90,000 tons of CO2 every year. Gehl notes that “[Copenhagen] has significantly improved conditions for life in city space in recent decades. Pedestrian traffic has grown, and the number of recreational optional activities has swelled.” [4] It is important to note that Gehl uses the term “optional” to describe activities that can only be done in good conditions, as opposed to “necessary” activities, such as going to school/work and grocery shopping, which have to be done regardless of the weather conditions. One by one the parking places in the city centre have been turned into squares that accommodate public life. [4]
Figure 7: The new and improved Israels Plads (Cobe, 2014)
Recent Developments
A change was triggered in the area of Israels Plads, due to the decision to erect the two market halls (Torvehallerne) on the site, evoking the “aura of the old vegetable market”. [2] The council’s brief for the reconstruction of Israels Plads demanded that the design concept should relate itself to the “history of the square, to the architecture of the surrounding houses, to the Ørstedspark at the southern end of the square and the Botanical Garden and the market halls at the northern end of the square”. [1]
The winning submission by Cobe and Sweco Architects envisaged a “flying carpet” spread across the entire square, where the cars would be “swept under the rug” with underground parking and organically shaped areas that are punched out of the surface to provide a variety of public recreational functions (Fig 7 and 8). [2]
Figure 8: The layers of Israels Plads, as envisioned by Sweco Architects and Cobe (Cobe, 2014)
User Experience
Zerlang (2008) declares that in the modern city, experiences are staged, and architects increasingly treat urban space with the eye of a scenographer. [1] Understanding that the consideration for the individual and their experiences presents a major challenge for modern urban planning, the question of “experiences” had a very high priority in the commission. The Council added a demand that the concept should consider the activities on the square, and also the pre-existing activities of the school children from the Zahles Skole (adjacent to Israels Plads), and the potential activities of the new-arranged square. [1]
The transformation of the public square focuses on its revitalisation as a living urban space [2]. Gehl (2010) urged urban planners and architects to reinforce pedestrianism as an integrated city policy to develop “lively, safe, sustainable and healthy” cities. He also ascertains that it is equally urgent to strengthen the social function of city space as a meeting place. [4]
Israels Plads provides a cohesive structure that offers “short walking distances, attractive public spaces, and a variation of urban functions”. These elements increase activity and the feeling of security in and around the space. [4]
Studies from inner-city shopping streets in Copenhagen show happenings, events and building sites where we can watch people perform, play music, etc. attract far more people to linger and watch than shops along building facades. Studies of benches and chairs in city space show correspondingly that seats with the best view of city life are used far more frequently than those that do not offer a view of other people. [4] The seating areas in Israels Plads are positioned so that people-watching is facilitated. The sloping sides of the sunken playing field can serve both as a barrier and as seating. [2] Wedge-shaped staircases at the western and eastern corners of the square offer a good view from an elevated position (Fig 9). [2]
Figure 9: Users seated on the wedge-shaped stairs, enjoying a sunny day (Cobe, 2014)
“The plaza has opened up to the historical landscape next door. The tree and water elements of the park are echoed on the plaza surface, and circles have been cut out to accentuate the big trees standing on the transition between city and park” (Fig 10) [7]
Figure 10: The cutouts on the plaza used to accentuate the trees. (Copenhagen Design News, 2020)
The cut-outs feature round bench formations underneath the trees, where people can observe the life unfolding on the plaza, a pre-requisite for Gehl’s ideal public space (Fig 11). The localised light zones of areas sheltered by trees also create an intimate setting for groups of people to gather and enjoy the night. The overheads and multiple sources of illumination, according to Schaack (2018), allow for visibility and facial recognition, which is crucial for users to trust their environment and the people using it. [3]
Figure 11: Round bench formations, ideal for people-watching (Copenhagen Design News, 2020)
Cobe’s founder, Dan Stubbergaard appreciates that Israels Plads has become a public meeting place and a playground for three different schools all year round. [7] It also helps that the design incorporates skateable aspects into the architecture of the space. Activities such as skateboarding, basketball and scootering are encouraged, which invites a lot more schoolchildren into the space. [11] Even the lighting is optimised for play. Four different lighting systems illustrate the complexity of the space at night. One of them illuminates the centre of the plaza to answer the need for visibility of sports users, basketball players and skateboarders. [3]
Figure 12: The public uses the Plads even in unfavourable weather conditions (Cobe, 2014)
Heritage Integration
“[The plaza] has a sculptural expression that refers to its historical past as part of the fortifications” [3] “Along the facades, a band of traditional Copenhagen pavement with granite slabs and Nordic cobblestones runs around the square (Fig 13), connecting the granite plate to its surroundings.” [8] These material choices are a throwback to traditional Danish building methods, and also match the colourful historical facades from the 18th century.
Figure 13: Nordic cobblestones and demarcation strips around Israels Plads (Copenhagen Design News, 2020)
The square itself often became the scene of political demonstrations in the 1880s [1] Similar to the 1880s, the square is still used for political demonstrations. In May 2019, the Revolutionary Antifascists group, organised a demonstration at the Israels Plads. [9] More recently, in October 2021, students of the University of Copenhagen assembled at the Plads to protest the University’s investment in Pro-Israeli companies that are involved in the demolition of Palestinian homes and building the Apartheid wall [10]. It is interesting to see how the Israels Plads’ usage has differed only very slightly from its original uses before the 1950s. Copenhagen also hosts WorldPride, the international festival celebrating the LGBTQ+ community, and one of the parades goes through the Israels Plads. [12]
Inclusivity
“This is where children play during recess, where friends meet for a beer after work, and where Copenhageners meet for flea markets (Fig 14) on Saturdays” [7]
Figure 14: The Flea Market that opens up on the Plads on Saturdays (Cobe, 2014)
An issue that I came across quite often when researching the inclusivity of such spaces, is the prevalence of anti-homeless architecture and exclusionary design, whether on purpose or a subconscious choice. A space such as this cannot be celebrated for its inclusivity, if it does not support ALL its citizens, including the homeless, individuals struggling with addiction, and the unemployed. Israels Plads has round benches with metal dividers (Fig 11), making them uncomfortable to sleep on, while the long tiered seating (Fig 9) lacks privacy and is open to the elements, which discourages anyone from taking refuge overnight. [15]
This goes against the policies of Jan Gehl’s “Humanist City” [4], pushing Copenhagen’s most vulnerable citizens out of the public space. Nina Hoegh (Director of Projekt Udenfor (Project Outside)) agrees, stating that catering urban design exclusively to the needs of the middle class in this way sends an implicit message about whom the city values. [15] Public space should be accessible and welcoming for all, without privileging one person or group over another. [16]
“Homelessness must be eradicated, but this process won’t happen overnight. Public places need to design for this reality, not ignore it” [16] Therefore I affirm that the architects of the Israels Plads have not been successful in their efforts to make the space inclusive.
Purpose Fulfilment
The architects have designed a method of directing cloudburst water into an artificial creek, which leads to a large water reserve in the adjacent park. However, their wish that the creek is an aesthetic and pleasant water feature during all other times did not come true, as the “creek” is almost always dry (Fig 15), and may be a hazard for a skateboarding student, or a person with a vision impairment. [7] The Danish Design Review also noted that the fountains and water channel at the park end are rarely running. [14]
Figure 15: The “Artifical Creek”, currently dry (Copenhagen by Design, 2015)
Despite its shortcomings, the plaza does serve as a new public space adding to the social and environment of Copenhagen, while fulfilling the still-existing demand for car parking in the city. The design of the space follows the policy of Copenhagen to be a sustainable and user-friendly city by connecting to the neighbouring park and food market, offering a recreational space with seating areas and sports facilities. [3] Israels Plads has accomplished its goal of being a multi-use space, seeing that it serves as a schoolyard during the daytime, a public basketball court and skate park during the afternoon, a “dining room” in the evening, and a flea market during the weekend. It is quite difficult to design a space where there is minimum clash between these activities, yet Cobe and Sweco Architects have managed to do it.
Figure 16: A Google Earth capture of the site by the author
Some of these new and old car-free squares seem deserted while others teem with life. The difference comes down to the fact that some squares have only been designed to “ferry” pedestrians across, while others seize the opportunity to provide an experience, so that people combine walking and staying in the area. Studies show that the latter type of square registers an activity level of between “10, 20, and sometimes 30 times higher than transit squares” [5] There is no point in having a sheer amount of space if it is not correctly designed, and this is why I believe Israels Plads has been so successful in attracting the populace of Copenhagen as a public space where children can play, adults can people-watch, and almost everyone can enjoy.
BIBLIOGRAPHY
[1] Zerlang, M. 2008. Experiencing Israels Plads. Nordic Journal of Architectural Research. 20(1), pp. 53–61.
[2] Hermman, E., Hofmeister, S. and Schoof, J., 2021. 2 Israels Plads Cobe, Sweco Architects. Urban Architecture and Public Spaces. pp. 36–45.
[3] Schaack, V. 2018. Improving light for the night. Thesis (MA) Aalborg University, Copenhagen. pp.37–41.
[4] Gehl, J. 2010. Cities for People. Washington DC: Island Press.
[5] Peñalosa, E. 2004. A Dramatic Change Towards a People City — the Bogota Story . (Keynote Address). Ed. Walk 21 — V Cities For People, 9–11 June 2004. Copenhagen, Denmark. Unpublished.
[6] Whyte, W.H. 1980. The Social Life of Small Urban Spaces. Washington DC: Conservation Foundation.
[7] Cobe. 2014. Copenhagen’s Urban Carpet [ONLINE]. Available from: https://cobe.dk/place/israels-plads [Accessed 01 January 2022]
[8] Le Goffic, V.C., 2015. Israels Plads: Between Park and Market. Topos Magazine, 91.
[9] The Local. 2019. Eight arrested during May 1st demo in Copenhagen. The Local [ONLINE]. 1 May. Available from: https://www.thelocal.com/20190501/two-arrested-during-may-1st-demo-in-copenhagen/ [Accessed 01 January 2022]
[10] Arbejderen, 2021. The University of Copenhagen has invested over two million in companies in the West Bank. Arbejderen [ONLINE]. 22 September. Available from: https://arbejderen.dk/udland/koebenhavns-universitet-har-investeret-21-millioner-i-firmaer-paa-vestbredden/ [Accessed 01 January 2022]
[11] Mersom, D. 2015. Bristol skateboarders take on ‘skatestopper’ defensive architecture. The Guardian [ONLINE] 7 October. Available from: https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2015/oct/07/bristol-skateboarders-skatestoppers-defensive-architecture [Accessed 01 January 2022]
[12] The Local. 2021. What’s happening for the grand finale of Copenhagen’s WorldPride Festival? The Local [ONLINE]. 20 August. Available from: https://www.thelocal.dk/20210820/whats-happening-on-the-last-day-of-worldpride-in-copenhagen-on-saturday/ [Accessed 01 January 2022]
[13] Sherwood, S. 2011. An Open Invitation to Eat in Copenhagen. The New York Times [ONLINE]. 30 September. Available from: https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/02/travel/torvehallerne-is-culinary-hot-spot-in-copenhagen.html [Accessed 01 January 2022]
[14] Copenhagen Design News. 2020. Israels Plads. Danish Design Review [ONLINE] 15 July. Available from: http://danishdesignreview.com/kbhnotes/2020/8/26/israels-plads [Accessed 01 January 2022]
[15] Rutkowski, L. 2015. Designing Homelessness Away. The Murmur [ONLINE] 22 June. Available from: http://murmur.dk/designing-homelessness-away/ [Accessed 02 January 2022]
[16] Huttenhoff, M., 2021. Coexistence in Public Space. San Francisco: SPUR and Gehl.
IMAGES:
Fig 1: Cobe, 2014. Copenhagen’s Urban Carpet [Online]. Copenhagen: Cobe. Available from https://cobe.dk/imagecache/images/ansel_high_qual/1623/050_cobe_israel_plads_diagram-5cc8302d8ea0f_8bbcfeb7b41ac2ed88f315b213dc76aa.jpg [Accessed 1 January 2022]
Fig 2: Cobe, 2014. Copenhagen’s Urban Carpet [Online]. Copenhagen: Cobe. Available from https://cobe.dk/imagecache/images/ansel_high_qual/1653/110_cobe_israel_plads_diagram-5cc830522c172_8bbcfeb7b41ac2ed88f315b213dc76aa.jpg [Accessed 1 January 2022]
Fig 3: Cobe, 2014. Copenhagen’s Urban Carpet [Online]. Copenhagen: Cobe. Available from https://cobe.dk/imagecache/images/ansel_high_qual/10382/111_cobe_israel_plads_diagram-5df3660649050_8bbcfeb7b41ac2ed88f315b213dc76aa.jpg [Accessed 1 January 2022]
Fig 4: Hjortshøj, R. Copenhagen’s Urban Carpet — 2014 [Online]. Copenhagen: Cobe. Available from https://cobe.dk/imagecache/images/ansel_high_qual/14653/030_cobe_israel_plads_history-5eff36fb90243_3f24588191c40721b5c4a2f0507101e1.jpg [Accessed 1 January 2022]
Fig 5: Copenhagen by Design. 2015. Israels Plads [ONLINE] Copenhagen: Copenhagen by Design. Available from: https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/532b4471e4b0ed181e218367/1424208594556-YMBVKAFBC6LYPOEQ5L54/image-asset.jpeg?format=750w [Accessed 01 January 2022]
Fig 6: Hjortshøj, R. Copenhagen’s Urban Carpet — 2014 [Online]. Copenhagen: Cobe. Available from https://cobe.dk/imagecache/images/ansel_high_qual/14657/041_cobe_israel_plads_history-5eff36fcc6355_3f24588191c40721b5c4a2f0507101e1.jpg [Accessed 1 January 2022]
Fig 7: Hjortshøj, R. Copenhagen’s Urban Carpet — 2014 [Online]. Copenhagen: Cobe. Available from https://cobe.dk/imagecache/images/ansel_high_qual/1629/060_cobe_israel_plads_exterior-5cc830465946e_71318731b48aacf0a18965ad7e07d9f2.jpg [Accessed 1 January 2022]

Let me start by saying, I'm a huge fan of the S-train network in Copenhagen, Denmark, and especially for the simple and direct communication the transit map of the network provides. The design of the existing map is clean and simple. But it still has in my opinion some flaws and are missing some vital details.
So I have tried to make my own revised S-train map for Copenhagen, based of course on the existing map of the network. With tweaks and improvement to make it easier to navigate as a user.
Just want to see the new map, jump straight to it here.
If you want an in-depth analysis and understanding of the Copenhagen transit map and network and what it looks like today:

Title: Copenhagen: The Best City I’ve Visited So Far
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Copenhagen surprised me in the best way. It’s not loud or flashy, but quietly brilliant — measured, functional, and full of life in subtle ways. It might not be for everyone, but for me personally, this was the best city I’ve visited so far.
Here’s a breakdown of my impressions, what’s worth seeing, and what (and where) to eat.
Copenhagen feels like it was designed for a self-contained urban human — someone who values clean lines, efficient systems, and doesn’t need the sun to be in their top three happiness factors.
It’s expensive, but everything you get feels fair. There’s no sense of being ripped off — just a steady, Nordic standard of quality. English is almost a second official language, spoken equally well by both the young and the old. That stood out and made everything smoother.
The people are polite, helpful, but emotionally reserved. Not cold, not snobby — just calmly distant. The city itself is beautifully quiet: no diesel engines, no honking, no chaos. Cash is barely accepted, tips are not expected, and digital payments are the norm.
Public transport is flawless — fast, clean, reliable, and not overcrowded. The metro system especially impressed me. The cycling culture is on another level: wide, protected bike lanes on both sides of the street, and visibly fewer cars and parking spots than in Zagreb.
It’s not as immigrant-friendly as, say, London, and that affects the atmosphere slightly. Still, Copenhagen delivers a kind of living standard and order that’s rare anywhere else.
Home of CarlsbergMore than just a brewery tour. This place ties together Danish beer, scientific progress, and art collecting. Jacob and Carl Jacobsen — father and son — are the central figures here. The father was a master brewer, the son added branding finesse and a love of the arts. They even established their own science lab, where in 1883 they solved the problem of “beer sickness” (a sudden souring of beer) by isolating pure yeast. Today, they’ve created a keg that triples shelf life. The visit includes a tour and beer tastings.
GlyptoteketA stunning museum founded by the Jacobsen family, housing collections of Greek, Roman, Egyptian, Danish, and French art. My favorites were the sarcophagi, the mummies, and The Prodigal Son sculpture. The building itself is a piece of art.
Tivoli GardensThe second-oldest amusement park in the world and the inspiration for Disneyland. It’s charming and atmospheric, though pricey. I took my first and probably last rollercoaster ride here. Worth it for the vibe alone.
Danish Design MuseumDesign is taken seriously here — from childhood education to everyday product aesthetics. We saw an exhibition on the development of Irma, a 137-year-old supermarket brand that brought graphic design into daily life. Another focused on natural, innovative materials (chairs from mushrooms, lamps made from cow intestines, dresses from milk-industry waste). Unfortunately, the furniture design exhibit was closed for renovations.
NyhavnA classic Copenhagen postcard: colorful houses along a canal, boats bobbing in the water. It’s a bit of a tourist trap, but still worth seeing — especially if the sun comes out. HC Andersen once lived in one of these houses while writing his first fairy tale.
Freetown ChristianiaA self-declared autonomous neighborhood built on former military land. Around 1,000 people live there — hippies, artists, and others drawn to alternative living. It’s more a sociological curiosity than an actual utopia. Don’t expect magic, but it’s interesting for a short visit.
Rosenborg Castle & KastelletRosenborg is a small Renaissance castle built by Christian IV in the early 1600s. It’s beautifully preserved. Nearby, Kastellet is a pentagon-shaped military fortress, still in use today and perfect for a peaceful stroll.
Food in Copenhagen is pricey. Meals range from 110 to 250 DKK (€15–€34), pastries from 40 DKK (€5.50), and craft beers between 60–80 DKK (€8–€11). But the quality makes it worthwhile.
Here’s what stood out:
Gasoline GrillNamed one of the top 27 burgers in the world by Bloomberg — and the only one from Europe. It’s served from a small former gas station with four cheerful employees. Probably the best burger I’ve ever had.
Juno the BakeryThe cardamom bun here genuinely moved people to tears. The founder is a former Noma chef, and it shows. The almond croissant and pain au chocolat are also top-tier.
Format Café (inside the Design Museum)New Nordic simplicity done right. The carrot soup with tarragon oil, cream, almonds, and sourdough was exceptional. The open sandwich with chicken, beetroot, capers, kale, horseradish, and a mystery cream was surprisingly rich and complex. Easily one of the best meals.
SeksA stylish brunch spot. The chive-and-pepper omelet was solid, the apple pancake with cream excellent, and the Moroccan green tea unforgettable. Small portions, though.
Warpigs BrewpubTexas BBQ in a Danish setting. Three meats (smoked pork, beef, spicy sausage), mac & cheese, beans, slaw, and on-site craft beer. Heavy, indulgent, and very American in vibe — but worth it.
Broens Street Food MarketGreat spot on the docks. We had organic fish & chips with an IPA under the sun. Simple, fresh, satisfying.
Sankt Peders BakeryThe oldest bakery in Copenhagen, open since 1652. Try the Wednesday cinnamon roll — sold only on Wednesdays. They make up to 4,000 in a single day.
Absalon FolkehusetA unique community lunch in a converted Lutheran church. We had rice with spinach, almonds, coriander, and a peppery sauce. At just 60 DKK, it was the cheapest cooked meal we found — and still delicious.
Pølser Hot DogsThe Danish street food staple. Tried two: one at Carlsberg and one at John’s Hotdog Deli at the main station (Bourdain-approved). Both were solid, nothing mind-blowing.
GRØDA porridge-focused mini-chain. The classic version with apples, cinnamon, roasted almonds, and caramel was pure comfort food.
Pico PizzaStandard, good pizza. Clean, consistent, and just what you need after a few fancier meals.
Copenhagen isn’t trying to win you over with flash or charm. It doesn’t need to. It simply works — quietly, confidently, and beautifully. It’s a place that respects both the individual and the collective experience. For someone who appreciates subtle details, structure, and thoughtful living, this city delivers on every level.
Without exaggeration, this is the best city I’ve ever visited — but I’d never move there, unless the sun files for residency too. 😆
--

Title: Paul Anderton | HR Manager Leadership Development, UNDP Copenhagen, Denmark
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Welcome to the United Nations Career Journey podcast where we interview colleagues working for the United Nations all over the world. Our conversations explore their fascinating career paths, what career satisfaction means to them and how they keep learning and developing on the job. My name is Alessia and our conversation today is with Paul Anderton from the United Nations Development Programme in Copenhagen in Denmark.
Welcome to the Career Journey Podcast, Paul, thank you very much for joining us. And it’s a pleasure to have you as our guest speaker today. Would you like to introduce yourself?
Hello there Alessia. Greetings, everyone. Yes, certainly. Thanks so much for having me. My name is Paul Anderton. I’m originally from the United Kingdom, but I’ve lived and worked in 11 different countries in my life now, including the last three years here in Denmark in Copenhagen. I am an international servant, international civil servant with the UNDP. As you just mentioned, I work as an HR manager for the Leadership Development team in the Office of Human Resources, in the UNDP’s Talent Development Unit. That would do is as a starting point. So back to you, Alessia.
Yes, thank you, Paul. That’s really interesting that you lived in 11 different countries. And so how did you become interested in this field?
I think when I go back and look at the course of my life, something fairly major changed for me when I was nine years old, when I moved from a small village where I was living in England, a small village that had more sheep than than people actually, that was very homogeneous. And because of my father’s work, we moved to Brussels in Belgium, one of the most international cities in Europe. I went to an international school, and all of a sudden, I went from going to a small rural primary school to a big international school, where I was sitting next to a boy from Tanzania, and a girl from Venezuela, and a boy from Bangladesh and a girl from Japan. And that really had an impact on me at that young age, and really made me interested both in travelling the world and seeing other places, learning, made me intensely curious about the world. And also made me passionate about the feeling of connectedness, the feeling that all of these different people in all different cultures around the world, we are all interdependent, and that an organisation like the United Nations really has an important role to play. And eventually that will be something that I will be able to, to contribute to. So, I guess that kind of international perspective was something that was influencing me from quite a young age, which I maybe didn’t realize so much at the time. But when I look at the kind of the path that my life took, both in terms of the places I ended up working, which includes Japan, and Zambia, Mexico, Nepal, I feel very lucky, very grateful for the possibilities that opened up for me to, to go to these kinds of places have an international career. And, you know, try to make the most of that, including my time here at UNDP.
Wow, thank you, Paul. That’s a really interesting story. I also went to an international school in my life here in Rome, and I do completely understand you when you say that you were sitting next to someone from Japan, someone from Bangladesh, I also had that experience. And it definitely gave me a bigger perspective of things of my life as well. So what does a typical day or week look like for you in this job?
So yeah, so maybe I should talk a bit more about what my job actually is. So as the manager of the leadership development team at UNDP, we’re overseeing all of the internal learning and development opportunities for UNDP’s leaders at all levels, and people managers, and that covers quite a wide range of of activities and programmes that we’re doing - obviously, a lot of online content, but also organising things like retreats, meetings and get-togethers. I would say that the one thing when we talk about a typical week is there is no such thing. There’s constantly different things that are being worked on, different projects, different initiatives. We have a really substantial work portfolio that we work towards with all the different leadership groups within UNDP. That’s Resident Representatives, whether it’s team leaders in country offices, keeping all those going while at the same time, UNDP is never shy to say okay, here’s a priority that we now need to give to you, whether that might be a Women’s Leadership Programme, or something related, due to inclusion of people with disabilities, so that variety is fascinating. The other thing that I think is absolutely essential for doing the job that I do is the kind of the communication and delegation with my team. So I’d say that the anchors are, in this, pretty variable and changing work schedule, the anchors are the regular team meetings, and one-on-one meetings I have with my team meetings. We have a distributed team, so we have a couple of people working with us here in Copenhagen, others who are located in other time zones and other parts of the world. And so therefore, it’s really important for us to have regular check-ins, to get on the same page in terms of what the work priorities are, who is doing what, who’s accountable for what, and I very much enjoy that part of the role as well, the people management, the getting to know other people. I found that the United Nations and UNDP in particular is a fascinating workplace, the people who work here are really interesting, have all kinds of fascinating stories. And I find that the best way that that we can kind of come and work together is to share those components of ourselves with each other that we’re most passionate about. That really elevates the team as a whole, and gets us motivated, even when we might be overwhelmed with a certain project or feeling tired, because we do we do have a lot of responsibility and a lot to do.
Okay, thank you. Wow, that was very descriptive and very useful for our listeners. And so what specific tools have been useful for you to develop career wise?
So in terms of tools, I was thinking, it’s in my career, it’s probably been less about kind of technical training or specific certification, so to speak, and more about kind of mindset and approach. So I think that some of the things in my career as a whole that have really helped me get to the point I am today includes things like agility, so being able to move from one thing to another, having, I guess, the self confidence that if I’m trying something that’s new to me that I can kind of fall back on the core skill set that I’ve kind of built up over time to get me through that, as well as the network of colleagues and others who can help me either with information or tips, mentor me through certain things to get me somewhere else. And when I was thinking about the idea of a career journey, my career — I don’t usually think of it in those terms, because it hasn’t ever really been kind of mapped out or planned to any great degree. The basic philosophy has been on my approach has been to be open to the opportunities that have come my way trying to follow my passions, which as I mentioned, have been around travel or around being an international civil servant. Also about international development work, that’s what my master’s degree is in, and I spent several years working as a development project manager and humanitarian worker before shifting more to an HQ role at UNDP. And that’s kind of incorporated some of the other skills and I guess, the different job titles that I’ve had over the years, all of those things have contributed different bits of pieces into the professional that I currently am. So I mentioned working in humanitarian worker in Zambia, Uganda in the past, but over time, I’ve also been a teacher, the university lecturer I’ve even though the short term jobs that I’ve had, whether that’s volunteering, I’ve done quite a bit of volunteering my life particularly with with refugees with the Red Cross, an International Rescue Committee, but also part time jobs as you know, things like a driver, a librarian, even a movie projectionist back in the day… All of these things have, you know, added little components into both my kind of my bank of experiences and skills, and also the way that I go about my job. So I mentioned kind of agility and moving from, from one thing to the next thing. Curiosity is also something that has been really important for my career, because that has meant that I have looked to keep growing and taking on different challenges, expanding the repertoire of things that I can do or will go put my hand up to take on. And in our team, the Talent Development Team here at UNDP, we often talk about the growth mindset, the idea that we’re constantly growing, we’re constantly evolving, we’re all on a continuous learning journey, where it’s not the case that — okay, after school in university, that’s it, your learning is done and you put it away. That’s not the way the world works. It’s not the way that work itself works. So, so that curiosity, agility, the growth mindset to keep trying new things. And I think, also important has been a willingness to take a few risks along the way. I kind of mentioned growing up in a small village in England, when I was young, I was pretty shy, I was not that confident. And I wouldn’t have dreamed, actually, that I would have taken on as many different things as I have done over the course of my life, taking chances to go and study for a year in the USA, where I didn’t know anyone, taking a first job after university in in Taiwan, part of the world where I didn’t speak the language, I didn’t know anyone, I have no idea what to expect. But it was a part of this…this kind of growth experience, and, led in all kinds of interesting directions.
Wow, that was really inspiring. I feel very inspired by that. Especially follow your passion. I feel like nowadays, it’s getting very competitive now, when you are in the search for jobs, but I do agree, follow your passion, agility, take risks, everything you mentioned. It’s nice to hear it once in a while. I feel like some people tend to forget, because of a lot of pressure in this in this environment with the job searching and stuff, especially after the pandemic, when you graduate as a student.
And I have to say as well, I can kind… in looking back, you tend to look at the highlights. There were plenty of lowlights along the way and plenty of moments of ‘oh my god, what is my next job gonna be’ or ‘what happens next’. And particularly when I think about my UN career, I’ve had every variety of contract there is, including being a pro bono volunteer, part time consultant, full time consultant, temporary appointment. I eventually got to a fixed term appointment, that was then abolished as opposed to, so went back not to having a post. I’ve gone through a team relocation, so all of these things are also happening, as well as along the way moments of great uncertainty about what what is the right thing to do? And where, where should I be, where should I be moving? And I do kind of see, not not just my career, but for all of us, our lives are a little bit in… in chapters that are being written as we go. And when you kind of look back at some of the completed chapters, it’s only then you can kind of see how everything came together. And I do sense that the moment that kind of the uncertainty and the questions that particularly young people have about, okay, what is our future going to look like? What kind of jobs am I going to have? What do I think about far from my career? It’s getting more and more challenging. And I think about that, in particular for for my daughters who are eleven and nine, so they still have a ways to go in their own education, but say, in 15/20 years from now, what the job market so to speak might look like is really hard to see. The speed at which the types of jobs that people are doing, or the jobs that people have, they’re just changing so rapidly. And that I think takes me back a little bit to what I was saying about being agile, being willing to change, and trying to build up your self-confidence that actually no, I will, be able to ride these waves and get someway good. And of course it helps a great deal ifunderneath that, the work that you’re doing or the place that you’re working connects to what you’re most passionate about.
Yes, yes, exactly. I agree with you. Overall, everything does move pretty fast, especially the market right now. But we’ll see, I guess, c’est la vie.
I think taking time to kind of really analyze and understand that for yourself. One thing I see that sometimes trips people up is that they might have certain expectations about what they think the world of work should be, or they joined a particular organisation and they have a certain idea — this is exactly what is gonna happen when I get there — And then maybe that’s not quite the reality. So I think the more research you can do, or the more analysis or reflection you can do, both in terms of the work and the job that you’re going into but also in terms of yourself and what you need or what you want to have in your career, that’s really going to help so. So take some time for self-reflection for analysis, and it might be that you see certain jobs where you think okay, well the job looks good, but actually, I’m not sure I fit in that organisation or vice versa, that’s an organisation I want to work for. But is that what they want to be doing? It’s not straightforward at all. And yeah, it’s something that yeah, I myself, I’m still in the middle of. You know, I’m mid career, I’ve probably got 15/20 years to go until until I’d be able to retire. So I’m also surfing the wave.
Yeah, you’re right. I think self-reflection comes with any age. But it’s definitely something that one should do once in a while, you know, especially when it comes to work. And just, overall, how you’re feeling with your job and what you want to do next.
Yeah, yeah.
Okay, so one more question, which I believe it’s very important. What role does networking play in your career?
This is an interesting one, because I was thinking back to especially when I first joined the UN, I think I had a vision of networking that is quite different from how I see it now. Because back then, I had quite a hard view of of people who I saw as ‘networkers’. I thought that they were being a bit mercenary, maybe in terms of okay, to network, I need to find the people who are going to help me move up in my career, the people who are going to give me backing or information that’s going to get me a promotion, or get me where I want to be. And that all felt a bit inauthentic. And I think, certainly there are some people who take that approach to networking. But the way that I understand networking now, and how I’d recommend other people who maybe think more like me about it, who maybe don’t feel comfortable with that more aggressive approach to networking, is that really, networking is a long term thing. It’s something where you’re looking to make connections with people. And for me, I feel most comfortable when it’s authentic human connections in the workplace. And I mentioned before being curious, I am constantly curious about my colleagues, in terms of how did they come to UNDP or whichever partner we might be working with, what drives them? What are they passionate about? What do we have in common? And that I think helps the the immediate working relationship. But it also gives you this network of people who, in the future, they might come to you with a question you might go to them with something you want to ask about, there might be just kind of shared information, or just an awareness of, oh, okay, I know that person who’s really good at X, Y, and Z. I’ve got this one thing where I need some help with X, Y, and Z, I’ll just check in with them. And it kind of goes in both directions. So I guess my second recommendation would be not to see networking as something that you have to do to progress in your career, so much as something that can actually be an enjoyable human part of the work experience. We spend so much of our daily life at work, and one of the things I most appreciate about working in the UN is the incredibly diverse and interesting workforce that we have. That’s something that’s both meaningful to me and I think that’s been important in the work that I do and what whatever comes next. And one last thing, because it’s kind of, slightly off to the side, in terms of, of networking. I’ve been quite an active user of LinkedIn. And that’s something where you’ve got some virtual networking at play, which obviously, is not the same thing as what I’ve just been talking about. So on LinkedIn, you’ll have connections to some of your teammates, or people that you work with, or people that you know pretty well, then there’ll be looser connections to maybe people who are in your organisation, but you don’t know, or people who are outside your organisation in other places. And then there’s also connections to sometimes really random group of people who you have no idea who they are. But in that virtual space, there’s a different type of networking going on. And for me, the way that I use LinkedIn is pretty much in three ways. So one is to, to kind of help show the work that I do and the work that my team does to give to kind of highlight what it is that we’ve actually been working on, which can also help me as well in terms of remembering what we’ve what we’ve done over the years. Also, I think LinkedIn is very good in terms of being a good advocate for UNDP itself and for the UN itself, because there’s plenty of posts from different parts of UNDP or the UN system, in terms of the the good work that we’re doing, and I think anyone who works in the UN system, it is part of what we should be doing — helping to support and promote the UN values, you know, the amazing work that we are doing. And then the last thing is also in terms of some of the people who are looking for work themselves. So I regularly reshare links to job vacancy announcements or interesting career opportunities within UNDP or elsewhere that I think that people will find value in. So those are kind of two different strands of networking. I hope that makes sense.
Yes Paul, it completely does. I believe that when I started this internship, I think that the networking has given me a bigger perspective in the way that I network with my colleagues to enjoy the relationship and to get to know them and to understand where they’re coming from, what their values and missions are. This has been really nice, and I don’t know Paul, if you have anything else to say?
So thank you so much Alessia for having invited me to take part and thank you to anyone who’s made it to the end of this this interview. I appreciate you listening!
Thank you so much for coming and thank you all for listening. We hope our conversations will inspire you to keep learning and advancing in your careers. And make sure to share this episode with any social platform you all have. We will see you all for the next time!
--
--

Title: Fujifilm X100V: Copenhagen — A photo story
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
What a weekend. I just had the pleasure to explore Copenhagen in Denmark for a bit. I took lots of photos with my beloved Fujifilm X100V and the conversion lenses. In this little article, I will share some of my favorite shots & spots from this trip.
All the photos you’ll see, have been edited with my presets. If you’re interested, you can get them here: www.chrisperkles.at
We arrived at a Wednesday night in the capital of Denmark, and we stayed in the Huxley Hotel in the center of the city. The location of the hotel made it easy to get everywhere by foot.
We started the first beautiful sunny fresh march day at Nyhavn, since it was next to our Hotel. The good thing was that on a Thursday morning, it was not too busy, and we could find a good spot for breakfast close to the water and in the sun.
After having some good brunch, we walked towards Kastellet along the water shore. Spotting some nice architecture and beautiful views.
Kastellet is something special. For me, as an old Stronghold gamer, this was very pleasant to see, how the castle was shaped and still used today.
After the castle, we walked back towards the center and checked out the Frederiks Kirke and Schloss Amalienborg. There we enjoyed a parade from the oldschool military.
Next on our list was Schloss Rosenborg and the attached garden. Since it was March, the garden was not that pretty because nothing was blooming. But the small palace was impressive.
Feeling: Hungry. So let’s get some food. In the area of Schloss Rosenborg, we found a place called Brdr. Price. Food was delicious, service was great and the location very pretty. 10/10 recommend.
Back on energy, we headed towards the Botanical Garden, but we’ve been too late, it was already closed. So the replacement program was the Rundetarn, an observatory with a beautiful view over Copenhagen.
That was the closing of our first day here. We spent a nice evening having some dinner and relaxing.
New day, new luck. We started the day with a quick breakfast and then heading towards the botanical garden again. This time we were on time.
In the evening we walked through the city, checked out some stores and just had a good time.
After all, this was a very beautiful trip, with some great food and beautiful weather. I can recommend copenhagen to everyone, but consider, that town is expensive as hell. The food compared to Austria is at least 50% — 100% more expensive. If you have any questions, send me a message on Instagram or leave a comment here.
--
--
I write about photography, communication and things that cross my mind // www.chrisperkles.at
