Title: Discover the Magic of the Copenhagen in 5 Unforgettable Experiences
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Welcome, wanderlust-driven adventurers, to the enchanting city of Copenhagen! Nestled on the scenic shores of Denmark, this vibrant metropolis boasts a mesmerizing blend of rich history, modern design, and irresistible charm. I would always stop by Copenhagen if I needed to fly from the Kastrup Airport. It is the coolest capital in the Nordic country in my opinion. In this article, five must-do experiences will be unveiled. So, grab your sense of adventure and let’s dive into the heart of this magical Danish capital!
Escape the hustle and bustle of the city and find tranquility amidst the lush greenery of the Rosenborg Garden. Located in the heart of Copenhagen, this expansive park is the perfect spot to enjoy a leisurely picnic surrounded by natural beauty in the typical Nodic summer afternoon. Spread out your blanket on the soft grass, bask in the warm Danish sunshine, and savor a delicious spread of local treats, a nice Danish sandwich will be a great choice.
The garden’s meticulously embedded flowers, tranquil ponds, and majestic trees provide a picturesque backdrop for your picnic. As you indulge in your culinary delights, take a moment to admire the stunning Renaissance-style Rosenborg Castle, which stands as a guardian over the garden. Whether you’re seeking a romantic escape or a peaceful retreat with friends and family, picnicking in the Rosenborg Garden is an absolute must-do in Copenhagen.
Step into a world straight out of a Hans Christian Andersen story at the iconic Tivoli Gardens. This whimsical amusement park, dating back to 1843, exudes an atmosphere of wonder and nostalgia. Stroll through enchanting gardens, take a thrilling ride on the roller coasters, and enjoy live performances by talented musicians and actors. As dusk descends, Tivoli transforms into a mesmerizing wonderland of twinkling lights, with charming food stalls offering delicious treats. Tivoli Gardens truly encapsulates the essence of Copenhagen’s charm and should not be missed.
For those seeking retail therapy, Strøget is an absolute must. This bustling pedestrian street stretches across the heart of Copenhagen and is one of Europe’s longest shopping streets. Lose yourself in a retail wonderland as you walk by the high-end boutiques, trendy international brands, and Danish design stores one after another. But Strøget is not just about shopping — it’s a vibrant hub of entertainment, with street performers, charming cafés, and historical landmarks along the way, like Round Tower, City Hall and the Parliament building. Take your time to explore the side streets and hidden courtyards, where you’ll stumble upon unique treasures and delightful surprises.
At the end of the pedestrian street, you can see the most colorful corner of Copenhagen, Nyhavn. It gives you a chance to embrace the picturesque waterfront district that perfectly captures the city’s allure. Its vibrant row of colorful 17th-century townhouses will transport you to a time when sailors, artists, and dreamers roamed these very streets. Stroll along the canal, admiring the quaint boats floating on the water, and indulge in the delectable Danish pastries at the local cafés. Nyhavn is a haven for photographers, and you’ll find endless photo opportunities at every corner. Soak up the lively atmosphere, raise a glass of Carlsberg, and toast to the beauty of Copenhagen.
Prepare to enter a world within a world at Christiania, an autonomous neighborhood that defies convention and embraces its own unique spirit. Founded in the early 1970s, this self-proclaimed “freetown” is a haven for artists, musicians, activists, and free thinkers. Meander through the colorful streets, adorned with vibrant murals, and immerse yourself in the eclectic atmosphere. Discover artisanal shops, organic cafés, and offbeat music venues. While Christiania’s unconventional nature may not be for everyone, it offers a fascinating glimpse into a subculture that celebrates creativity and alternative lifestyles, concurring with a typical hedonist Danish image.
While you’re around the neighborhood, why not visit the top of the Vor Frelsers Kirke? From there, you can look over the whole city, with everything under your eyes. The church also preserves the oldest pipe organs in Copenhagen.
In Copenhagen, where fairy tales blend with regal history, a visit to both Amalienborg and the Little Mermaid promises a captivating journey through time and folklore. Begin your royal escapade at Amalienborg, the present royal castle and residence of the Danish royal family. Marvel at the elegant architecture as you explore the majestic palace complex, composed of four identical rococo-style palaces surrounding an enchanting courtyard. Witness the Changing of the Guard ceremony, where soldiers in their distinctive bearskin hats create a scene straight out of a storybook.
From the regal splendor of Amalienborg, venture to the tranquil shores of Langelinie to meet the iconic Little Mermaid. A short stroll along the promenade leads you to the petite bronze statue perched on a rock, gazing longingly into the sea. This beloved symbol of Copenhagen, inspired by Hans Christian Andersen’s enchanting tale, captures the imagination of visitors from around the world. If you are lucky, you may see swans along side with the mermaid, making this walk even more fairytale-like.
Copenhagen, with its blend of history and creativity, is a destination that promises to captivate every traveler. It is a perfect choice for those who come to visit Scandinavia for the first time. Whether you find yourself lost in the whimsical world of Tivoli Gardens, savoring the colorful sights of Nyhavn, or immersing yourself in the bohemian allure of Christiania, this enchanting city will leave an unforgettable mark on your soul.
--

Title: A Perfect Day in Copenhagen, the Socialist Utopia Gone Right
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
My perfect day in CPH starts in Vesterbro, my favorite neighborhood in the city. Formerly a blue-collar neighborhood, it’s known for its hipsters, dive bars, and murals, so I feel right at home, thinking of the Mission District in San Francisco, my second home I left behind.
The main drag, Istegade is grungy and chic in turns: Central Station where Istegade begins crawls with junkies and hookers. Early in the morning, that area is fogged with old cigarette smoke and the clouded eyes of unseeing street-walkers. The Danes are modestly boastful about this last bastion of filth in their practical little city, and the fact that they invented the concept of modern porn as we know it.
My morning begins with pastries. I lived in Paris for years, but I might go out on a limb and say that the Danes’ pastry and bread-making skills are on par if not slightly above the French in general. Near the end of Istegade is BRØD, where a sandy-haired young Viking stands behind the counter and gruffly hands over fresh-baked bread, steaming heft and wholesomeness in his likeness.
One of the things you must do to fully enjoy CPH is rent a bike. The bike roads are so well-paved, the city so level, and the air so crisp, it’ll make you wonder what you did to deserve this bliss. Ride down the suspended bike-only bridge by Fisketorvet mall, and head to the docks for a canal tour, preferably one where they give you warm wine, or gløgg. (I swear I’m not choosing all of these words based on the funky-looking Danish “ø,” which is called a Faroese, you nerds.)
During the tour of the Copenhagen canals, you will learn many things about this watery city, like how it was founded in 1167, about the illustrious reign of King Christian IV, and their near-constant naval humiliations. But the most impressive of all is the newly built power plant, Amager Bakke, which imports waste from neighboring countries to generate energy. The smoke produced from the plant is 95 percent water, with which they aim to recreate the freshness of a mountaintop near the plant’s chimneys where the world’s largest man-made ski slope starts. If that is not doing the MOST good, I don’t know what is.
Back on land, it’ll be time for lunch. Torvehallerne is a fresh food market that delights the senses of food-obsessed world travelers and Copenhageners. Definitely have the smørrebrød, which is dark rye bread covered in all good things like smoked salmon, roast beef, or shrimp, smothered in aioli, nuts, and dill. After that you could check out the Design Museum, one of the best of its kind. But the mother of Danish design and supreme engenderer of material covetousness is Illums Bolighus downtown, the most spectacular design and living store I’ve been inside.
By the time I’ve had my fill of looking at pretty things I can’t afford it’ll be around 3 or 4pm, when people get off work. Yes, you heard me right. It’s time for a drink. A Danish friend told me Denmark has the highest per-capita consumption of coffee, ice cream, and beer. I didn’t check these facts, but I believe him because he’s a doctor.
Whatever you choose to drink, make sure to have a good view of the street to watch the commuting Danes. Other than the fact that they are ridiculously good-looking, one thing struck me as particularly notable: the amount of blond-haired children in the street accompanied not only by their beautiful mothers, but invariably by their fathers as well. Truly, I had never seen a city where so many men were catering to their children. This is the first place I’ve ever been where having kids and taking care of them isn’t emasculating for men or akin to career suicide for women. It was almost as though toxic masculinity had been wiped out. Maternity and paternity leave is mandated by law, and not a miserly few weeks for the mother only, but a whole year, that’s fifty-two weeks of paid leave to be shared between the parents. The government takes good care of its citizens.
Coming from San Francisco and Seoul, where none of my career-driven girlfriends dare having children until they are settled and secure well into their mid-thirties, I suddenly had the creeping suspicion that the rest of the world had got it all wrong. The Danes had figured life out. Everyone was well-fed, a feeling of wholesome well-being permeated the city with the brisk salty air coming off the Baltic Sea.
This was the ideal socialist Utopia, or the closest thing I’d ever seen. The possible future of feminism and mankind invigorated me. But looking around, my heart sank. No one here looked like me. People of color were rare and far in between: I would never belong here. I would always be considered a tourist, or worse, a Thai masseuse.
The Danes are kind but insular people who are sometimes described as cold by expats. Their days and weekends are filled with family picnics and parties that outsiders aren’t invited to. What they have, their culture, their practical sensibilities and husbandry of their surroundings, their dedication to the good life represented by hygge are treasures that should be protected.
But CPH is where one of the worst housing crisis in Europe is taking place for students, newcomers, and immigrants. Denmark receives less refugees per capita than any other Western European country excepting the UK. It is a far cry from what Denmark’s neighbor, Sweden is doing. The future and health of a city can be judged based on their treatment of outsiders, people who aren’t from there who want to move there. And it struck me as sad that some nationalists might cite Denmark as a good example to close their borders to people in need.
When I am about to be depressed by my own thoughts, it’s time to head to Christiania. Christiania Freetown is the jewel of Copenhagen, a radical morsel of prime real estate that hippies took over in the 70s smack-dab in the middle of the city. Until quite recently they didn’t pay for electricity or taxes, operating under their own laws. Before sunset is the ideal time to go there to check out the architecture, which is a euphemism for the only place that sells weed in the open in Denmark. Sit on the outdoor benches or by the water with a beer in hand and feel that brotherly love seep back into you.
When it becomes too cold to sit outside, I would head back towards Vesterbro to Kødbyens, the meat-packing district filled with restaurants and nightclubs to continue the night until the sun comes up. As I creep back home in the morning, the streets are quiet and subdued, foggy and windy like no one lives in this sleepy town. There is none of that anxious energy that makes a big city spin, spin, spin. Bukowski’s saying, “Find what you love and let it kill you,” is not a phrase that goes down well with the practical Danes nor with the soporific comforts offered by hygge.
And I love CPH because it helps me imagine a different life where I don’t have to kill myself for my career, or tamp down every instinct until I make something out of myself. If only one could belong here.
--
--
1
Writer and literary translator penning & living her fantasy

Title: Copenhagen Adventures
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Have you ever arrived in a city so tired from traveling, but somehow the energy of the place wakes you up? That’s exactly what happened when I landed in Copenhagen…
We got to Copenhagen on Friday morning after a ridiculously early 6 AM flight, and we were dead tired. We didn’t have any time to lose so we set out for the hostel. We took the train to Steel House, which was hands down the best hostel we’ve been to yet. It had everything — pool, gym, cinema, you name it. We dropped our bags and headed to the city. Upon arrival we stopped and listened to a singer on the streets, it was super cool to see him perform.
Locating the Streets and Gasoline Grill
Copenhagen has an atmosphere that makes you just want to walk around. We walked around the streets, dropped by Rosenborg Castle, and let the city reveal itself. Somewhere along the way, hunger caught up with us, and we went to Gasoline Grill, which serves famous burgers. The burger was just what we needed and it set the tone for the day.
The Old Irish Pub and Barkowski’s
We continued walking and ended up at this place called “The Old Irish Pub,” where they had a live band playing. The atmosphere was just right with a good energy. We sat back, listened to the music, and just absorbed the atmosphere. It was a mix of locals and tourists, and it felt like one of those pubs you find on a college campus.
We finally checked into the hostel at 3pm and freshened up to then head back out into town. This time we headed to Barkowski’s, a restaurant/bar that was full of people. We had heard that they heard pull tables but didn’t see them at first sight. After an urgent search we headed downstairs to the basement and found the pool tables and asked some locals if we could play them. They were excited to play “The Americans” and spoke great english. We ended up beating them in a best-of-5 series and it felt very good to win. We hung out for a little while longer and listened to the jazz/rock that was playing, then called it a night.
CopenHot and relaxing, and partying at Rumors
The next morning, we were ready for something entirely new. We went to CopenHot, where they have hot tubs right on the water. It was busy, but in the best way possible — people were just hangin’ out, relaxing. We even did the ice plunge for a bit. The cold was terrible but the instant jump back into the hot tub made up for it. The soft music in the background made all this feel ultra peaceful. It was just the reset we needed.
Then we were hungry and went to War Pigs to get BBQ. As someone who is from Texas, I can vouch that it was some of the best BBQ I had had. The mac and cheese was phenomenal and it paired just right with the pulled pork sandwich. It was the ideal way to finish off a relaxing morning, and I would eat in again in an instant if I could.
We napped briefly, then prepared for the evening. We headed to The Jane, a former library turned bar. The music was just what you’d expect if you were in a library listening to music. It was definitely a first for me and it almost makes you feel like you are in a library. It had books on the walls and the lighting was very dim. It was a very mellow vibe.
Though that changed pretty quickly… We then headed to a club called Rumors. It was all EDM and sing-along tracks here, and the atmosphere was on a whole different level. People were dancing in what looked like a pit.. The music was blasting, and we got to feel what its like to almost be at a concert in Denmark. We met some locals, danced and then called it a night to end our trip.
The Copenhagen Vibe
By the time we got back to the hostel, I had concluded that Copenhagen somehow felt like Amsterdam — the buildings, the bars, the surprises around every corner. There’s a sense of never having any idea what’s gonna happen next and what place you will end up in. Everywhere we went was somewhere completely different and somehow we had a great time everywhere we went. And honestly, the music in this city ended up shaping the whole experience. It was the soundtrack to it all, establishing mood and rendering each moment a little more memorable.
Thanks for reading! If you enjoyed this post, make sure to follow my account for more travel stories and insights. Stay tuned for next week’s adventure .
--
--
Exploring the world through music while studying abroad in Barcelona. Sharing stories on how different cultures express themselves through sound.

Title: Copenhagen Gave Me a Taste of Tokyo
Content:

Member-only story

After a long, dark, freezing, and often soul-crushing winter, Copenhagen slowly begins to come alive in April. It’s green and beautiful with colorful flowers all over the city.
And right in the middle of so many colors, when the cherry trees blossom, their delicate white and pink petals create a stunning contrast against the lush green grass and the clear blue sky.
Copenhagen is full of cherry blossom trees. You see them everywhere. They are in the gardens of tall buildings and standalone houses, in playgrounds, near water bodies, and even lining the roads.
This was quite surprising for me during my first year here. I always pictured Denmark as people biking through the streets, taking icy dips in the sea, and sipping coffee with Danish pastries in cozy cafés.
But cherry blossoms?
That was something I never expected.
This was one of the sweetest surprises that Copenhagen, the world’s happiest city, has given me.
I’ve travelled to over 20 countries, some just once, others many times, but Japan has always remained a dream. Though I have planned many times, a trip to…

Title: Schrödinger’s Cat: Superposition, Copenhagen Interpretation, Quantum Mechanics
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Overview
Schrödinger’s cat was a thought experiment proposed by Erwin Schrödinger in a discussion with Albert Einstein in an attempt to illustrate the insufficiencies of the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics. The experiment questioned the validity of superposition and posed the largely unsolved question of at which point a superposition collapses into one of its possible states.
Superposition — Young’s Double Split Experiment
Superposition plays an essential role in the Copenhagen interpretation and thus Schrödinger’s thought experiment. It is the ability of a quantum system to simultaneously exist in multiple states until observed. The idea is demonstrated by Thomas Young’s double-slit experiment, where a beam of light is aimed at a barrier with two small vertical slits. The light that has passed through the slits is measured on a photographic plate. When one of the vertical slits is covered, a single line of light is observed on the photographic plate on the side of the uncovered slit. If both are left uncovered, however, rather than two lines of light, there are many more on the photographic plate. In route to the photographic plate, each photon exists in a state of each of its possible trajectories, demonstrating a concept called interference, which is essentially the superposition of waves.
In an attempt to further analyze the trajectories of the photons, experiments have been conducted to track their paths. Doing this, however, seems to disrupt the superposition of the photons, creating what would be expected by classical physics on the photographic plate, two lines of light mirroring the slits in the preceding barrier. It appears that the superposition of a particle can not be directly measured; its effects (interference) can only be observed.
Schrödinger’s Cat
Schrödinger’s Cat is a thought experiment that was proposed by Erwin Schrödinger in a discussion with Albert Einstein to highlight the seemingly ridiculous nature of the concepts of superposition used in the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics. The Copenhagen interpretation briefly states that a quantum system remains in a state of superposition until directly observed by the outside world. When observed, the superposition collapses into one of its possible states. For example, when the photons in Young’s double-slit experiment were measured, they collapsed into one of their possible trajectories, creating two lines of light.
Schrödinger, attempting to disprove the practicality of superposition, proposed a hypothetical in which a larger system was dependent on the superposition of a quantum particle. Schrödinger suggested that if a cat were placed inside a sealed box with a radioactive particle and a flask of poison and the poison was only released if the particle decayed and released radiation, the mortality of the cat would be subject to the state of the radioactive particle. Because the Copenhagen interpretation states that the radioactive particle is in a position of both decayed and not decayed, the cat, by extension, will be in a position of both alive and dead until observed by the outside world. The goal was not to propose the practicality of simultaneously dead and alive cats, instead the thought experiment emphasized the unrealistic implications the Copenhagen interpretation had at a larger scale.
The thought experiment had brought to light a question that is still largely unsolved today: “At what point does a particle stop existing as a superposition and collapse into one of its possible states?” The Copenhagen interpretation had assumed this would happen when an observation of the superposition takes place.
Von Neumann Interpretation
In response to the flaws of the Copenhagen interpretation, John von Neumann proposed the idea that the radioactive particle is observed by the device that detects radiation which is subsequently observed by the controlled flask holding the poison. The point at which the superposition of the particle collapses is not significant. The only point at which the superposition must collapse is when there is a conscious observer. Even this interpretation, however, has been rejected by a thought experiment proposed by Eugene Wigner called Wigner’s friend. Other interpretations include the ensemble interpretation, relational interpretation, and transactional interpretation all with the common goal of identifying at which point a superposition collapses, a question posed by Erwin Schrödinger’s famous thought experiment: Schrödinger’s cat.
For a further look into the different interpretations of quantum mechanics and superposition
en.wikipedia.org

www.techtarget.com
courses.lumenlearning.com
plato.stanford.edu

Title: How My Trip to Visit the “Best Place on Earth to Live” Never Happened.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

“The longer I live, the more beautiful life becomes.” (Frank Lloyd Wright) Non-fiction pieces, personal essays and occasional poems that explore how we feel about how we age and offer tips for getting the most out of life.

Member-only story
--
Share
“Jonathan just tested positive for Covid here this morning.” My son Dan called me from Copenhagen with the bad news. And he called just minutes before I was to fly there for a long-anticipated visit to Copenhagen, to visit Dan and his family. I was devastated. I knew it would be crazy at age 87 to head off to Copenhagen when someone in the household there had Covid. I canceled.
I had been reading and talking about Denmark for weeks and I found myself continuing to do research and hold forth on Denmark. And now, dear readers, I want to share some of the amazing information that I have learned and to tell you why what is going on in Denmark matters to each of us. Even if we never go there.
Denmark has been ranked as the best place on earth to live and also the best of all countries in terms of quality of life. It has been named as the least corrupt country in the world and number one in terms of protecting the environment and gender equality. It has been ranked the 2nd happiest country on earth, (after Finland) for…
--

“The longer I live, the more beautiful life becomes.” (Frank Lloyd Wright) Non-fiction pieces, personal essays and occasional poems that explore how we feel about how we age and offer tips for getting the most out of life.

Title: Wellness Guide To Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Alright. I have completely fallen in love with Copenhagen. If I were to do college again, I would study abroad here… in the summer ; ). It’s seriously such a magical place — the parks, the bike lanes, the zero noise pollution, the food, the “hygge”… I could go on. Copenhagen is considered one of the happiest cities in the world, + I can totally see why.
Pro Tip — Bike… everywhere. Literally, everywhere.
1] Mad + Kaffe: MUST. HAVE. BRUNCH. HERE. They serve brunch until 12:30 every day. Wow. I can’t believe a spot like this is not in Chicago yet. This has been voted “best brunch in Copenhagen.”
2] Wulff + Konstali: Another — MUST. HAVE. BRUNCH. HERE. They serve brunch until 3 PM [even better!]. Go to the one on Ameagerbro, so that you can go to the beach after!
3] Grod: We went here for takeaway dinner, but I wish I could have come for breakfast! Everything is porridge based… sounds weird but it’s SO GOOD.
For Next Time (Brunch) — Baryl, Social, Bowl Market, Cafe Det Vide Has, Moeller Kaffe + Kokken
Coffee — Coffee Collective, Original Coffee, Statement Coffee, Prolog Coffee Bar
Bakeries — Sankt Peders Bageri [cinnamon rolls on Wednesdays! ++ Copenhagen’s oldest bakery!], Leckerbaer, Isoteket, , Juno The Bakery, Lilli Bakery, Hart Bageri, Meyers Bageri, Bageriet Brod
Sweets — Nicecream, ISTID, Social Foods, Granny’s House [in Torvehallerne]
1] La Banchina: Hands down favorite spot in Copenhagen for a few reasons: the food is incredible [apps = bread + olive oil, olives, + almonds… + then the starter, fish, vegetable, + dessert change every day!], THEN after dinner: jump in the water… + then warm up by the fire + SAUNA. They are also open for breakfast, which is probably so dreamy too.
2] Organic Boho: We stumbled upon this place on our way to Christiana [the hippy town] + WOW, obsessed. Get the burger with tempeh, + THE LOVE PLATE [my fav]. They have tons of beautiful drinks too — juices, smoothies, + rainbow lattes ; ).
3] 42Raw: I love that so many spots in Copenhagen have easy “takeaway” options. We ordered takeaway to bring on the Go Boat: acai bowl, green bowl [“this almost tastes too healthy” — Isaac], salad of the day, + chocolate PB cup. The sweet potato fries looked bomb, too.
4] Neighbourhood: Organic pizza + cocktails… what more do you need? Oh, + TRUFFLE POPCORN. Make sure to get the burrata love pizza.
5] Sprod: You know a place is good when they don’t have an English menu. We ordered the chicken sandwich to split as a snack… + then instantly ordered another one. SO YUM.
6] District Tonkin: This place has the “best banh mi in Copenhagen” + it lived up to the hype . Chicken lemongrass banh mi + pho = winning combo.
7] Souls: This won the most sustainable restaurant in Copenhagen, AND best vegan restaurant — so definitely go. The warm potato salad was liiiiiife. ++ the summer lemonade.
8] Aamanns Deli: A trip to Copenhagen is not complete without trying a smorresbrod. There’s a few Aamanns, depending on the experience you want — I liked the deli because you can eat it in the restaurant, or easily choose takeaway + bring it to a park!
9] Kodbyens Fiskebar: MUSSELS : ) This was the fanciest restaurant that we went to [on our last night]. It’s in the Meat Packing District… we hopped around to a few places — staying at each place for an hour while ordering: drink + one item from the menu to share, what we call #AppyHour.
10] Smag: The BEST salads + sandwiches, oh my gosh. Go before a picnic!
For Next Time — Morganstedt, SimpleRaw, dop, Bollyfood, WEDOFOOD, Gro Spiseri, Ma Poule [duck sandwich is apparently amazing], Kaf, California Kitchen, Mahalle CPH, Plantepolsen, Barabba, Amass [$$$$], Kadea [$$$$], Noma ; ) [$$$$ — named the best restaurant in the WORLD]
Markets — Copenhagen out did themselves with all the markets here. Like, WOW. Trovehallerne is obviously a must… make sure to get Smag, GROD, a chocolate peanut butter brownie from Granny’s House. Other fabulous markets are The Bridge Street Kitchen, Reffen, Rebel Food, + Tivoli Food Hall.
1] Mikkeller + Friends: Apparently the best spot for beer in Copenhagen.
2] WarPigs: Go for the beer, stay for the MEAT. Omg, literally — the brisket was to diiiiie for. *Make a stop here during #AppyHour.
3] Noho: Funky cocktails + hip vibe. *Make a stop here during #AppyHour.
4] Grab Wine… Literally Anywhere: Drink in a park, on the streets, by the lake, etc. It’s open container law!
For Next Time — Sidecar, BRUS, Baghaven, Himmeriget, Lidoeb, Malbeck Vinbar
1] ALL. THE. PARKS: Faelledparken, Svanemoelle Beach, The Citadel, Frederiksberg Gardens (*probably my fav because you get a shot of the zoo in the park + can see the elephants!), Superkilen, King’s Garden, Botanical Gardens… + more. If I lived here, I would spend every day in a park. They are all so gorgeous + unique. You must visit them all!
2] Walk Down These Streets:
3] Go Boat: We chose this over the Canal Tour [if I had time, I’d do both!] — you rent a boat to drive… yourself… with no experience required! Aha. It’s right next to the Islands Brygge Harbour Bath, which you should definitely go to on a sunny day. *Book ahead of time!
4] Tivoli: Copenhagen’s second oldest amusement park, + right in the center of town. It’s definitely worth a stop.
5] Visit The Cemeteries: Sounds creepy, but this is also a must. Vestre Cemetery + Assistens Cemetery are incredibly beautiful.
6] Christiania: The hippie commune — the only place hash/weed is legal in Copenhagen. Super funky to walk through... most people built their homes themselves! Couple things to note: I wouldn’t go there at night, no photos are allowed, + no running.
7] Shop Vintage: Check out this guide for the flea markets!
8] Wellness: I wasn’t able to test any of these out, but I heard great things about: YO Studios, NOR Nordic Health House, CopenHot, Hot Yoga CPH.
We stayed at Hotel SP34— incredible free breakfast every day, in a great spot in town [a bike store is like two seconds away… or you can rent bikes at the hotel], + WINE HOUR EVERY DAY! Also, there are a few other hotels close by in the same collective, so you can go there for wine hour, too ; ). Check out Brochner Hotels. / *One thing I will say is the room we booked was TINY.
There are so many components within Copenhagen that I want to bring back to Chicago — particularly BIKE LANES. ++ how they do brunch… + all the parks. I’m in loooooove. Please visit!
What did I miss? Let me know!
++ Elisabeth
--
--

Title: Understanding the S-train & metro network in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Map Quest is your go-to destination for exploring the intricate world of public transportation, map design, and urban design. Submit your story: https://tinyurl.com/3zaej7hs

Member-only story
--
Share
Copenhagen, Denmark, has a unique and interesting transit system. When looking at it at first, most will just see the S-train network, that by any means is not the largest one in the world. But it’s a quite effective network. And when combined with the metro that got added to the Copenhagen transit network back in 2002 when the first 2 lines opened.
The S-train network has been running since 1934. It was the vision for the network, even before it was born that it should be 100% electrified. And it has been, from its start until today, it has only been running on electricity. This vision was part of some earlier work done by The Electrification Commission of 1926, that wanted to electrify many of the commuter rails in and around the suburbs of Copenhagen.
The first line opened the 3rd of April 1934, and ran from Klampenborg via Hellerup and Vanløse and terminated at Frederiksberg. This exact line is now defunct and does not exist in today's network. Along with a timetable…
--
--

Title: 5 things about my trip to… Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My interest to explore Copenhagen stemmed from the immaculate design culture that I had heard of . In the quest to explore the origin of hygge life we left for about week’s adventure to Copenhagen.
Fun Fact: The Danish Royal Family holds the title of the oldest monarchy. If Queen Elizabeth visits she will need to bow down to the Queen and King of Denmark.
2. Food & Drink: During my visit, the surprising find for me has been the refined food scene here. Unlike other cities, I did not go here with a focus on devouring food all day but I was pleasantly surprised by the offerings. It could be the influence of René Redzepi’s Noma, which is seen as one of the best restaurants in the world potentially attracting a lot of culinary talent here. Although, I could not get reservation at Noma these are some restaurants that left me wanting more:
Similarly for drinks some spots to check out are:
3. Fashion & Art: When I travel, I love to check out local stores that depict the local style. For sartorial trends street style was definitely trending in the city. Most of the stores I went to showcased unisex easy to wear style. Some stores that were interesting to check out are:
You cannot leave Copenhagen without checking out the best in class design stores. Some to check out are:
4. Must see: As mentioned, Copenhagen is a beautiful city. To understand its past and present I would recommend you to check out these spots, which span all over the city and gives you a good idea on what Copenhagen is all about.
Nyhavn: Street with beautiful colorful building. Great for an evening stroll.
Garden Royal: Close to Aamann’s great to catch a break here and check the rose garden.
Supekilen: For all the reasons listed above highly recommend to check this out. Although a bit away from city center.
Freetown Christiania: This is a free commune which operates as a local body without any governance from local government. It is an interesting oasis in the middle of the city , which is worth checking out.
Nyboder houses: Built in 1757, these houses have lasted several city fires and provides a little flavor of the past.
Church of Savior: This church gives a great aerial view of the city. Worth climbing up the 700 stairs to check out the cityscapes.
Design Museum of Denmark: This museum provides Danish sensibility and evolution from everywhere across fashion, architecture, furniture.
5. Tips & Tricks: These are some quick tips that I wanted to leave you with while planning your trip.
--
--
Facebook, Ex-Google, Fashion Tech Entrepreneur

Title: Stockholm, Copenhagen, Berlin, Amsterdam : Our trip and how we did it
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I just got back from my two-week trip across most of Northern Europe. This is my third trip back to Europe. (My first was a summer abroad in Italy nearly 8 years ago and my second was another two-week trip in 2014 where we explored Dublin, London, Amsterdam, and Paris.) I daresay this was the best so far! Thom and I visited Stockholm, Copenhagen, Berlin, and again, Amsterdam this time around. In order to share our experience and to create a living record of its details, I’ve decided to write across a few posts on each city and its adventures. This first post serves to detail our overall travel plans, information on flights/places to stay, tips on light packing, and general advice for good travel. I should mention that I’m not an expert on any other these things but it’s worth sharing the little knowledge that I gained before, during, and after this trip.
To begin with, here are a few starting facts about our trip:
Let’s begin by discussing budget flights. Nine months before this vacation even happened I found some non-stop flights from Oakland to Stockholm for $600 a person. These flights kicked off the entire trip and made everything possible. I recall the very first time I ever flew to Europe. (Which was 8 years this summer!) It was to Genoa, Italy from Buffalo, NY. That flight had three stops (Buffalo to NYC, NYC to Frankfurt, and Frankfurt to Milan) and one train (Milan to Genoa) in order to get to my destination with a total of over 20+ hours at a hefty price of $1500. (Thanks Aer Lingus! 🖕) So to come across a flight that was only 10 hours and non-stop to my choice destination, it felt like fate...
Doesn’t that last sentence feel so inspiring? Statements and facts like those are the gold and shiny wrapper on the cheap bar of travel chocolate. Here’s the nitty-gritty of budget flying:
With some of the add-ons and extra taxes, our $600 tickets actually came to $711.30 a person. Our in-between flights from city to city were around $50 a person. (As compared to a train from Berlin to Amsterdam which was $120 a ticket.) In the end, you have to deal with the minor annoyances for that 💰deal.
Let’s move on to transportation.
Thom and I took public transit for the most part. (I’ll discuss the bicycling and Uber rides a bit later in some of my city posts.) For us, it’s a fun challenge learning a new city’s public transit. And unlike American public transportation, European public transportation is fast, convenient, and very, VERY reliable. Upon arriving at the Arlanda Airport, which is located just outside of Stockholm, we took the Arlanda Express Train that runs directly to the city center in just 20 minutes. (As compared to my 1.5 hour MUNI and BART trip to Oakland International Airport. 😑) Out of the four cities we visited, Berlin boasted the fastest and most reliable transportation (dat German innovation) with Amsterdam coming in at a close second. (Trams, trams everywhere!) All the trams, trains, and buses that we took were clean and clearly marked. My only complaint was the summer heat which was especially felt in the enclosed and non-air conditioned trains.
I plan to discuss each Airbnb in detail for each city post but in general our decision to use this service came from a few points:
Finally, let’s talk about packing. Much like my last Europe trip, I took a single backpack and personal bag with me. That was it! Now that this trip is over, I can say, quite proudly, that it was the best decision that I made for packing. After each city we visited, Thom and I both got a little better at packing our bags. It was a very efficient way to travel, IMO.
Here are some pros:
I admit that there are some cons involved with this kind of packing. While I can pack a mean bag, it doesn’t exclude the fact that the weight gets to you…no matter how light. If you’ve ever landed at an airport and took public transit into a city, the transfers mean a lot of walking between terminals and stations. The weight of the bag can cause a lot of stress on your neck and shoulders. Even this year, I packed a bag that weighed about 8 lbs total and after a while, say 20 minutes of walking, it can really push down on you. I should mention that my bag isn’t meant for hiking or true backpacking and therefore isn’t super ergonomic. I’m sure if I had chosen a small hiking backpack, my experience would be different. The bag that I took is just an everyday backpack for commuting which is why long walks with a lot of weight can easily become a small burden.
Backpacking can also force you to make some crucial decisions as to what you pack. One small error (should I bring a bathing suit?) and you’ll be forced to carry that item throughout the entire trip with much resentment. The last time we were in Europe, it rained for most of the trip. Thom brought an umbrella this year. He never needed it! 😂 🙃 Lessons learned.
A few surprising things that we did bring this year are:
I’ve only really traveled internationally in the summer months so packing has always been dictated by the warmer weather. I took mainly dresses with a single pair of jeans and shorts. A few shirts to mix it up and a hoodie with a jean jacket for cooler evenings/days. I took a pair of black flats since they’re so versatile and my Keds for comfort as I walked/biked everywhere. I kept toiletries to small sizes and bought anything else that might have run out.
Thom and I failed to exchange any currency prior to the trip. But I would recommend making that order with your bank if possible since ATMs abroad will charge you a fee for any withdrawals. Also, make the obligatory call to your bank letting them know that you are traveling abroad so that they don’t lock your card and account.
A kind co-worker provided us an extra SIM card and we had another already from past trips, so this year we both had data/service for our phones. Thankfully our SIM cards were both purchased in the Netherlands with Vodaphone. These cards worked in all the other countries we visited and we didn’t need to purchase new cards along the way.
Finally, I’ll add that we obtained Global Entry prior to the trip. It made entering the US very easy and fast when going through customs. If you are a frequent international flyer, consider getting Global Entry. Global Entry includes TSA PreCheck. So if you fly around the country frequently (which I do), it’s very convenient and handy for jumping those long security lines.
This post is a part of a series based on my recent two-week trip to Europe.
To read this in order:
--
--
Creative technology leader who loves travel, photography, and collecting hobbies.

Title: The Copenhagen Interpretation of Quantum Mechanics Is Not Idealist in Nature
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Philosophy

--
5
Listen
Share
The Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics — and even quantum mechanics generally — has been both loosely and strongly associated with the philosophical position of idealism (see here).
Of course, there are almost as many varieties of idealism (from subjective idealism to absolute idealism to pluralist idealism) as there are idealists. So this isn’t the place to run through all of them. In any case, the kind of idealism I have in mind will become clear in this essay itself.
So take as an example the following passage (written in 2005) from Harry Nielsen:
“ Almost unbelievably perhaps, [the academics who developed quantum mechanics] chose to interpret the strangeness of quantum behaviour by denying the existence of physical reality. And as a standard textbook interpretation of quantum mechanics, physicists have been taught for the last 80 years that physical reality therefore only exists as a result of the act of observation. This is the ‘Copenhagen interpretation’ of quantum mechanics, developed in the late 1920’s by Niels Bohr and Werner Heisenberg. To quote Heisenberg: ‘I believe that the existence of the classical ‘path’ can be pregnantly formulated as follows: The ‘path’ comes into existence only when we observe it’.”
The passage above doesn’t actually mention “idealism” — yet the general gist seems to be that the Copenhagen interpretation is idealist (or at least subjectivist). And it isn’t at all odd that this writer thought this way about this interpretation of quantum mechanics.
So it’s important to stress that the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics is not idealist. Or at least the Copenhagen interpretation itself can be interpreted as not being idealist. That said, it is difficult to explain why that’s so. Indeed not many physicists — or even philosophers — have fully clarified why that is so.
Finally, there are stronger arguments which assert that quantum mechanics — if not the Copenhagen interpretation itself — is entirely subjectivist in nature. Yet there are clear differences between subjectivism and idealism. Indeed, Harry Nielsen’s words above can be interpreted as only claiming that the Copenhagen interpretation is subjectivist, not idealist.
Various philosophers (such as Karl Popper) have also argued against those who claim that quantum mechanics is subjectivist , let alone idealist (see Popper here).
It is therefore convenient that there’s a short and simple passage (as quoted in Karl Popper’s The Logic of Scientific Discovery) from the Austrian physicist Arthur March (1891–1957) which perfectly clarifies this issue.
Firstly, Arthur March makes an explicit anti-idealist statement. (It’s not clear if that was his main intention — indeed, it probably wasn’t.) He wrote:
“Naturally nobody is so mad as to assert that a body ceases to exist the moment we turn our backs to it [].”
[March was referring to quantum bodies such as particles; not cups, trees or human beings.]
An idealist, on the other hand, would argue that
a body ceases to exist the moment we turn our backs to it.
And that’s because, to an idealist, “a body” — and everything else — only exists in the individual mind or in some kind of collective mind. Thus, it does indeed cease to exist when “we turn our backs to it”. (Unless, that is, it still exists in the mind of God — as with Bishop Berkeley immaterialism, in some other being’s mind or in a collective mind.)
Arthur March, on the other had, stated that it is “mad [] to assert” that idealist position. Yet March did preface that phrase with the following words:
“One may say perhaps without fear of being misunderstood [] that for the physicist a body has reality only in the instant in which he observes it.”
It’s worth noting the phrase “for the physicist”.
This isn’t an expression of a philosophical view or even of a layperson’s position. As a physicist, March was speaking entirely as a physicist.
So even though it may be problematic to stress observation alone, this is still the stress of a physicist qua physicist. And, almost by definition, a physicist is only concerned with the observations of — and experiments on — a (in March’s word) body.
Thus March, qua physicist, stated that the
“[body] does cease, in the moment, to be an object of inquiry for the physicist”.
Why is that?
It’s
“because there exists no possibility of saying anything about it which is based on experiment”.
March’s statement above is true by definition. That is, what comes before the experiment can’t actually be part of the experiment. Or if someone does “say[] anything about it”, then what he says can’t be based on the experiment, and is therefore not itself physics. Indeed, even the mathematical formalism and/or the wave function required for the experiment has nothing to “say” about any bodies before the experiment.
The wave function has just been mentioned.
Thus, the standard interpretation of the wave function is that — in itself — it has no physical interpretation. It is purely a mathematical function. A tool. Something physicists use to do things with. Of course, it can then be given a physical interpretation.
Take the Schrödinger equation.
This doesn’t tell us what the wave function is — other than in purely mathematical terms. The physical meaning of the equation — i.e., what entities, etc. are posited — is a product of the interpretation of quantum mechanics the physicist adopts.
And even when physicists do “guess” at the (as it were) before-observation, that too is only a use of the wave function; which, again, is a large abstract mathematical object made of smaller mathematical objects.
So, basically, Arthur March, qua physicist, wasn’t interested in what might have been the case before the experiment. And, presumably, he wasn’t that interested in what was the case — i.e., in the experimental area — after he took off his white coat and packed up his bags to go home. Alternatively, if he was interested in both the before and after of the experiment, then it was as a philosopher or a layperson, not as a physicist.
As hinted at in the introduction, it’s at least partly understandable that some people see the Copenhagen interpretation as being philosophically idealist in nature. In the passage in the introduction, for example, Harry Nielsen quoted Werner Heisenberg.
So I’ll help Nielson’s cause along by also quoting Heisenberg stating the following:
“[A]n ‘objective’ physics in this sense, i.e. a sharp division of the world into object and subject has indeed ceased to be possible.”
Such passages from Heisenberg and others have provided grist to the mill for various idealists, mystics, New Agers and whatnot. Yet even here (on my reading of idealism at least) an idealist simply can’t make any distinction at all between “object and subject”. (Of course, it’s possible that the word “object” can be defined in such as way that it squares with idealism.) That’s because (to an idealist) literally everything is in the individual’s (or experimenter’s) mind. (Either that, or everything is in a collective mind or in the mind of God.) In other words, there is simply no object in idealism — we only have a subject or subjects.
My philosophy blog:
--
--
5
Philosophy

Title: Guide to Copenhagen (Culinary)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Here is my usual guide to Copenhagen for tourists who enjoy the culinary side of life and want to visit Copenhagen for the first time.
In general I tell Taxi to use taxa.dk +45 35353535 or use Donkey bikes with app or use the electric scooters.
Packing: Copenhagen is rainy and windy and chilly. Check weather forecast. Plenty swimming opportunities, so bring a towel and swimwear if you want to swim.
Inner city: This is the old town of Copenhagen. Think small streets, alleyways, and historic squares. The main (shopping) streets are Strøget and Købmagergade. Sights to see: Parliament (Christiansborg) and the Round Tower (Rundetårn). You will find two good wine bards here: Ved Stranden 10 and Den Vandrette as well as restaurant Musling.
Christianshavn: An old residential neighborhood full of canals and colorful houses. Sights to see: Cathedral of Copenhagen (Von Frue Kirke) and the Freetown Christiania. Try Rufino’s delicious pasta if you’re in the area or grab a beer at Barr in the evening sun. Restaurant 108 is also located here.
Vesterbro: The area is full of hip cafés, bars, galleries, music venues, and restaurants. The main streets are Istedgade and Sønder Boulevard. Sights to see: the meatpacking district (Kødbyen), where you can pick up Rosio Sanchez’s delicious food (ex-Noma) at Hija de Sanchez, enjoy coffee at Prolog or dine at Fiskebaren. Also, check out Rosio’s new opened place Sanchez on Istedgade.
Nørrebro: This area is often described as the most diverse part of Copenhagen. You’ll find vintage clothing stores, antique shops, café’s, and authentic Danish bodegas (bars). The most interesting streets are Jægersborggade, Stefansgade, Griffenfeldsgade, Guldbergsgade, Nørrebrogade, Ravnsborggade, and Blågårdsgade. Swing by Bæst for pizza if you’re near Guldbergsgade.
Østerbro: in an old bourgeois, residential neighborhood. Among other things, you’ll find Copenhagen’s largest park, Fælledparken, here; interesting streets: Østerbrogade, the stretch closest to The Lakes (Søerne) and Nordre Frihavnsgade. Sights to see: Kastellet (an old family fortress), Svanmøllen beach, and Juno Bakery.
Amager: Copenhagen airport is situated here. You can reach the inner city by metro in 17 minutes. Islands Brygge is worth a visit — and a swim! Sights to see: The wild landscape of Amager Fælled, Amager Strandpark (the beach), and Helgoland (a traditional sea bathhouse from 1913, that is open for everyone during the summer months).
Refshaleøen: This is the area of Copenhagen where a lot of top restaurants are based. Recently, the peninsula has been in constant development. Check out restaurant Amass, LA Banchina, and Lille bakery.
Restaurants, bars, and coffee shops:
Here, we have composed a small list of our favorite restaurants in town. We’ve also added our favorite wine bars, coffee spots, and hang-outs.
Places opened on Sunday are marked with an asterisk (*) in the list.
Velbekomme!
Restaurants:
SANCHEZ*
A neighborhood restaurant modeled after the Mexican cantina by the incredibly talented Rosio Sanchez.
lovesanchez.com
108*
noma’s Michelin-starred sister restaurant with casual coffee and wine served all-day at The Corner.
108.dk
BARR*
A casual restaurant & beer bar with outdoor seating in the former noma location — and part of the noma family.
restaurantbarr.com
KØDBYENS FISKEBAR
A Copenhagen classic in the meatpacking district, serving fresh fish and seafood, cocktails and wine.
BÆST
Sourdough pizzas from a wood-fired oven, house-made charcuterie, and cheeses. Right next to the Mirabelle bakery.
Baest.dk
SLURP RAMEN JOINT
Kickass ramen in the heart of Copenhagen, open for lunch and dinner (Wed-Sun) and dinner only on Tuesdays.
slurpramen.dk
MENFREDS & VIN*
Intimate wine bar with small plates to share, featuring vegetables from Christian Puglisi’s “Farm of Ideas”. Open for lunch and dinner.
manfreds.dk
GEIST
Relax, unwind and savor the moment with inventive cooking at the hands of chef Bo Bech in the inner city.
restaurantgeist.dk
GAARDEN & GADEN*
Very casual spot. Combined café and wine bar, serving breakfast, lunch and dinner.
gaaga.dk
AMASS
Matt Orlando’s 100% organic produce and inventive cooking in the most beautiful location on Refhaleøen, next to the NOMA symposium place.
amassrestaurant.com
GERANIUM
On the 8th floor of Denmark’s national soccer stadium, Rasmus Køfoed and Søren Ledet create a menu which is an exploration of Scandinavia’s superb wild and organic produce presented in delivate, beautiful forms.
geranium.dk
ADMIRALGADE 26
Restaurant run by the team of Ved Stranden 10, combining Nordic & Japanese cuisines.
admiralgade26.dk -> Can recommend!
BARABBA*
Simple bowls of pasta & great list of natural wines served until 2 AM in the inner city.
barabba.dk
ILUKA*
Chef Beau Clugston’s restaurant opened recently, focusing on super-fresh seafood and vegetables, made with care and commitment and server as if you’re family or best mates.
restaurantiluka.dk
HOS FISCHER
Italian trattoria with billiards and casual vibes.
hosfischer.dk
KADEAU
Kadeau’s Michelin-starred cuisine is focusing on the wild landscape of the Danish island of Bornholm.
kadeau.dk
OSTERIA RUFINO
Rustic Italian eatery with great pasta.
rufino-osteria.com
PALÆGADE*
Offers traditional Danish smørrebrod for lunch and à la carte for dinner.
palaegade.dk
RANEE’S
Casual Thai eatery, with a small wine list — you will find some surprising and fun bottles!
ranees.dk
RELÆ
Focused and thoughtful food, no fuss! Simplicity with quality ingredients.
restaurant-relae.dk
SCHØNNEMANN
The place to go for traditional Danish open sandwiches around since 1877.
restaurantschonnemann.dk
Wine bars, beer & cocktails
DEN VANDRETTE*
A cozy wine bar with fun plates of food to share at the foot of Nyhavn.
denvandrette.dk
ANCESTRALE
Vesterbro’s best natural wine bar.
ancestrale.dk
POMPETTE*
A new, intimate wine bar with a great selection & fair prices on natural wines, lovely charcuterie from Sweden and cheese.
@pompettecph
RUBY
Cocktails and happy thoughts among beautifulfurnitue and cozy corners.
rby.dk
BALDERDASH
Whimsical cocktails and endless stories.
balderdash.dk
LA BANCHINA*
Just a short walk from the new noma. Great wine and simple food by the harbour front.
labanchina.dk
VED STRANDEN 10
Iconic wine bar with the most beautiful interior. The evening sun shines on their terrace until it sets.
vedstranden10.dk
THE CORNER AT 108*
Café during the day serving snacks, a changing selection of wine and drinks in the evening.
108.dk
HIMMERIGET
A special selection of beers on tap and huge list of bottled beer.
Himmeriget.dk
NANSENSGADE NR.30*
Very cute wine bar with an amazing wine list, focusing on natural wines open daily in summer.
nr30.cargocollective.com
KØLSTERS TOLV HANER
The official beer brewers for noma symposium serving up amazing biodynamic beers.
koelster.dk
Coffee & pastries
THE CORNER AT 108*
Breakfast, pastries & coffee in the morning with a lunch menu and drinks during the day.
108.dk
JUNO*
Maybe the only bakery in town where people will queue for baked goods. Recommended: Cardamon buns.
@juno_the_bakery
LILLE BAKERY*
Former 108 colleagues, recently opened this beautiful bakery nearby noma.
MIRABELLE*
Mirabelle server great coffee, delicious croissants and buns in the morning before turning into a restaurant with organic food for the rest of the day.
mirabelle-bakery.dk
PROLOG*
Exceptional coffee in the meatpacking district, Prolog is the winner of the Danish Barista Championship 2018.
@prologcoffeebar
COFFEE COLLECTIVE*
Explore coffee experiences in a manner that improves the living conditions of farmers across the globe.
coffeecollective.dk

Title: Blog | Navigating the Copenhagen study abroad experience through pastries
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When people hear ‘Danish,’ they typically think of Danish pastry, a multilayered sweet pastry with various fillings like cheese or a berry sauce. Or they think of Danish cheese.
From the moment I landed in Copenhagen, locals and people from my program told me to try the numerous famous bakeries in the city. Of course, as a foodie, I couldn’t say no.
But what I didn’t realize was how central of a gathering place bakeries are for Copenhageners (is that what they call them?). Their fast-paced life accompanies grabbing a pastry and cappuccino on their way to the office, or as a casual meet-up spot for friends as they get off work around 3 or 4 pm.
When I look back via camera roll at the delicious, warm, and fluffy pastries I tried, it evokes more than longing to have the level of freshness and quality these pastries have at an affordable price. It sucks me right back into highs and lows during my study abroad, new friendships blossoming, and lessons learned.
Here are five moments (and pastries) I am happy to share from my study abroad experience in Copenhagen:
A week into my stay, I found myself wandering through the streets near Kongens Nytorv, the city center filled with people, shops, and the famous Nyhavn canal. I was walking home after a class excursion feeling hungry and exhausted.
I was still figuring out public transportation (bus or train?) and I had unsuccessfully made any plans with new friends.
The homesickness and loneliness were starting to sink in.
I stumbled upon the nearest coffee shop, Farumhus, which translates to “farmhouse.” I walked in and ordered the Kanelstang, a cinnamon Danish pastry but elegantly twisted in various ways, depending on the bakery.
The place was about to close, so the lady ringing me up offered me an extra pastry for free. her kindness was a small act but stirred a few tears for me, sprouting a tiny sense of belonging in this new country.
Biting into the Kanelstang felt like a warm hug as well, with the generous layers of cinnamon and the intricate swirls, perfect for ripping pieces as I sat on a bench and people-watched for the evening.
I’ve been to this bakery twice during my stay and both times were with new friends I had made. My Food and Identity professor recommended this bakery, located in the Meatpacking District, to our class after a field study in the area.
My friends and I sat outside the bakery in Enghave Plads: this utopian park area where families, friends, and children gathered to chat, play, and spend time together. How I long for areas like these in the US. It was a great area to break the ice over delicious treats and get to know each other more.
As an Indian, trying a cardamom bun was absolutely out of my comfort zone. But strangely it’s a popular pastry option in Copenhagen. But the lemon tart was gorgeous. A light and fluffy meringue, with the tart lemon flavor, dare I say — it’s almost better than a key lime pie (shocker! as a Floridian.)
I was well into my study abroad and just completed my second session. Life was good, I was finally getting used to navigating the area, and made some good friends and memories. But I was longing for one of my favorite moments of my stay: my partner visiting me.
I purposely avoided a few attractions and restaurants to try when he got here, which included Skt. Peders Bageri, which translates to St. Peter’s bakery. A cozy bakery that hails as one of the oldest in Copenhagen, they’re known for their Wednesday snails (cinnamon rolls) that I regretfully did not try. I know nothing about authentic Danish food, but this certainly felt what ‘authentic’ would be.
I tried their plain croissant which was indubitably the BEST croissant I’ve had in my life (I think about it often..) and had to snag a blueberry pastry (pictured) as I saw a worker carry it out fresh from the oven.
Even trying my partner’s picks of pastries, every single item here was divine, fresh, heartwarming, perfectly sweet, with golden flaky crusts. This certainly ranks as the best bakery I tried on this list.
When I was down to a week left in Copenhagen, my friend and I scrambled to try the missing bakeries like Juno (pictured left), famous for its cardamom bun. This was the only bakery I waited an hour in line for. Would I say it was worth it? Maybe, if they had more options available.
But Juno sticks to what they do best and people line up for it, fostering this humming excitement waiting in line as people socialize — standing, sitting at tables, across the street if there’s no room — it feels like a hidden pocket of hygge [hue-gah], the epitome of Danish comfort and coziness.
I really was on my croissant high, trying one in both places, searching for a crust so flaky a knife would scrap across beautifully, a hint of sweetness and saltiness, and the soft multitude of layers inside.
After a long day of souvenir shopping my friend and I sat at Original Coffee, located in the heart of the Strøget shopping district. It’s located on the top floor of Illum, a department store, and serves as an excellent place to look at the city and reflect on the city.
We thought back on everything we got to experience and do, what we learned, whether would we even come back to Copenhagen, and when? What about a different place to study abroad? It certainly was a wistful atmosphere as we enjoyed our last few days being abroad.
My last ‘Danish’ meal before I headed to the airport to fly home, Joe and the Juice is the only place on this list that has a location back in the US. Their pricey smoothies and juices, along with the default Danish pastries, are available on every other corner of Copenhagen. They’re delicious and healthy. It’s no surprise that they’re one of the top food chains in Denmark.
Yet, it had me feeling nostalgic. Before coming to Copenhagen, I had heard and seen this chain but passed it off as a pricey, overly healthy spot that wasn’t worth going to.
However, coming to Copenhagen shook up my perspective on things, and now I was willing to try the very same spot in its original country. Studying abroad pushed me to try foods, and seek out places I would never go to back home. In Orlando, I’m so used to going to the same few spots, complaining about nothing new to do, and sending myself in the loop of my weekly routines.
But when I was in this brand new city, I was wide-eyed, ready to explore, and curious about each corner, hidden gem shawarma spot, an interesting castle, or nature an hour’s ride away.
I just hope to carry this newfound excitement in exploration as I explore my city and reminisce about my summer studying abroad in Copenhagen.
--
--

Title: The Infernal Comedy in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
The unique mix of one-man play and opera was in town. The always charismatic John Malkovich came with disturbing confessions, the sopranos Chen Reiss and Susanne Langbein sang beautiful opera arias, and the Vienna Philharmonic played Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven, Vivaldi to make sure to deliver an unforgettable experience.
The Story
The story is about Jack Unterweger, the serial killer, the writer; the unloved child.
He murdered prostitutes and was sentenced to life in prison. In prison, he started to write poems, plays, and short stories and eventually earned literary respect. Two Nobel laureates in literature (Günter Grass and Elfriede Jelinek) were campaigning for Unterweger’s release because they believed that he was the proof that even the most repulsive people can be converted through art. His biography called Purgatory became a bestseller. Convinced that he was a changed man, he got released on parole. While he was invited to talk shows and other events, he still strangled and murdered prostitutes in Vienna, Graz, Prague, and Los Angeles. The FBI caught him after two years, and after being sentenced again he killed himself in his cell.
This play is meant to be his second biography.

Title: Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
(a to-do list at the bottom)
A city that mostly moves to the rhythm of cycles. With 350km of bicycle tracks, it’s a city where legs and bicycles are synonymous. Silences and blank expressions can be easily mistaken for snobbery, while in fact being softness, simplicity, and kindness of the locals. The cinnamon swirls are sweet and the coffee is strong, old guys play chess in Wednesday evening clubs and old ladies bike by faster than both of us.
I was educated on what makes a city truly ‘emotionally intelligent’ by the architects of a smart city, and something they said that has become my rule to observe was that — a city is not defined by the buildings it has or makes, its energy is defined by the spaces “between” those buildings. Copenhagen is a city where urban development has been based on and around its nature and green cover- that’s really the true beauty of this place. They make it easy to carry luggage without using cars, to walk, bike to work or run back home through lakes and gardens without worrying about traffic or breaking rules. It is truly a sustainably intelligent city.
Areas in Copenhagen are spread out wide, and very self-sustained in terms of food, coffee, parks and culture. Someone living in Frederiksberg doesn’t need to come into Indre-by and someone in Christiania has no actual need to go into Vesterbro. While I loved the neighborhood local vibe of Norrebero and Frederiksberg, I did feel like my eventual place of stay around HC Andersons Boulevard. From airbnbs to eco-hotels, the average rate in Copenhagen doesn’t vary too much if you’re a last-minute nomad like me but I highly recommend at least 2 days in the hotel I stayed in (details at the bottom)
Eat & Drink- only my 2023 favorites, in no way exhaustive :)
Stay- my personal favorite is the Manon Les Suites Hotel — an eco hotel with the best of comfort meets conscious in a central location. If you prefer an Airbnb, check the ones around Norrebro and make sure you check step free access.
Getting Around- Rent an e-bike but not from a hotel.
Yoga - I’ll always check out yoga studios in every city as a personal rule and my favorite one here was ‘Rive Gauche’. The weekly pass makes it easier on the pocket than a one time pay.
Places to Run/Walk- The Lakes, Rosenborg Gardens, Frederiksberg Garden
Follow my journeys on instagram @upasg
--
--
I write, I dance, I surf and I travel, I work in storytelling.

Title: Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
3, Niels Hemmingsensgade www.stilleben.dk
6, Værnedamsvej www.playtype.com
61, Østergade www.hay.dk
Flæsketorvet 10 https://space10.io
Danish artist Monika Petersen studied illustration at St Martins College of Art and Design UK. Following her graduation, she worked in London for several years before returning to Copenhagen where she is now based.
Her work has been featured in many magazines including Elle, Cover and Rum. Her designs have also been used on products: wallpaper, cups, pillows and recently a billboard campaign for BIC.
Today Monika works as a printmaker. Working on a large printing press she produces open and limited edition Lino Prints depicting large bold shapes like; a giant yellow lemon or a single gold leaf.
In september 2015 she opened her own shop & showroom in central Copenhagen:
Gunløgsgade 7, kld tv, Islands Brygge, 2300 Copenhagen S
http://monikapetersen.com
You will find Designmuseum Danmark in the middle of Copenhagen’s historic centre, near tourist attractions, the harbour boats, design companies and galleries. We are the gateway to design destinations in Denmark and are right around the corner from Amalienborg Castle — the home of the Danish royal family — and the cafés and restaurants at Nyhavn.
Bredgade 68, DK-1260 København K
https://designmuseum.dk/en/
Finn Juhl was one of the leading figures in the creation of Danish Design, architect and designer and he would have turned 100 come 2012.
The Art museum Ordrupgaard celebrates the centenary of Finn Juhl. His private home built in 1942 — right next to Ordrupgaard — is open to the public.
Vilvordevej 110, 2920, Charlottenlund
ordrupgaard.dk/finn-juhls-hus/
Finn Juhl’s House | Visitcopenhagen
Established 1959, is a lithographic workshop and gallery space located in a 1000 m2 characteristic building in the Christianshavn district of Copenhagen.
Strandgade 66, 1401 Copenhagen K, www.editioncopenhagen.com
Paustian A/S Kalkbränderilöbskaj 2 DK-2100 www.paustian.com/
Grundtvigs Church was erected in commemoration of the great Danish priest, poet, and reformer N.F.S. Grundtvig (1783–1882). This monumental church is referred to in modern terms as a gothic cathedral. Master builder and architect Peder Vilhelm Jensen Klint (1853–1930) died before the church was finished. The task was entrusted to his son architect and designer Kaare Klint (1888–1954), who completed the building of the church in 1940. Kaare Klint has also designed the chairs for the Grundtvigs Church — a chair made of beech wood with wickerwork seat — a Danish furniture design classic. Despite its massive size, the church seems to exude an atmosphere of calm contentment. Perhaps it is the appeal of the regular yellow brickwork forming the sole decoration of the church.
På Bjerget 14 B 2400 København NV www.grundtvigskirke.dk
Conceived as an iconic building, which create awareness of cancer without stigmatizing the patients. Designed as a number of small houses combined into one, the center provides the space needed for a modern health facility, without losing the comforting scale of the individual. The houses are connected by raised roof shaped like a Japanese paper art origami, which gives the building a characteristic signature.
Nørre Allé 45, 2200 København N, Dinamarca
The close coexistence between private and communal spaces, often separated only by a thin door, makes this hall of residence quite unique. In fact, the dialogue between individuality and communality forms the very basis for the architecture and layout of Tietgenkollegiet.
Tietgenkollegiet was the result of an architecture competition organised by the Nordea Denmark Foundation with the intention of building a visionary version of the hall of residence of tomorrow. Lundgaard and Tranberg’s round building won the competition. On both the architectural and metaphorical fronts, it is all about inclusion, community and equality.
Rued Langgaards Vej 10–18, Ørestad North
Built for The Medical Association housing scheme and initially were known as Lægeforeningens Boliger. These well-built but relatively inexpensive houses for poor families were some of the first social housing in Copenhagen and were built on the initiative of doctor Emil Hornemann as an immediate and practical response to a cholera epidemic in Copenhagen in 1853.
Danish Architecture Centre
Strandgade 27B, 1401 København K, hwww.dac.dk/en
Cirkelbroen
Cirkelbroen celebrates pedestrians. It reflects the daily life and intimacy that you find around the canal in the Christianshavn neighbourhood, its houseboats and sailing boats, the unique life on the ramparts. Copenhagen’s harbour was once a centre of maritime activity, and Cirkelbroen is a testimony to that history. While working on the bridge, I remembered the fishing boats I saw as a child in Iceland. In the harbour, the boats were often moored right next to each other, and it sometimes seemed that you could even cross the harbour just by walking from boat to boat.
Christianshavns Kanal, København K
The Kalvebod Waves
When addressing this infamously gloomy and desolated side of the harbor, the architects put their focus on two major design aspects: to create urban continuity and to locate the new structure on the sunny spots in the water.
Facing Southeast, the quay has fantastic sun conditions until the early afternoon, but to attract the public after working hours the architects needed to study the course of the shadows casted by the huge buildings along the promenade. The two new main piers are located in the shadow-free zones and programmed as active islands on the water. The project then re-connects those islands to the urban network and to makes them blend naturally into the city’s infrastructure. Two bridges link the tip of the main piers back to the old quay, creating two inner water-basins for watersport activities.
Superkilen
Superkilen is a park that supports diversity. It is a world exhibition of furniture and everyday objects from all over the world, including benches, lampposts, trash cans and plants — requisites that every contemporary park should include and that the future visitors of the park have helped to select. Superkilen reattributes motifs from garden history. In the garden, the translocation of an ideal, the reproduction of another place, such as a far off landscape, is a common theme through time. As the Chinese reference the mountain ranges with the miniature rocks, the Japanese the ocean with their rippled gravel, or how the Greek ruins are showcased as replicas in the English gardens. Superkilen is a contemporary, urban version of a universal garden.
Radio House
Politikens Boghal
With two floors filled with books written in Danish and English, Politikens Boghal is fairly-often considered one of the top choices for book lovers in Copenhagen. The warm bookstore associated with Politiken, one of the largest newspapers in the country, has been welcoming locals and foreigners since 1915. On its selves, visitors can find old and new releases of everything from fiction and poetry to nature and hobby books. Moreover, special events such as concerts, speeches, and presentations take place regularly throughout the year attracting the city’s intellectual crowd.
Politikens Boghal, Rådhuspladsen 37, Copenhagen
Cinnober Bookstore
Cinnober has been standing in the heart of the city center for approximately 10 years. Its founders, Ulla Welinder and Morten Voigt, have a great passion for graphic design and illustration. Therefore, a big part of their book selection consists of magazines and books that showcase the best of design, architecture, and art. Make sure to stop by while exploring the area around the Round Tower and rummage through the bookstore’s collection of local artists’ prints and paper products. Visitors might even find a special souvenir to take back home.
Cinnober Bookstore, Landemærket 9, Copenhagen
Palermo Hollywood
The colourful tropical storm that is Palermo Hollywood is the brightest workspace and concept store in all of Nørrebro. Its a modern mash-up, where art and pop culture, sensuality and seriousness, fun and quality — and especially GOLD & GLITTER — go hand in hand. The shop stocks contemporary english books from modern feminism to colouring books, stylish stationary and selected fashion accessories. Pop on down and feel the vibes the girls are bound to make you smile.
Jægersborggade 31 Visit Website
Paper Island, Copenhagen’s New Design Neighborhood
A mix of creative businesses have moved into this previously concealed neighborhood including &tradition, which opened a new showroom here in August.
Trangravsvej, 1436 København K
108
A great addition to the Copenhagen food scene from the Noma family. Delicious seasonal fresh light food beautifully and creatively presented. Charming place at the canals and the atmosphere is fresh stylish and full of hygge.
108 Strandgade, 1401 København K https://108.dk
Fætter Fætter
Or cousin cousin is owned by the two cool cousins. While your cousin might not be there the tasty toasties and classy drinks will be. Take your guilty pleasures on a ride, you can snack a little or snack a lot these guys have the best atmosphere on the block. A simple snack will set you back 35 kr or upgrade to the “The Full On Experience” with their delirious “Fucking Toast”, “Veggie Toast” and a “Dressed Up Advokado,” with Honey Butter on Cinnamon toast for dessert. Bring a date or fly solo — you are in good hands.
Møllegade 8A, 2200 København N, Visit Website
Soundtrack: Jacob Bellens - Untouchable
--
--
Designer, modernist. Writing about good design, life and travel (en dos idiomas) www.danielvazquez.net
