Title: Palaeo, Copenhagen, Denmark
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Healthy. Organic. Paleo restaurant
Inspired by our latest trip to Berlin and how much wifey and I enjoyed the #SexyGood healthy delicious Simply Keto restaurant/cafe in Berlin, Germany, I realised how much I had enjoyed a similar experience last August when we had gone to Copenhagen Denmark.
The entire #SexyGood + links to the 3 visits to Simply Keto can be captured here https://medium.com/@abhijitpradhan/the-launch-of-the-true-life-metric-95a305856195
We had done a short 5 day trip to this amazing city for the following reasons
After paying homage to the Coffee Collective at their roastery outlet in Godthabsvej/Freidricksburg, we came to the famed Torvehallerne, the hip and happening food hall ( there are 2 big halls ).
And while hunting for lunch options, my eyes settled on Palæo which I had read about earlier. Luckily, as one could pick up food from any kiosk and sit together in one place, I didn’t have to worry about wifey, who was frankly not too interested in the place ! ( It took her a trip to Berlin last month to finally nudge her !). She looked at the different food options, but her attention quickly wandered off and she came back with a multi cheese platter as her lunch !
I went to the counter and the person taking orders was friendly and helpful. The place was more a snack/fast food/smoothie kind of place. Apparently there was a “restauranty” style Paleo outlet somewhere else in the city, but she told me the food was essentially the same.
I ordered a salad which was heavy on keto bread, avocado, nuts, berries, etc.
She suggested I go for the Sweet Potato chips. I did. And my main course was a “grass fed” Hot dog with the sausage wrapped in an egg omelette.
I was in seventh heaven as one did not get such treats back home-especially the grass fed hot dog !
The other thing that struck me after reaching Copenhagen was the sheer quality of their produce. Especially the vegetables. I told wifey that I could happily give up meat for ever, if I get a constant supply of such awesome vegetables. This theme continued throughout the trip and even in the Michelin starred restaurants that we ate in and loved, the vegetables were like from another planet !! #Swoon
Torvehallerne became a very convenient lunch spot for us. It was next to the hub station, Norreport, so it was connected to all places in the city ( Metro, train, bus) and dinners were strategically chosen and booked by wifey to feed her chef soul, so basically I got a license to have most of my lunches at Palæo ! Yay ! Think I did at least 3 :)
My favourite dish was discovered when I ordered their burger. The same friendly order taker told me the bread used for the burger was not as heavy as their regular bread as it used more seeds than nuts. Cool !
I loved it. The meat was obviously grass fed beef and from the first bite I was transported to my school days where my dream meal was in one of the fast food burger joints ( Hardees, Dairy Queen etc.) and my favourite dish used to the burger ( specifically the Mushroom & Swiss burger in Hardees).
I ensured that I had the burger again in my next and last visit here !
This experience gave me hope that Sexy and Good can co-exist and my recent trip to Berlin and Simply Keto has only reinforced that hope !! Also, it was heartening to know that Michelin star chef Thomas Rode Andersen was behind the design of the menu ! #SexyGood in action !https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/mar/02/fast-food-restaurant-caveman-diet-copenhagen
I had turned “Paleo” way back in 2012 and in fact tried to use that approach while running marathons but it didn’t work as after 30 k of running, the system would just revolt and scream for quick carbs. Energy gels, potatoes. I was eating more and more unhealthy stuff just to fuel my runs !
It was only in 2016 where I discovered “Keto” which actually gives me hope of plugging that energy crash issue that I always faced on the longer runs.
Paleo can be seen as High Protein ( which I realised was not actually good for me) + Low Carb + Low Fat whereas Keto is High Fat + Moderate Protein ( a crucial tweak) and Low Carb
When ( and if ) your body adapts to the High fat and low carb component of Keto, it slowly starts prefering to burn fat as a fuel ( which is far cleaner) rather than the extremely dirty and volatile carbs as source of fuel. I know now that if I had managed this during my marathoning days, it would have made a world of difference ! I don’t do long runs anymore as it took me a very long time to get over a knee injury and I realised that my body thrives on high intense short bursts of activity rather than the prolonged abuse that I was subjecting it to + after the recent Paris + Berlin trip, I re-connected with “walking” as it probably activates health in my system better than any other activity ! Wow.
The above is a short recap of how I arrived at #SexyGood in terms of diet, nutrition and exercise.
--
--
A Curator of PASSION + PERSPECTIVE translating them into INSIGHT for inspirational ACTION

Title: Three must-visit spaces for Art & Design in Copenhagen.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When this Airbnb host in London decided to be an Airbnb guest in design-conscious Copenhagen, he found much to be inspired by in the galleries and museums. If you’re also looking for design/art inspiration, here are three spots you should include when visiting Copenhagen. (Although just being in the city itself seems to activate latent design genes…)
The SMK houses 700 years’ worth of Danish and Nordic art and sculpture with a clear demarcation between the original architecture built in 1896 and the stunning, light-filled modernist section built 100 years later. If you like a chronological context, you can work your way from the front and understand the big themes through the centuries with clever diversions into more obscure and ‘problematic’ branches every so often.
A short train trip north of Copenhagen takes you to another repository of modern art in a stunning waterside setting, housed in an architectural marvel.
Louisiana (named after the original owners three wives, all named Louise) is a day trip in itself. The permanent collection boasts works by Picasso, Klein, Arp, Moore, Warhol, Hockney, Giacometti and oodles more. The current exhibitions included a immersive retrospective of Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama, Lucien Freud and ‘Africa’, a hugely thoughtful and surprising treatise on architecture, art and culture from the continent today.
If Copenhagen can’t have a stunning museum of design, what hope is there for anywhere else? The museum has the lofty twin ambitions to both serve ‘as a source of inspiration for people active in industry’ while making ‘contemporary consumers both critically aware and discerning’.
This translates of course into a whole lot of #chairporn…
So, despite ostensibly taking a break from London, Airbnb and design, I find myself filled with a better understanding of how Danish design works. Now to bring some of that all important hygge to Kith & Kine.
Kith & Kine is a stylish two-bed property close to all the hip/tech action in Shoreditch, London. Come and stay and see how far we’ve got recreating some Danish hygge…
--
--
Two rooms in London via @Airbnb. Ridiculously close to the tech action. Has vinyl. Some bovine branding (but it all makes sense). Chief cowboy = @endaguinan

Gabriela Trofin-Tatár
“Travel has been the fire that has shaped my current self, accumulating layers of complexity in my thinking, thoughts, and actions as a result of my journey’s successes and failures.” Gabriela Trofin-Tatár
My Erasmus University exchange in Odense, Denmark, during the spring semester of 2006 was an unforgettable chapter in my life. Immersed in the vibrant atmosphere of Tehnisk Kollegium, I discovered the power of collaborative learning through teamwork, an experience that would profoundly shape my educational journey.
Moreover, during the semester, I traveled both in Denmark and abroad, expanding my horizons and becoming more curious about my studies.
In the following sections, I invite you to read about events and places that had a positive impact on my love for Denmark and my cultural awareness during that time.

Title: Here Is My Alternative Tourist Guide To Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Supporting new writers to the Medium platform

Member-only story
--
2
Share
I am not often in Copenhagen. It is a one-hour drive from where I live. And I can get my shopping and entertainment needs covered closer to home. But I do go there occasionally. And when I do, I see reminders of our racist past everywhere.
I will start with a disclaimer. I am a white dude, who is soon approaching 40. I am a history buff. And I have always tried to fight racism where I can. But I am aware I can not fully escape my racist history.
Many Europeans acknowledge the blatant racism in the U.S. But they falsely believe that it is a uniquely American problem. It is not. The slave ships that brought these slaves to the U.S. sailed from our harbors.
Racism is a European invention. We had to invent it in order to justify our atrocities against people of color. And guess what. We think our invention was so smart, that we Europeans call the historic period where we shipped slaves and exploited our colonies “The Age of Enlightenment”.
Yes, racism is systemic. And trying to censor this truth in our classrooms will not make it untrue.

Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

En samling af artikler til inspiration for #ResponsiveOrg interesserede i Danmark

--
Listen
Share
Based on a meeting in Copenhagen, one call to Australia, a number of tweets, Linkedin and Yammer posts, the word was spread and the first #ResponsiveOrg meetup in Copenhagen became reality Thursday 27. November 2014 — read about the preparation here ,
Eager to meet the people who signed up for #ResponsiveCoffee in Copenhagen on Meetup.com I got to the cafe about 30 minutes early…
tables where placed in a corner, and the coffee was just about to brew — we where ready to meet.
All interested and curious we gathered and the talking started by one to one introductions as people showed up, then the non existing agenda developed in this way:
6 men joined — Kenneth has listed ResponsiveOrg Copenhagen relevant tweets here — and here are the names of the 6 men at the first meetup
admitted - it looks a bit as a bunch of..
“..handsome, thoroughly clever, perfectly plump men in our prime” as Karlsson on the roof says
The conversation touched diversity and all agreed it is needed for future meetups. Also discussing the need for a meetup in english, which is obviously is an option if non Danish-speaking wants to join — please let us know at meetup.com or as a comment here.
I am not really sure, but I know that I have found likeminded people whom I want to share my experiences with, and I am sure they will share interesting angles on topics that relates to #futureofwork, #ResponsiveOrg, #worklikeanetwork — add the # you like, or tell the story as Matt Partovi
http://player.vimeo.com/103393370
One thing it instantly brougth was Kenneths scoop.it on Leadership a ressource of inspiration for future topics, and so much more.
And the all participants was featured in this tweet
Wanting to get into a series of meetups, the next meetup is planned as #ResponsiveMorning for the 14. January at 9:30 - you can signup via meetup.com
Do you want to give a 10 minute speak about a topic you care about? If so suggest a topic for the meetup, and suggest a topic anyway.
A big thanks to all of you showing up, and for those of you who showed interested but couldn’t find the time, come by in the future.
To all of you who liked, retweetet and shared the posts to make the noise — most appreciated!

Title: On re-routes and rainy Copenhagen days
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
August 4, Sabbatical Day 23
Sunday did not go at all like I had planned. I walk out of my apartment at 10:40am, planning to bike to church (that starts at 11am), only for rain drops to start falling. So I pivot to taking the train … only that adds to my travel time and makes me 10 minutes late to church. And I’m sleepy in my movie-theater seat in the back of the auditorium, fighting heavy eyelids. And if we’re being honest, I don’t get much out of the guest pastor speaking.
But I’ve still got the entire day, right? Only it’s pouring when I walk out of church, so I linger a little longer in the lobby, game-planning my day on my phone.
Church attendees are slowly making their way out (this church takes place in a hotel conference center). And one makes it’s way over to me. Glasses, ash-blonde air a little ruffled, lanky and crooked smile. No rain jacket.
“Were you at Hillsong?” He asks in heavily accented English.
“Yes, I’m visiting Copenhagen and every time I’ve come to the city before, I have come to church here.”
He proceeds to tell me that he just moved to Copenhagen last week from Bratislava, Slovakia. He’s staying in a hostel now, but wants to live by the beach. He tells me about the bike he bought from a guy a month ago (the guy just left it on the street for him to buy!), and how it was locked up on the street for the last month waiting for his return. I tell him about my journey to Copenhagen, my sabbatical.
Eventually I see the rain lightening up, and say my goodbyes. I walk off to the metro, planning on taking it to Norrebro to get this focaccia sandwich I dreamed about getting last visit. And just as I make it down the escalator, I hear an alarm going off.
“Evacuate immediately,” it says.
So everyone makes there way back up the elevator, crowing under the metro awning outside, because — mind you — it’s still raining. Sirens start in the distance, and a fire truck rounds the corner.
I make the call to try for the bus instead, since clearly this train station won’t be opening back up anytime soon. I walk back past the church, past the Slovak, and to a bus station a block away. The bus is 10 minutes late, but finally arrives. By this point, it’s nearing 2pm, and the sun has broken through — you’d hardly know it was so nasty 30 minutes ago.
I get my focaccia sandwich from Rondo, inhale it, and start walking back to my apartment to pick up my bike. I think I take a wrong turn somewhere along the way, because it’s taking longer than I anticipated. I’m cutting through Fælledparken, and start realizing — if I want to go visit Grundtvigs church, I need to do it now, since they close at 4 and are closed Monday. So once again, I backtrack to the bus station. And what do you know, the heavens open up midway. I wait under a tree for a couple minutes, waiting for it to lighten up, then make my way to the bus stop. The bus is late, which I’m starting to realize is a Copenhagen trend. I start seeing a bunch of people walking in the same direction with jerseys, and realize there’s a match on today. Do I want to go? I calculate the time it takes to get to the church, take a quick spin, then go back to my apartment to change, then go to the game. It’s a lot, so I decide against. This is all being thought through while I’m on the bus.
Eventually I get to the church … only to walk up and find that it’s closed due to water damage. And honestly, I’m more bummed about the hour of travel time round trip than the actual church being closed.
So I make my way back to my apartment, changing out of my church clothes and swapping my bag for coffee shop books and journals. There’s one right around the corner from my apartment that a guy from Hagen Espresso in London recommended. It’s pretty full for 4pm when I get there, so I snag a seat inside since there’s not a seat open outside to enjoy this gorgeous weather.
But right after my drink is delivered, one does open up, so I gather up my bag and cortado and relocate. I’m sitting outside for around 20 minutes before I see a young guy — who I think is not Danish — walk into the shop. He’s by himself, wearing a Cyprus cap, along with a green market tote bag.
He sits at the table to left of me, back to the street, while I’m facing the street, Mere Christianity in hand. I keep eying him — do I make conversation with this fellow traveler? After all, sometimes I’ve found some of my best travel moments behind starting a conversation. But how to start — do I ask him about Cyprus?
At this point, I pull out my phone that’s plugged into my power bank. And that’s my opening (or rather, his).
“Do you have a USB-C cable?” He asks, once again in accented English. “I have a power bank, I just need the cord.”
And this, reader, is where I thank God once again that I bought a power bank with several types of cords.
“No, but this has one in it. Here, you take it,” I insist. “Are you visiting Copenhagen?”
“Yes, I just arrived today.”
“Oh, and where are you from?”
“I’m from Ukraine, but I’m living in Italy now.”
“Oh, where in Italy?” I ask, thinking about my January trip there.
Outside of Florence, he tells me. “I’ve hitch-hiked here from Florence.”
Cue my jaw dropping.
“I first went to Berlin, where I stayed with some friends. Then hitchhiked here. I wanted an adventure, and I had things that I wanted to figure out for life. But now I think I know what I need to do next, so I’m going to just fly home. Plus hitchhiking is exhausting.”
The conversation that follows is not one that I could have predicted.
I find out more about his life — He lived in Italy from 2019 to February 2022, making money so he could come back to Ukraine flush with cash — rich in their eyes. This is when he says he thought his dream, ideal life would start. But he didn’t have to explain it too much — Russia invaded a month later. Eventually he got out of Ukraine (which he didn’t explain, but I know means avoided being conscripted). Back to Italy, working in services industry — a textile manufacturer, I think.
He said his life was comfortable, but he didn’t want to blink and life fly by. I asked him what his realization was, and he answered, “I need to leave Italy.” He has various gripes with Italy and Italians — lack of openness and diversity, lack of parks, lack of opportunities to connect with others. He also doesn’t know what to do work wise — he’s tried a lot of different things.
I couldn’t help but think at this point — “Oh buddy. You’re searching for a happy life, but that’s never going to satisfy.”
I ask him what brings him joy, and he says talking with people — at some points he struggles to find the words in English. He likes providing advice, or crisis management, as he says.
He asks about me, too. I tell him about my sabbatical, about processing life, what I want to do next.
“How satisfied are you with your life? Put a number on it.”
I tell him that while I love my life, of course there are things I’d love to be different. I’d love to be married, I’d love for experience physical healing. 75%, I say.
“That’s pretty high.”
We talk some about singleness — I say there are things I could not do if I was married. Like working with the youth kids that bring me so much joy. I probably could not do a trip like this if I was married. That’s when I’m surprised to find out he’s married (no ring). Just left his wife back in Italy to hitchhike for a bit.
I explain that in the south in the U.S., people get married younger. My sisters both married young.
“Do you feel pressure to? From your family?” He asks.
“Not really.” It’s more the pressure of my own timeline. But my parents don’t quite understand the different world I am dating in, and find themselves befuddled that being asked out is so non-existent for so many of my friends.
We shut the coffee shop down, and move to a bench next door. At some point, he has me follow him on Instagram so we can keep up with one another. How much, we’ll see. Near the end of our conversation, he asks me, “So what’s your plan from here?”
I clarify — “Do you mean for today, this trip, or my life?”
“For your life.”
Oof. How to answer this?
“Here’s the thing, I can make plans for my life, but ultimately, I could die tomorrow –“ He recoils a bit at this — “I mean, I hope not, but I know where I would be if I did. And here’s the thing, as great as all this is,” I wave my hand at the street in front of me, “Heaven is better. So I can make plans, my life is not my own. My life belongs to God. He has plans for me. One of the things I love about God is I can do x or y, but he’s going to use it regardless for my good and his glory.”
He’s watching me as I talk and I don’t know if I’ve entirely lost him. I feel the need for honesty not pontifications.
“Listen, is it easy to say that? Absolutely not. I want to be tight fisted with my life. I have to remind myself regular to let go, because I know his plan for me is so much better.”
He doesn’t respond to any of this, and that’s okay. I don’t need him to. The conversation peters out some from there — but before we part, I ask to take his picture and he acquiesces.
We stand — he’s VERY TALL — and bends at both the knees and the waist to give me a very awkward hug. “Don’t die tomorrow,” he tells me.
I smile at that, and tell him I’ll try not to.
I walk off in the direction of the grocery, reeling a bit. Did the last hour and a half just happen? I’ve never had a conversation with a stranger like that before.
I rewind through my day — the delays and redirects and ending up at Prolog Coffee outside at 4pm. It would be easy to look at my encounter with Bogdan (that’s his name) in a silo. But I can see the fingerprints streaking across the window of my day, and I can see how the fact that I ended up there was not happenstance. Who knows if any of that will stick with him, but it was as much for me as it was for him.
There’s this rewiring starting to happen inside of me on this trip.
Life with God is an adventure. I’ve said that before, but I’ve thought about it more in the large-scale sense. Adventure of career, dating, etc.
But now, now I’m starting to realize that every day is an adventure. To look at the margins — or lack of — and invite him in. Surprise me, God.
--
--
I heard someone say once that they had “a curiosity that spans the universe.” And I thought, “That’s me.”

Title: I Found Happiness (In Denmark) By Getting A… Bicycle
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Heartfelt, down-to-earth and real stories by women for women. Support our lovely Modern Women editing team @ ko-fi.com/modernwomen

Member-only story
--
38
Share
When I arrived in Copenhagen six years ago, after a particularly hard year in New York, I needed to regroup, re-think and reinvent myself. I was stressed out, exhausted and confused — everything you’d expect a New Yorker to be. My salvation came from the most unexpected source — a bicycle.
If in New York cycling was saved for hipsters, exercise fanatics and tourists at that time, in Copenhagen, it was (and is) the main mode of transportation. Bike roads run alongside car roads there, with dedicated traffic lights, and bicyclists are respected and given priority. In return, they obey strict rules and laws. The whole thing is very civilized. No yelling, no honking, no confusion.
After two weeks of taking overpriced buses like a tourist and gawking at masses of bicycles at intersections, I gave in and bought a used bike. Little did I know, my rusty two-wheeled companion was to become my best friend in Denmark’s cold capital and my best chance at finding happiness.

Title: Underground Bands — Hypnos, Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My old friend Kathrine invited us to stay with her a while at her new tiny house in Copenhagen. For our first night out, she looked at a number of options: There was a weird performance art piece by The Center for Militant Futurologi, drummers were needed for a climate change demonstration on two tallships sailing down whatever the big river in the middle of the city is called (I swear I can’t find this information anywhere), and a jam session was brewing in Freetown Christiania. Kathrine said her best bet was a metal show at a small bar called Lygtens Kro, with a headliner from Sweden (Gothenburg, naturally) who played in the style of the 1980s. “Power metal?” I asked, and her boyfriend said that sounded right to him. I became partly acquainted with the numerous highly-specific metal subgenres back in my nightclub days, and I do my best to keep up as the lexicon matures; but I’m never sure what names to use.
So we met at the Metro station, hit the bar, and got a round of Golden Ladies (a slightly-higher-priced form of Tuborg lager, analogous to ordering a Miller Genuine Draft instead of a Miller High Life). The opening band, I thought, was good but not great. They could use a new guitarist. Still, it was enjoyable enough, stoner rock with a vein of grunge in there that might have resulted more from a lack of rehearsal than an aesthetic choice. I figured this was what would be on the menu tonight. I couldn’t have been more wrong. After a short set break, during which I smoked a comically tiny joint outside, the headliners took the stage sans announcement and began to play. I happened to be near the door that was nearest the stage, headed straight in, and got myself an enviable position in the very front of the room to see and hear a band called Hypnos.
Holy shit, these boys could play. There was an Iron Maiden thing happening, sometimes escalating into Queensryche territory or putting its root down into Soundgarden. If you know those bands, then a certain kind of metal vocals are playing in your head now that speaks to a certain era of rock — “No one sings like you anymore,” as the late great Chris Cornell lamented — and you’re right on the money. This singer Linus Johansson was extra fun — a sensuous and playful front man with frizzy blond hair and a porno mustache, with a voice like Geoff Tate and moves like Robert Plant, graceful arms and serpentine torso, with penetrating eye contact at such close quarters. This bar didn’t even have a stage, so I was just standing right in front of these guys, able to really get into what the players were doing, and they were doing plenty. The lead guitarist, Pontus Isebring, was positively fucking rad, an inspired shredder in a paroxysm behind his veil of dark brown hair yet locked in tight with the rhythm section. To call them a rhythm section is to undersell them a bit, in fact: The younger-looking second guitarist Oskar Wersall often harmonized with solos and melodies note for note, leaving the chugging rhythmic floor to dead-serious bassist Anton Kallmin; and even that mustachioed and muttonchopped warrior was doing some pretty fancy shit when space opened up on the bottom end. Drummer Oskar Brindmark was a beast and a scientist, not a drop of sweat on his brow as he assembled and deconstructed patterns with breakneck speed. They were one sick five-piece metal outfit, my friends. This isn’t even my kind of music, particularly, but I know greatness when it’s blasting me in the face.
It wasn’t all about technical chops, either. Part of what made Hypnos so much fun to watch was that they were all having so much fun, enjoying one another’s company on stage in a way that lots of bands fail to do even in their honeymoon years. Anton and Oskar W. stepped in to share backup vocals on a single mic, eyes flashing and heads bobbing at one another. Linus couldn’t get enough of Pontus’ solos — every time the latter cut loose, the former sidled up real close and let his own fingers wiggle up and down his mic stand in a celebratory air guitar dance that brought to mind Bowie/Ronson in the Spiders From Mars years. I guess this singer isn’t even the original guy — he joined the band in 2017 — but having watched them play I can hardly imagine Hypnos without him. That this band remains so infatuated with the stage and with each other on their fifteenth year of performing says much about their special chemistry, and for an audience member it makes all the difference.
At the end of the set, Linus asked us to make sure and buy something at the merch table. “We don’t have any money!” he cheerfully informed us. Sadly, I hadn’t a dime to spare at that very broke point in my own independently-booked tour of Europe; so the best I could offer was my congratulations and this article. Hypnos seems to be on tour at all times, releasing music on The Sign Records that you can buy right now and generally doing the work of a rock and roll band in the prime of life. You should find an opportunity to see them play live, ideally in a small venue, and bring enough cash for the CD or the t-shirt or whatever. Folks like us are out here scraping by in 21st-century showbiz, even living metal gods from Sweden, and time shovels dirt over all of us soon enough. It’s up to the fans to keep the scene alive. As long as there are heads in the club, Hypnos is sure to keep them banging.
--
--

Content:

Member-only story

2
Share
by Jim Baggott
[Note from Massimo: This article by my friend Jim Baggott is a bit on the technical side. But if you care about our deep understanding of the world, or about the nature of science, or about the relationship between science and philosophy, enjoy.]
I read Massimo’s essay “Physicists don’t know what the world is like, at bottom” (29 May 2020, also here) with considerable interest. And no little frustration. In the epilogue of my new book Quantum Reality (published in the US in September) I close with a brief analysis of a survey of attitudes on the interpretation of quantum mechanics that was conducted among physicists in 2011. Massimo’s essay concerned a more recent (and more extensive) survey published in 2016, which I’d overlooked. Thankfully, in most respects both surveys produced similar results.
Massimo observed that, despite all the popular media attention given to fantastical interpretations which invoke the existence of multiple, parallel universes, the Copenhagen interpretation remains the most favored. (And I heaved a sigh of relief, as this was true also in 2011.)
But what I found even more fascinating is that the 2016 survey, conducted by Sujeevan Sivasundaram and Kristian Hvidtfelt Nielsen at Aarhus University in Denmark, included questions which allowed them to go beyond this simple statement of…

Title: What is Day Zero? The Adventure Begins. [Copenhagen, Denmark]
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
It’s Monday, the start of a new week. Nat and I are both working at our desks, which at this moment is a small wooden kitchen table in our Airbnb in Vesterbro. The sun is shining into the living room after a split second downpour — after less than two days here we’ve already come to understand this is totally normal. Not your typical tropical rainstorm, but a charismatic part of the city I’ve embraced rather quickly. Ask me again in a couple of weeks…
We arrived on Saturday evening. After meeting our Airbnb host, who was very friendly and helpful, we unpacked quickly into our home for the next 3 weeks and took advantage of the late-setting sun to wander around our neighborhood. Copenhagen hasn’t been short of hubbub since we landed: Saturday was the Pride Parade; Rapha Nocturne, a nighttime cycling race ironically hosted in London for the past 10 years, was set up a few blocks away; and IRONMAN had its triathlon all throughout the city yesterday. We made our way through the liveliness to explore what Vesterbro had to offer, with the not-too-distant goal of finding a place for dinner, too.
The main street was decorated with rainbow leaflets and cutouts from the Parade, but ultimately, pretty desert when compared with the West Village in New York in June. To be fair, Pride in Copenhagen is a full 5-day event including open-air concerts, Drag Night and After-Pride Chill Out… no need for post-Parade rowdiness, even if it is a Saturday night. We walked by a few cool-looking bars and restaurants... lots of starring on our Google Maps for future ventures… and got drawn to a place called Madklubben for dinner.
There was a huge line outside — a large group of ladies waiting to get seated — which, as my Dad always says, is always a good sign a place is worth trying (not the ladies, but the line…). We waited at the bar for a table and got served by two very suave, attractive Danish men, shaking their shakers in unison and making stoic yet flirtatious conversation with the single New Yorker sitting next to us. Nat got a beer.
Dinner was delicious, though the stools not too comfortable. Guess that’s what you get when you go to a “minimal spot for unfussy dining” (quote from Google).
Next stop: a drink! It was Saturday night after all. We tried a speakeasy called Duck & Cover but they had no space — not packed, just full. Another night, perhaps. Instead, we headed to CURFEW, which had the coolest signpost at the entrance. A horizontal cutout with a light shining through, projecting the bar’s name on the wall. And a spider, fairly large, dangled comfortably. We almost believed it was fake.
Is this day zero? I asked Nat, not wanting to give up our first day so soon.
Nat ordered one of CURFEW’s award-winning drinks — key ingredients: Tanqueray gin, tarragon and mango — and I went for a refreshing alcohol-free fizz. Big mistake. Nat likes to say I’m a cheap date because I don’t like to drink, but considering how delicious this Little Dragon was, my new theory is I take only the best.
The vibe was perfect. 1920s Prohibition style, matching music, bartenders in suspenders… Nat and I didn’t even talk, we just enjoyed the moment.
The next day, it’s really day one. Or day two… I haven’t decided yet. We rented bikes — the only way to travel in Copenhagen — and Nat mapped out a whole itinerary for us. Christiansborg Palace, Rundetaarn, Botanic Gardens… today, we’re tourists, not just digital nomads. We ate lunch at Torvehallerne and biked to Kastellet, a 17th-century fortress on a star-shaped island. It seemed like anywhere we biked, another beautiful palace, church or building was there, waiting for us. This city is just stunning.
www.instagram.com
The surprising thing is we’ve adjusted so quickly. 48 hours in, we feel like we know our neighborhood decently well; we’ve gone to and made friends at our first CrossFit class at Butcher’s Lab; we’ve cooked our first meal and slept the best couple of nights we’ve had in weeks. As this first work day comes to a close, I’ve finally settled on a name for my poetry project, Midnight Plume (you’ll notice the first sneak peek in this post). I’ll properly launch it this week. I hope you’ll follow along… it’s quite personal and something I’ve thought of doing for quite some time. I’m so excited to finally share it.
And while I’m not yet sure how this travel blog will take shape, this hereby concludes my first post. I’m sure I’ll include more places and spaces we’ve seen and loved, and I hope to dive more into the feelings and questions intrinsic to this adventure. Thanks for reading, and see you soon! ***
--
--
1
Writer, poet, traveller, marketer. Loves music, theatre, literature, fitness. Will never say no to karaoke.

Title: Away from the Dan — Copenhagen Marathon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In the last two years running has occupied a great place in his life. All this time, I slowly, slowly walked the small steps to the next goal — to run a marathon.
Preparation began in the farthest February: I trained and participated in competitions that interested me. But he tried to plan his running calendar for 2019 so that the peak of training and running occurred in April and early May. And so it turned out: at this time I ran three half marathons (Poznan, Slavutych and Białystok), one run in Brovary 11 km and 30 km. in Kharkov. The latter was important before the marathon, as he had to show how my body would respond to heavy loads.
Although at first I wanted to stop at the Prague Marathon, but its start coincided with the Bialystok Half Marathon. The problem was that this year he decided to run the “Crowns of Polish Half Marathons” and the “Bialystok Half Marathon” was on the list of this series. After thinking about the month, he preferred the Bialystok Half Marathon over the Prague Marathon.
Two Scandinavian marathons in Stockholm and Copenhagen caught my attention. Having long wanted to visit Denmark, I stopped at the Copenhagen Marathon. He also started 40 times and had an interesting route.
You can register for the marathon on the marathon page: http://cphmarathon.com. There you had to fill in your details (name and name; country; contact details; if there was experience in marathons, approximate time for which you were going to run 42 km). You could also choose the size of a T-shirt. After paying the starting fee, the system automatically assigns a starting number. The marathon route was held in one circle by the central and surrounding streets of Copenhagen, passing by the main architectural monuments of the Danish capital.
Ancient packages can be banned on Friday, Saturday and Sunday before the marathon starts.
After paying for the starting number, getting acquainted with the route of the marathon, it is time to plan the trip itself, that is, buy airline tickets and book accommodation. I decided to fly to Copenhagen on Friday night to have a free Saturday and get to know the city a bit, visit the Sport Expo and pick up the starter pack in advance.
Arriving in Copenhagen on Friday evening, my route ran from the airport to my place of residence, and at the same time enjoyed a stroll in Copenhagen in the evening.
The main task of Saturday was to find the starting number, so I followed him in the morning. The extradition took place at the Sparta Hallen Sports Complex, which also hosted the Sport Expo, Kids Running. To get the desired starter pack, you need to have a passport and a certificate from the participant who came to the mail after registering for the marathon.
The first half of Saturday came with the launch pack and the Sport Expo. The latter is well organized: in addition to the usual sports goods and equipment, there was a lot of interesting information about various marathons in the world.
After the preparation for the marathon was over, it was time for a walk in the city, a little evening jog and rest before the marathon.
I decided to run the marathon only with water and isotonics without gels, so in the evening I bought them at a local supermarket.
Sunday morning was good weather. Especially in the morning when the sky above the city was overcast and everything was indicating possible rain. This could not but rejoice, because in the heat did not really want to run.
The starting town is spread out on the waterfront on the island of Bruges. Immediately it was possible to use the cameras, get the start numbers, change clothes. In the morning, the runners began to gather here, the closer they got to the start, the more and more they became. Someone dressed up, someone kneaded before the marathon, and someone admired the views of Copenhagen, which opened from the waterfront.
All marathon participants were divided into sectors according to their time of running the marathon. The marathon runner could choose his own time before the start, unlike the Polish races, where the participant must start in the group that he chose at registration. The starting numbers were all the same and not divided into sectors by color. And the runner himself before the start chose in which sector and for what time he wants to run.
The marathon started at 9:30. The participants gradually started to run one solid mass, which again was not very convenient at the beginning of the marathon. For myself, I chose place-holders for 4 hours 10 minutes and tried to hold on to them.
The first half of the marathon was easy enough, it ran comfortably. First, the route is almost flat, with only a few climbs. Secondly, it was overcast, starting to get clear by 12 noon.
He used the hydration points constantly as soon as he met them on his way. The first part of the marathon I tried to hold on to the placemakers. In 2 hours 2 minutes I overcame the first half of the track. The movement to the finish went well. The second part of the marathon started under a very beautiful arch, informing the runners that half the distance had been passed.
The next psychological boundary after the 21 km mark was 19 miles for me. Why this mark? Mainly due to the fact that I had already overcome the 30 km distance during the Easter run in Kharkiv and knew the approximate time of its passage and that I would not encounter any problems in overcoming this distance.
One of the main tests besides the 42 km mark itself, the physical and psychological strain was a 15-mile climb to the trestle. Psychology has played even more here. The experience gained during the same “Kharkiv Half Marathon” became relevant when you just ran down one hill and you were already waiting for a descent and a new one. Another such rise was not very much wanted to overcome on its way.
I overcame the second psychological mark of 19 miles in 3 hours and 10 minutes, which again is good — in Copenhagen I spent 1 minute longer than in Kharkiv. Running towards the finish line was in the planned rhythm. The distance was 4:10–4:20 because one hour would be enough to cover 7 miles of the route. Although these are all theoretical calculations that do not always coincide with what is happening in practice. The closer I was to the finish line, the more I met on the sidelines of the runners, whose parameters were brought back to normal, and the slower I started to run.
The last 7 miles could already be described as running from one hydration station to another, where you could drink a little water, isotonics, and some to eat a banana or orange. It was a little distracting from fatigue. For those 7 miles, I stuffed everything I had just encountered along the way: from the Danes’ pizza to redbull. At about 39–40 km I began to save power, although it was difficult to find them here, which would make the last dash that would have taken me over the finish line.
A preliminary detail about the runners was in store for a surprise: a minor row on the bridge. When he appeared on the horizon, in the main sense the thought was: “it does not fit, although it is small, but I do not want to draw”. the last test, after using the descent and the finish line.
There were fans on the side of the road, adding strength to the run. From this atmosphere and the thought that even a little more and you will see the cherished word “Finish”, the forces do not understand where they came from.
After 4 hours 48 minutes of running and overcoming 42 km of my feet, I was still brought to the coveted arch with the inscription “Finish”. There I was waiting for the restoration of strength with delicious fruits, hot chocolate, cola, pastries. And most importantly — it was possible to take a breath and already nowhere to escape.
My first marathon fully met all expectations. He presented wonderful emotions, both from the run itself and from the atmosphere that dominated it. It was extremely nice to run near the Embassy of Ukraine in Denmark, where there were Ukrainians. The hometown flag is especially inspiring in the second round, when you are already exhausted and looking for some positive things to move on. A very well thought out route along the main architectural monuments of Copenhagen, the whole route is accompanied by fierce support of residents and visitors of the city. After the finish, there are a lot of different flavors for everyone to recover, as well as massages and showers. The task for this marathon was first and foremost to run it without injury so that it would not be the last.
In the beginning, I wanted to run better and finish in the range of 4:10–4:20, but in the process it goes to the background and the bar is already reduced to 5 hours — the main thing that would be no injury.
The Copenhagen Marathon has taken management to a new level of development as a runner, so in the last northern year marathons will take their place in my two main calendars.
--
--
I love running and travel. And describe your impressions on your blog: androshchuk.com

Title: Fanboying in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A travel journal by Brian Lange

--
Listen
Share
an artist, a brewery, a restaurant
I’ve spared you the gory details on most of my other museum visits, but I have to write a little about Olafur Eliasson’s installation Riverbed at the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art (located about 30 minutes outside of Copenhagen by train) because Eliasson is one of my favorite artists. Earlier on my trip I saw his Turner color studies at the Tate Britain — painted perfect gradients of colors sourced from famous J.M.W Turner paintings onto donut-shaped canvasses. But before Riverbed, I’d never seen an installation by Eliasson. He makes a lot of different types of art, but his installations are what he’s best known for.
Riverbed is, on its face, very simple. You walk down a hallway with boardwalk flooring into a typical museum art gallery. White walls, well lit, etc. The floor in the gallery, however, has been transformed into a virtual riverbed, covered with smooth stones of various size. An actual trickle of water running through the whole thing, cascading down the steeper bits of rocks where there are stairs. And it’s not just a layer of gravel that’s been thrown down; the floor has significant topography, and seems to ignore the walls and doorways of the gallery space.
There’s no designated path through the landscape, you just kind of wander until reaching a reading room at the end, at which point you must turn around and exit the way you came in. It’s natural but very sparse, much like the photographs of Iceland Eliasson published in a new book also debuted at the exhibit. Perhaps more than anything, this exhibit made me really want to go to Iceland sometime.
It’s art that’s participatory and immersive; as a visitor you are part of it, and it’s all around you. It’s not confined behind proximity sensors or crowds of people; you literally get to walk all over it.
I also think the practice of creating simulated nature inside an art museum space is interesting. You can look at it as a sly middle finger to stuffy gallery spaces, or a statement that natural beauty deserves to be examined with the scrutiny that manmade art is. Or maybe it’s just meant to be a meditative spot. In an interview about the piece, Eliasson said “It’s about exposing yourself to time, to things taking time. The walking is time unfolded.”
Personally, I did find it to be meditative. It’s funny how just putting something inside a museum makes you pay more attention to it than you might otherwise. Writing about it now, after my trip is over, I still remember the feeling and sound of walking over the layer of rocks, and watching others do the same. Eliasson’s first exhibition at MoMA was titled Take Your Time, and you get the feeling that’s what he wants you to do here too.
Still, I get that it’s not for everybody. I heard somebody upon reaching the end say “That’s it?” Some of his installations deal more with doing impressive things with light, mirrors, color, and haze. I would love to see some of those too, but I thought Riverbed was pretty cool.
Also in the museum was a theater showing some of Eliasson’s films and, and one of my favorite parts, a “model room”. The model room is essentially a table covered with hacked-together bits of wire, 3D-printed plastic, foam core, and other materials. It’s rare to see an exhibit focus so much on process and intermediate products, and I love seeing that stuff. It reminds you that works don’t just get conjured out of nothing, and gives you a peek into what the tables at Eliasson’s large Berlin studio must look like.
I highly recommend exploring some of the stuff he’s done using “Your uncertain archive” on his website. Even if you’re not interested in Eliasson, it’s a really cool piece of web design.
OK. So I’m done gushing about an artist. Time to gush about something else. I have also spared you the gory details of food and beer I’ve had on my trip thus far, but this place also requires an exception to be made.
The first time I ever heard about Mikkeller, I was with friends at the excellent Northdown Tavern in Chicago. After a couple drinks, our probably drunk bartender leaned in and started speaking in a hushed tone. “Listen. You guys wanna try some really good shit?”
Of course we did. He brought out a fantastic beer by Evil Twin Brewing (Imperial Biscotti Break Natale — Pretty Please With A Cherry On Top, for all the beer nerds out there) and mentioned that the brewery was called Evil Twin because the guy was the twin brother of the guy who started Mikkeller. “Between the two of them,” he said, “they’re making some of the best beer in the world.” In my experience thus far, he’s right.
A couple days into my Copenhagen visit I remembered that Mikkeller was based in Copenhagen. While I couldn’t find any sort of brewery tour type of thing, they do have a few bars sprinkled around the city, and a new restaurant that specializes in smørrebrød– Danish open-faced sandwiches. I was sold.
The place is called Øl & Brød (pronounced oel og broed… yeah, good luck with that), aka “beer & bread”. The interior is very hip– extremely well decorated, with an almost comically meticulous table setting and Scandinavian rock played over the speaker at the host’s podium. In addition to having several taps of delicious beer from Mikkeller and others, they also have the most extensive Akvavit (a spiced Scandinavian liquor) list of any bar in Northern Europe. Didn’t get around to sampling any of that though.
I wanted to get a real Danish delicacy, so I went for the pickled herring sandwich which was topped with fennel, cabbage, apples, and onions in various states (pickled, grilled, raw) and aioli, piled on top of a slice of very dense, dark rye bread. I took the menu’s recommendation (it has beer pairings for everything they sell) and got a glass of Boon unblended lambic beer to go with it. You’ll hear more about lambics when I write about Belgium, but the way they’re brewed makes them tart or even sour, which was perfect for complimenting the pickled bits of the sandwich and cutting through the creamy/oily bits.
After the meal I walked next door to the Mikkeller bar, tried a few tasters of beer, and talked with a pilot from Phoenix, AZ who was stopping by on his day off. Beer nerddom, like any nerddom, is great for making quick connections while abroad.
Needless to say, if you’re ever in Copenhagen you need to give this place a look for lunch. It’s a little pricier than just going to a kebab place or something, but it’s still reasonable (for Denmark) and entirely worth it. One of the best meals of my trip. And if you’re not going to Copenhagen any time soon, keep an eye out for Evil Twin or Mikkeller beer at your local bar or liquor store. Be sure to read the labels; both breweries have excellent senses of humor.
Just as a reminder, I’m choosing to write about favorite spots and stories in each city I visited as opposed to major attractions which you can read about in any guidebook. Yes, I visited Christiania and the Nationalmuseet and the Little Mermaid statue and all that. If you want to hear more detail about my trip, just talk to me ☺
--
--
A travel journal by Brian Lange
I design, code, and think for @dsatweet. I tweet about data geek stuff, music stuff, beer stuff, food stuff, design stuff, and life in Chicago.

Title: My Ill-Fated Trip to Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A place for unique non-fiction stories based on travel memories.

--
5
Listen
Share
In November 1981, having lived in West Berlin for four months, I was given the unexpected privilege of having four days off from my job at the Hotel Schweizerhof. I was ready for an adventure and gave careful consideration regarding where I should spend the days.
Paris was too far away, a fourteen-hour train trip. It took very long to get anywhere in Western Europe from the walled-in city that was closer in distance to Poland than it was to West Germany. A co-worker told me it was possible to go to Copenhagen directly from East Berlin. Not only was it a much shorter trip than going through West Germany, but it was also significantly cheaper.
I didn’t need much time to think it over. I was going to spend my little vacation in Copenhagen.
I went through the always intimidating checkpoint at the Friedrichstrasse station in East Berlin and procured a transit visa. This was a rather routine affair and didn’t require the complicated application process for obtaining a tourist visa. I had not even considered spending my holiday in East Germany, the nearest country. Ironically, that’s what I would end up doing.
I was excited as the train pulled out of the East Berlin station and headed north toward the Baltic Sea. By the time we reached Warnemuende, the seaside town from where the ferry would cross to Denmark, darkness had already descended.
There were not many passengers heading for the ferry terminal, perhaps fifty or sixty, and all appeared to be Westerners. Of course, that is not surprising considering the fact that East Germans were generally prohibited from traveling to Western countries.
The train soon pulled out of the station and headed back to East Berlin. Meanwhile, I gathered with my fellow ferry passengers in the terminal. I immediately had the sense that something wasn’t quite right. I looked out on the dock and didn’t see a ferry.
My ears picked up someone speaking English and I gravitated to that voice. It belonged to a young South African, who I later learned was heading to Copenhagen to spend a semester at the university there. He was speaking with a Danish couple.
They told me the ferry was delayed because it couldn’t make the crossing safely in the stormy sea. I never even thought about weather conditions. In my mind, I pictured a serene sea and a calm, relaxing three-hour crossing. The news that the sea was not at all as I imagined made me worried. I am not a sea-faring person. I always prefer to have my traveling feet on solid ground, or at least on reliable tracks. I have given in to air travel as an unavoidable necessity.
The Danish couple made inquiries and then informed us that it was unlikely the ferry would be arriving that night.
My initial reaction was relief. I wouldn’t have to face a multi-hour ferry crossing on a stormy sea. Always the optimist, I assumed the storm would subside during the night and the next day the sea would be calm, and we would be able to make the crossing under a blue sky, basking in the autumn sunlight. Okay, I was waxing poetic in my mind and not being particularly realistic. I was shaping the adventure I wanted to have.
There wasn’t much we could do. I was realistic enough not to expect the East German terminal police to provide us with mattresses and blankets. People grabbed the few chairs that were around, but most of us had to make do with the hard floor.
Needless to say, it was not a restful sleep. In fact, I doubt that I dozed off for more than a few minutes.
We were stirred awake by a not very cheerful “Guten Morgen” (Good Morning) and informed that we had the opportunity of purchasing East German marks (currency) so that we could have breakfast if we wished. Of course that would be at the one-to-one ratio that East Germany maintained was the true value of their money, when in reality it was about six East marks for one West mark. But who would be foolish enough to argue with them? I was hungry and didn’t really mind.
I stayed close to Dennis the South African, and the Danish couple in order to get the latest information about when the ferry would be arriving. I looked outside and was disappointed that my fantasy image didn’t appear to be manifesting. The sea was gray and stormy.
The couple was not about to spend the whole day waiting for a ferry that may or may not come. They had an alternative plan. They informed Dennis and me that there was another ferry, a very reliable one, that sailed from Sassnitz, a town in the far eastern part of East Germany. This ferry, however, didn’t go to Denmark but rather to Sweden. It would then be fairly easy to cross over to Denmark.
The couple walked up to the terminal police and indicated their plan to travel to Sassnitz. Watching from a distance, I could see that the police did not like the idea, probably because we didn’t have tourist visas for traveling around East Germany. We all just had transit visas for the route we were on.
But the couple was not going to be dissuaded and somehow got permission to leave for Sassnitz. Dennis decided to join them. I elected to as well. I didn’t want to spend most of my four-day trip in a ferry terminal. I thought it would be an unexpected adventure to travel across the northern region of East Germany and end up a stone’s throw from Poland.
A few hours later, the four of us boarded a train for the journey east. I soon realized that train travel in East Germany is laboriously slow. The tracks were obviously not in great shape. But I really wasn’t in a hurry. I had nearly forgotten about my original destination and now embraced the unexpected change my journey had taken.
We were on a local train route and made innumerable stops at small, dilapidated stations. In between the stations was a very pleasant countryside, fields and farms with an occasional small lake.
I was aware that we were attracting attention from the other passengers. Many of them, living so far from the capital city, East Berlin, probably never heard English spoken and it was unlikely that they ever encountered Westerners.
I wondered if the East German passengers were looking at us with envy that we had so much more material wealth than they did. Or perhaps they were expressing disapproval of us as decadent capitalists. German facial expressions are difficult to interpret.
It was already late afternoon when we saw in the distance a beautiful old town with a soaring steeple. The November light cast a soft golden haze over it. For some reason, the train was not stopping there. My companions told me it was Stralsund, one of the historic Hanseatic towns on the Baltic Sea. They heard that it had a well-preserved medieval center. I made a mental note of it for a future journey.
At last, we arrived at our destination. Although we were close to Poland there was no border crossing nearby. Sassnitz was more like a village than a town. But it was from this out-of-the-way location, at the eastern extremity of East Germany that the reported reliable ferry would be departing for Sweden. We easily found the tiny terminal and there was in fact a ferry there.
My fellow travelers were excited and walked immediately to the ticket booth to purchase a ticket. I stood back and gave some thought to whether I would join them. I looked at the sea. While it was not as stormy as it had been at the other location, it nevertheless did not match my ideal of calmness. It would also be a much longer crossing than with the other ferry. For Sweden was quite far from East Germany. I only had two days left of my allotted time off. I would arrive in Denmark just in time to depart.
That might not have dissuaded me from continuing on with the others, however; what really convinced me not to go was the sea crossing. The prospect of a long, rough crossing on an unpredictable sea was not inviting. I thus bid farewell to my companions as they prepared to board the ship.
I walked to the little train station and purchased a ticket to East Berlin.
I seemed to be the only one boarding the night train to Berlin. I had the compartment all to myself. It was going to be a six-hour journey. I stretched out and rested but didn’t fall asleep. I was waiting for the conductor to come in and check my ticket. But no one came. I wondered if it was just me and the train engineer on the train. I heard no footsteps and no one boarded or disembarked from the train at each stop.
We arrived in East Berlin at half past four in the morning. I walked up to the entrance to the intimidating maze of mirrors and glass partitions that constituted the Kafkaesque passport control office that one needed to navigate in order to enter West Berlin. But it was closed.
It would open in one hour. I didn’t know where to wait. Not a single person was around. I didn’t want to simply stand there for an hour. So, I walked outside into the deathly still nighttime city center.
As I walked up dark, deserted Friedrichstrasse, I didn’t feel so much afraid, as I would have been on the streets of any American city at that hour. But I felt rather nervous because I was there illegally. I had no tourist visa and thus shouldn’t be strolling around the city. Fortunately, I encountered no uniformed agent. It was eerily silent. After walking back and forth along the street, I returned to the border crossing office.
At exactly half past five, the gate opened, the lights came on. I was the first and only customer. I promptly walked up to the glass partition and handed the agent my passport. He saw the transit visa issued three days earlier. He clearly was not pleased.
Still holding on to my passport, he walked away and spoke with other agents who were standing around with nothing to do. He returned and gestured me into an open area where I was soon surrounded by seven or eight border police agents. I was told to sit down on a chair that was in the middle of the area. The police gathered around me.
In normal circumstances, I would have been nervous finding myself in this situation. But I was exhausted, having hardly slept the last two nights, and so I was rather calm. I felt very American at that moment, thinking what are they going to do to an American citizen? Thank you red, white, and blue.
Then the questioning began. Fortunately, they spoke slowly and clearly so I could understand most but not all of what they were saying. I was having some difficulty responding in German and generously sprinkled my sentences with English words. I understood what the problem was. It was now my third day in the German Democratic Republic but I didn’t have a tourist visa. All I had was a transit visa issued three days before. They wanted to know exactly where I had been during all that time.
I managed to give them an account using increasingly more English words. They seemed to understand, or at least some of them did. While they noted that I spent the previous night on the train, they were perplexed about where I had been the night before. I proudly informed them that I spent it on the floor of the ferry terminal in Warnemuende.
This was apparently shocking for them to hear. I then added a bit cheekily that it wasn’t very comfortable accommodations.
That seemed to do the trick. They were not about to prompt another flare-up in the Cold War. I was allowed to re-enter West Berlin without any further delay.
I soon breathed the not particularly fresh air of freedom in West Berlin and headed back to my furnished room. I actually wasn’t disappointed that I never made it to Copenhagen. My unexpected adventure behind the Iron Curtain proved to be highly memorable.
My heartfelt thanks to Darren Weir for his editing suggestions and assistance with the photos.
--
--
5

Buddhist monk, formerly an Orthodox Christian monk, before that a professor of English literature, before that expatriate writer, living mostly in Berlin.

Title: Living in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Jebiga…
This is a pretty often word used by myself: Filip Malek, a 22 year old Software Development student, part time full stack web developer and a part homeless student from Croatia.
Let me give you a little back story and the reason of writing this article. It all started many, many, many years ago when I was a little angry, 6th grade rebellious kid who preferred running through forests playing airsoft, spending every single dime on surplus military equipment rather then spending time with his peers and doing all the usual shit that kids do at that age.
Why?
Its simple — I just couldn’t do what all the others did… It just didn’t make sense. I hated the idea of following trends and being just another fish in the sea following the usual everyday routines.
Why am I telling you all this?
Well, because going to the country you have never been to, with very limited financial resources, to a accommodation you have no clue is any good, without knowing anybody there that could help you out and if that isn’t good enough — flying for the first time in your life (if we ignore flying when I was 5 years old) — requires some serious guts, or craziness, or both…
The reason I opted for ‘Living in Copenhagen’ as the name of this article is because its just that — living, not studying.
There’s so much more to just studying in Copenhagen.
You don’t come here to study, you come here for a whole package. All the good things,bad things, headaches, relationships (both love and friendships)...
Studying in Denmark is very much different from, for example, studying in England or at the campus in the ‘states’. There you have a dorm room that you can live in as long as you study which is not really the case in Denmark. Of course there are dorms here but nobody is gonna find them for you and waiting lists for the bad ones are up to 12 months… It is completely up to you to find accommodation and even though you might get tips from school or others, it is still very, very hard.
You might be getting a hint on what I’m aiming with this article. No, it’s not the fact that finding a room/apartment in Copenhagen area is a living hell or that the weather is pretty sh**** or, in fact, that jobs you will do when you start off are pretty sh**** as well.
It’s just one man’s observation on the fact that life is HARD! And trying to start off in a country such as Denmark isn’t the easiest thing in the world and you won’t be padded on your back nor congratulated on every step of the way.
It is just a wake up call and a slap in the face from the life itself. You see, life is a tragedy, we can’t argue that. Ancient Greeks knew it way back when life was much simpler. Jordan Peterson wrote about it in his book “12 rules for life” — which I definitely recommend by the way! We just have to make sense of it all if we were to survive and live a meaningful life. To set of in a world at the age of 19 with circumstances that I had was a bold move and still, 3 years later, I am not comfortable enough to look at myself and say that there is no work left and let alone sit back and relax.
But I did actually kinda relax. I was living the life. Living super close to city center in my own place (I sublet a room with its own kitchen, toilet and separate entrance in a much bigger apartment), working was just 5 mins away and school barely 7, hitting the gym often and just being happy. I was super lucky to get that place. After being kicked out and having to crash at a friends sofa for a few days I got contacted by a lovely woman who offered me the room. That just doesn’t happen in Copenhagen. Usual practice is to send 10 messages a day to landlords looking for tenants and hope that after a few weeks you get invited for an open house. I knew that this doesn’t just happen and I treated it as such.I respected the rules and I decorated the place to my own taste. Bought a black board to note shit down (always wanted one), put Star Wars posters all around, old Copenhagen Tuborg commercial posters, Copenhagen Street Food memorabilia (used to work there for 2 years). Made a hygge corner (google it) with candles and stuff… It was a really nice place and I felt at home there.
Then life decided to happen…
On 1st of May there was a some plumbing work being done in my building so they cut off the water from 0700 to 1700. My upstairs neighbors did a small mistake that led me to being kicked out again… Don’t get me wrong, they are generally nice people. I don’t know them that much though. Small talk is considered awkward and you can really see a Dane not enjoying it if you don’t know him well, that is. So I didn’t talk to them. Except saying “Hello” when I saw them in the stairwell or “Tak” (danish for thank you) when they held the door for me or vice versa. All I knew is that they were a couple with two small kids. On 1st of May — when plumbers were plumbing away — their kid left the faucet open and around 1500 — when they connected the water back on — it started to flood everything… At least that’s what they told me. I am not blaming the kid (even though, technically it is his fault). He is just a kid after all. Maybe plumbers messed up when they turned the water on too early… I came home from work only to see my room being completely wet and water dripping form the ceiling. To be honest I wasn’t angry or anything. I just wanted to go to the gym. I even bough a Ultra White Monster and a Reese's bar. I waited until they shut down the water but didn’t want to wait for repair man to come so I told my landlord that I will be going to the gym. She was okay with that as there was little to nothing that I could do. Few days after insurance company came and said that I will have to move out along with all of my stuff until latest August. I was speechless, to way the least… By then, the damage should have been fixed.
This was 5th time that I was moving in almost 3 years of being in Denmark and I definitely wasn’t happy about it.
Then life showed its beautiful side and I stumbled upon a room 25 km from Copenhagen until my place gets fixed. My cousin met a Danish girl in Bulgaria on some kind of student event. Her parents have a house in Kokkedal (district somewhat close to Copenhagen) that they rent out to students and turns out that they had one room free just for me (rhyme is on purpose here :) ). I took it without too much thought. I am still extremely grateful to these wonderful people because without them, I am not sure what would have happened.
In the time of writing this article I am still living there. Three months have passed and repairs are only 50% done and I don’t know how long will it take them to finish but I at least hope to move back in once it is done.
I guess that at the end of the day this is life. Sometimes good things happen and sometimes bad things happen. You might get 10 bad things happen and then only one good thing or vice versa. Only logical thing to do is — and I quote great Jordan Peterson — to “Stand up straight with your shoulders back” and take it like a man.
Wining and complaining never helped anybody anyway…

Title: I Witnessed My Chinese Lesbian Friends Get Married in Copenhagen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Amplifying LGBTQ voices through the art of storytelling

Member-only story
--
30
Share
Facing Copenhagen City Hall across the street, Tivoli is the second-oldest amusement park in the world. I hold a special affection for it, because two same-sex partners in one of my favorite pioneering Chinese LGBTQ novels, Beijing Story (later adapted into the well-known film Lan Yu), bought a house in the suburbs of Beijing and named it Tivoli, hoping it could be as dreamy as the amusement park since they couldn’t be openly together in the city.
Tivoli became not only a shelter for them but also a haven where they could express and nurture their love. Many years have passed, yet we still need and yearn for such a place in reality.
I couldn’t hold back my excitement and took a quick look at Tivoli in the cold wind before running to catch up with my friend into Copenhagen City Hall.
My friend, K, walked ahead, glancing back repeatedly to check the wedding veil pinned to her shoulder, fearing it might fall. Her wedding with another girl, J, was to be held at City Hall in just half an hour. Two Chinese girls, getting married in a foreign country far from home.
The quiet and solemn City Hall was carefully decorated, with rainbow flags hanging in mid-air, rainbow stickers on the…

Title: Kastrup Søbad, Copenhagen: wind, rain, and swimming
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Life viewed from the water…

--
Listen
Share
By the time we got to Femøren metro stop the wind had picked up and the rain was lashing down. More inappropriate weather for a sea swim you couldn’t imagine. But it would take a bold — and rash — person to stand between me and a swimming adventure and so we pressed on, holding umbrellas horizontal, like shields in battle against the driving rain.
Half an hour previously, scurrying from the warmth of our cosy hotel to the metro station, we had had a tiff about umbrellas. Between us, you thought that one small black collapsible umbrella was not enough: it was raining, windy and miserable. You wanted me to shelter under the brolly beside you and and I didn’t want to pin myself to you to keep dry. I don’t care for umbrellas. I prefer getting wet and bedraggled to the fuss and bother of an umbrella. My protestations of “Look, I’m waterproof!” and “I’m not cold! I don’t mind getting a little wet!” didn’t convince you. It made you feel ungallant, you said.
“What if it’s really rainy when we get to the other end and there is a long walk?!” you wailed, persuading me to let you go and buy a second umbrella.
Thank goodness for the second umbrella, I had to concede. It was much worse by the time we got off the metro. A less determined expedition would have turned back. Instead, we pressed on. I was going to have my swim. We skirted through an industrial estate, crossed 4 lanes of traffic, and squelched our way across the sodden and marshy grass of a park because it seemed marginally quicker than the pathway. Anything to get out of the driving rain.
I’d seen pictures of Kastrup Sea Bath in glossy design and architecture magazines. It looked beautiful: an elegant curved wooden construction, warmed and weathered, at the end of a long jetty, where locals can swim, sunbathe and dive, sheltered from the elements.
On a day like today there were no swimmers, sunbathers, no hanger-outers. Not a soul. It looked beautifully desolate, forlorn, slightly spooky. The usually silvered wooden timbers were black and sodden with rain. The planks looked more like the snaggle-toothed weathered boards of a wrecked ship than a haven. There was nobody around. Had they all abandoned ship?
We walked out along the jetty to investigate more closely, I had a sense of foreboding. I hoped it might appear more inviting close up, but it felt just as bleak. Doors to changing rooms were locked, it felt like the world had left for the summer and well and truly locked up on the way out.
We decided, I decided, that a swim from the shore, from the beach, might be more prudent. We walked back along the jetty to the beach and found a large spartan changing room nearby and stripped off.
As we stood in our swimming gear on a cold autumn day, in the rain, in the middle of nowhere, slightly hysterical, miles from civilisation, a middle aged woman rode up noncholantly on a bike. Seemingly unphased by the vile weather, she leaned her bike against a wall, and walked along the jetty to the sea baths. The lifeguard had arrived! As we watched from the beach she wandered around the sea baths unlocking doors and settling in for a quiet day at the office. I felt more reassured by her arrival.
Back to the reason we’d come. We tiptoed into the water. Sand underfoot. Wincing. Cold. My feet hurt. Undeterred I waded in deeper, reasoning that being under the water would somehow would be warmer, because I’d be out of the wretched wind. You let the water dance across your thighs, and then turned back, not as convinced by the beauty of the cold as I was.
Emboldened by the presence of another human being who might be able to help if something went wrong (what would go wrong?!) I headed out from the shore. Breastsroke at first — to take in the view — and then front crawl. Out past the edge of the sand into an area of tall seaweed beds. I tasted the water — it was suprisingly unsalty. Is it the sea? Or a river to the sea?
Becoming bolder, I headed further out — swimming alongside the jetty, with little choppy waves to slap me as I went. Arriving soon at the haven of the wooden platform I was greeted by the lifeguard, a middle aged Danish woman, smoking a cigarette, wrapped up against the weather. As I treaded water, we smiled and said hello. “14.5C” she offered, unprompted, with a friendly smile. The international language of swimmers. Would she swim, I asked? Perhaps. How many people would swim today? About five to six.
Then I saw you wandering back along the jetty, in only your trunks, to join us.
And there we were, the three of us, chatting away: one fully clothed and bundled against the cold, one standing half naked in the wind, and one bobbing about in the water. On a swimming platform, out to sea, in the wind and rain. Oh Copenhagen. What better way to experience a place than to be right there, surrounded by it. Inside it.
If you liked this article, please clap the clappy things below to show your appreciation. Click the (Follow) button if you’d like Medium to alert you when something new is published.
--
--
Life viewed from the water…
Swimmer, writer, eternal optimist
